story:
Our Story

The Threadbare Sex was the inaugural production of  Coryphaeus Theater Company three years ago, when Mara Lileas, Naomi McDougall Jones, Mia Romero, Gwenevere Sisco, and Elspeth Turner came together to tell a story - an innovative and breathtaking exploration of justice, freedom, love, loneliness, and power through the eyes of three women.  Written by Mia and Naomi, The Threadbare Sex follows three iconic Greek women, Antigone, Cassandra, and Electra, from Ancient Greece, through an 1860s drawing room comedy, and into the present day. In each re-incarnation, the women wrangle with their own fates and what it means to be the threadbare sex.

The Threadbare Sex was first performed in July 2008 at the Rose Nagelberg Theatre, as part of the Strawberry One-act Festival, in which it was a finalist and Gwenevere Sisco was nominated for Best Director.  Due to the fantastic response, it was further developed and produced full-scale in September 2008 at Manhattan Repertory Theatre.  Coryphaeus has continued to produce daring and powerful theatre on shoestring budget, and now we have the chance to present Threadbare Sex at Manhattan Theatre Source, as part of Unsex Me Here: A Night of Two Plays, opening July 11th. 

We have a revamped and revitalized script, a wildly talented cast which now includes Veronica del Cerro, and a magnificent venue - all we need now is your support!

 


The Impact

Coryphaeus is aiming to revolutionize theatre by making the female voice and presence a definitive force onstage. We tell these stories because we believe they need to be told.  This is why we produce them from our own pockets.  But if you’ve ever peeked into the pockets of a New York City starving artist, you can probably imagine the challenge ahead of us.  So your donation not only supports groundbreaking independent theatre, but it also means that our food/shelter piggybanks remain intact!


What We Need & What You Get

Our budgetary needs:  We’re serious bargain-hunters, so we’re keeping the budget extremely tight.  That said, Rehearsal space alone will cost us approximately $300, paying our crew will require another $200, and printing costs for programs and marketing materials tend to add up to $50-100.  We’re hoping the rest will cover all our costume/prop/set needs.
It would be lovely if we could pay our actors for their time and extraordinary talent, but that depends on what’s leftover.  Rest assured that whether or not we make our goal, every little bit of your donation will go toward this production. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Tell all your friends about this fantastic opportunity to support our Theatre Company.  And most of all, COME SEE OUR SHOW!!!  We’re nothing without our audience, so please mark your calendars, invite everyone you know, and let us thank you in person for your support.

story:
Our Story

Dreamtime is a Bangla- and English- language interactive puppetry show for 3-5 year olds in the London boroughs of Tower Hamlets and Hackney. The live show will be filmed to develop a free online learning tool and will be pitched to theatre companies for full production.

 

The fantastical JungleHead Kolpotoru (â€œImagination Treeâ€) invites us into her dreams where we meet Slither the Snake. Slitherâ€™s day is full of challenges, but as he meets a series of colourful new friends along the way they help him to learn some essential life lessons such as valuing ones friends, being determined to succeed and above all being true to oneself. Babu the Baby Bird, a group of colourful jungle anemones, Mama Wolf and her cubs, and five precocious stars sing, dance, and teach colours, words and numbers in engaging, original scenes.

 

The multi-sensory environment uses soundscapes, tactile objects and magical scenery and a repeated format with scenes of 3-6 minutes to engage children throughout the 40-minute play. In a specially created after-show workshop children will make puppets to take home, learn songs from the play, create an improvised poem and experience imagined journeys through the jungle.

 

Weâ€™ve been offered a fantastic space to put on the show, 80% of the audience is guaranteed and several local childrenâ€™s centres have expressed an interest in bringing children to the show. The script is being finalised under the expert guidance of our early years theatre advisor, rehearsals and training for puppeteers are already taking place - now we simply need to create the puppets and the set to be ready for our premiere on the 26th February 2012!


The Impact

The 2011 Ofsted report highlights â€œthe poor quality of early years provision in deprived areasâ€ with Hackney and Tower Hamlets being ranked as two of the three most deprived areas in the country. The Department of Education stresses â€œLiteracy is the area with the lowest percentage of children working securely within Early Learning Goalsâ€. There is no doubt that this project is urgently needed in our target area, with special need from within the Bangladeshi community:

 

â€œSecond and third generation [Bengali] children still have bilingual skills, but are in danger of losing them unless they have sufficient support to develop their mother tongue.â€  (www.naldic.org.uk)

 

By addressing and encouraging bilingualism in English and Bangla, Dreamtime seeks to foster cross-cultural understanding as well as literacy. There are few, if any, Early Years educational theatre projects in the area in Bangla and it is well-recognised that attendance of cultural events is low: â€œJust try to get a Bangladeshi audience into the theatre. They will not come.â€ - Bangladeshi Director Mukul Ahmed (TARA Arts; National Theatre)

 

We have established links with the community however and have gauged interest in the project from key target groups such as Jagonari Sure Start Centre (a majority Bangladeshi centre) and Hackney Learning Trust. In order to circulate it further the show will be filmed and turned into a free online learning resource with websites such as www.earlylearninghq.org.uk keen to host the video. We also hope that Dreamtime will be commissioned by one of the established theatres that we are inviting to the show.


The Creative Team

A strong creative team will ensure that the quality of the show will be high. Writer and director Imogen Butler-Cole spent two years working in young peopleâ€™s theatre in Bangladesh (2009-11). One of her projects was to implement curriculum enhancement through drama for Early Years students of English and Bangla for a respected NGO for children outside the education system. Here she developed the Dreamtime script using puppets to teach literacy and numeracy.

 

Puppetry direction and puppet-making is by Katerina Damvoglou (Hightide, Blind Summit). Performers are Mariana Whitehouse, Sophie Page Hall (trained in puppetry at LISPA) and Showmi Das (Bangladeshi actress and puppeteer). Set design sketches by Florence McHugh and puppet designs by Studio Inku can be seen in our video. Marigold Hughes (Theatre Centre) is our Early Years Theatre Advisor. Anusheh Anadil (Bangla Band) is advising on Bangla scripting. Producer for THEWHATWORKS, Ine Van Riet (Kids United, Little Cauliflower Theatre Company) specialises in working for young people.

What We Need & What You Get

THEWHATWORKS have applied to both statutory and private bodies for a large percentage of our costs for Dreamtime. Fees for performers and production team, venues, haulage, hospitality and overheads will all be covered by these grants. We are also fortunate to be sponsored by the award-winning Bertie Films who will cover film-making and hospitality costs.

 

This leaves us with the most exciting part of the project â€“ creating the puppets themselves. We need to buy materials for mock-up puppets to be experimented with until we find the perfect style and design. The designers and creators of the puppets need to be paid for their time. Once designs are perfected we need to make the final puppets themselves. And this is where you come in!

 

We are offering you the opportunity to adopt a puppet for yourself or a child of your acquaintance, by becoming its Auntie or Uncle. As a puppet's Auntie or Uncle you will receive a design sketch of the creature, an invitation to the show (adults will only be admitted if accompanied by a child below the age of 10), a photograph of the finished puppet and monthly updates from your adopted creature. These updates, as with the show itself, will contain fun educational material created in line with Early Years learning objectives. They will include photos of the puppet you have adopted as they live out their lives, and will give you a unique position as Auntie or Uncle of the animal when you come to see the show. Just imagine a childâ€™s face as they watch their very own adopted animal performing to a live audience, then get to meet them in person after the show!

 

If we do not reach our final funding target the puppets will still be created but our resources will be massively limited and we will not be able to pay our amazingly talented team for their time and effort. And we at THEWHATWORKS believe in fair pay, so please help us to ensure that all our creatives are paid for their hard work!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us by sharing information about this campaign to your own networks, especially those with young children, friends or hearts, who might be particularly touched by the opportunity to love one of our special friends! Just click on any of the links below to see our campaign on facebook, twitter, youtube or our website. Thank you for your supoprt!

story:
HELLO! And thank you for visiting our campaign and taking a moment to read about our exciting new show.

MONKEY is a new dark comedy written by Offie-nominated writer David K. Barnes (Wooden Overcoats, Timothy, Doctor Who) written specifically for TumbleDry Theatre. It will be performed at The Vaults Network Theatre, Waterloo at 7.30pm throughout 13th – 17th February 2019.

 

WHY THIS SHOW?

SUCCESS at Edinburgh Fringe 2018 and an official sell out show prompted us to apply with a new show for VAULTS FESTIVAL 2019. Building upon the decade long collaboration between VAULT favourite David K. Barnes and TumbleDry Director John Rushton, ‘Monkey’ was the obvious choice. Originally written for John, both MONKEY and TumbleDry Theatre debuted in 2015 at the Drayton Arms Theatre, South Kensington.

Audience Praise from Fringe 2018

 

ABOUT THE WRITER

CREATOR of the critically acclaimed podcast sitcom 'Wooden Overcoats', David K. Barnes’s stage plays include the Offie-nominated 'Birthday Suit', 'Games of Love and Chance', and the internationally produced 'Timothy', whilst audio credits include 'Doctor Who' and 'The Discovery Adventures'.

 

 

ABOUT THE COMPANY

“MASTERS OF STORY TELLING” (WeeReview 2017) Tumble Dry Theatre is run by John Rushton, Jenni Goodchild, Robin Hellier and Connor Jones. Our debut production was an early version of ‘Monkey' in 2015. Since then, we have gone on to produce projects in London and Edinburgh including, ‘A Soldier and Death’, ‘The Wonderful World of Dissocia’ and ‘A Trilogy of Horrors’. We delight in sharing stories new and old with all audiences, and hope you can join us in The Vaults for our newest show!

 

“All of the components are in place ... TumbleDry have a lot more on the cards” – WeeReview 2017

 

WHAT IS THE FUNDING FOR?

WHAT'S IT FOR? We are looking to raise some money to help fund our show at The Vaults. We would need the funds to pay for:

  • Posters and flyers to advertise the show at the festival
  • Venue hire fees
  • Props and costume
  • Cast and Crew

Producing a show is very expensive and we would very much appreciate any help you can give. Shows like MONKEY are the life blood of the Vaults Festival and we would love for you to be part of the future of the show. As a backer you will be kept up to date with any news or reviews that come out of the production.

 

WHAT YOU'LL GET

 

 

THANK YOU

THANK YOU for reading, watching, sharing and donating. We at TumbleDry Theatre value the importance of fringe theatre and the opportunities it gives HIGHLY SKILLED AND TALENTED actors, directors and writers to explore new ideas. As a patron of the arts, YOU are apart of the creative movement that promotes innovations and creativity in the theatre, and on behalf of ourselves and performers worldwide we are deeply grateful and humbled by your support.

-TumbleDry Theatre

story:
PARKER & DIZZY RETURN TO NEW YORK!

We are thrilled to announce that Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow is returning to New York City for a limited engagement. Running January 9th to the 26th! Here's what critics said about our production when it premiered at the New York International Fringe Festival in 2011:

“By far the best play I’ve seen so far at this year’s Fringe is Parker & Dizzy’s Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow, a head-spinningly fun campy musical ode to every gay icon from Crawford to Gaga. I was expecting a low rent version of another gay musical, but it’s so much better and smarter than that. Be warned the humor is campier than an episode of RuPaul’s Drag Race with rapid-fire vaudevillian one-liners and well crafted but broad musical numbers… I can honestly say that Parker & Dizzy’s acting and production values were better than the last Broadway show I saw.” – Chris Thomas, Out-FM

 

Highlighted by Huffington Post as one of ‘The Best Shows of 2011.’ “This is the most promising musical I saw at FringeFest.” – Michael Giltz, Huffington Post

 

”I am happy to report that “Parker and Dizzy,” a warped re-imagining of “The Wizard of Oz” with detours into “Star Wars,” “Thelma and Louise,” “Ghost,” and a hundred other pop-cultural landmarks, is a joyous, loopy romp – precisely the kind of show you dream of discovering at FringeNYC. Beneath the jibes and jokes and camp, “parker and Dizzy” is an old-fashioned musical with a heart of gold, wanting little more than to make sense of a cruel world. People help each other. Good triumphs over evil. Love saves the day. And hope springs eternal.” – David Kennerley, Gay City News

BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP TO MAKE IT HAPPEN!


We need to mount a production of this complete with costume, sound, props, musicians, publicity, the works. Your donation to this project will help make this dream of ours a reality. By contributing money to this project, you are helping the artists associated with this project to see an original production come to fruition. We have set our goal at $4000 but if we reach that, please keep giving! Every cent raised on this site will absolutely go to the funding of this production. 
Please spread the word! Tell your friends about us. Visit our Facebook page. And please, above all else, come and see the show! We would love to see everyone there.

The Players

PETER ZACHARI (Director / Playwright / Music & Lyrics) wrote, produced and directed Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow for the New York International Fringe Festival. He has also written Fat Asses: The Musical, The 3rd Gender, Lighten Up!, which was produced off-off-Broadway, as well as Loosen Up!, Shake It Up!, Live It Up!, and One Love. His ten-minute play, I Am Seventy Going on Eighteen was selected for production at the Boston Theatre Marathon VII.  Mr. Zachari’s directing credits include Into the Woods, Footloose, Rumors, Grease, They’re Playing Our Song, Return to the Forbidden Planet and Moon Over Buffalo (Summer Theatre at Salem) as well as West Side Story (Marblehead High School.)  For several years, Mr. Zachari taught Acting and Directing for the Department of Theatre at Salem State University.  He received his Master of Fine Arts from the University of Florida and his Bachelor of Fine Arts from Salem State University.  Peter is forever grateful to every individual who contributed to this production.  Follow Peter @zachatack on Twitter.

DAMON MAIDA (Music & Lyrics) is a singer and songwriter based in New York City.  As a performer, he has appeared at some of New York's premiere listening rooms (The Bitter End, Symphony Space, Piano's and Triad).  Damon is a frequent co-writer and is excited to be working with Peter Zachari fresh from their success of Fat Asses: The Musical and Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow.  When not writing songs with Peter, Damon can be seen singing with his vocal band The Perspective.  Also an actor and voice-over artist, Damon's voice can be heard on a number of children's video games, commercials, and the newest "World of Warcraft: Cataclysm" video game.  Damon is currently writing music for the follow-up to his debut album "Only Child," available through CD Baby and iTunes.

JOEY MIRABILE (Choreographer) choreographed Parker & Dizzy’s Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow for the New York International Fringe Festival as well as Fat Asses: The Musical for Theater for the New City.  His collaborations as choreographer with Peter Zachari have included Into the Woods, Grease and Footloose (Summer Theatre at Salem) as well as West Side Story (Marblehead High School).  Joey has also choreographed Oklahoma! and Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat (Marblehead Little Theatre) as well as teaching musical theatre dance classes at A Dancer’s Dream.  Joey Mirabile shares his love with the cast and crew, and reminds them to live, love and “just dance.”  Paws up, Little Monsters.  Follow Joey @JoeyMirabile on Twitter

DOUGLAS MAXWELL (Musical Director / Arranger) has been lucky to work with incredibly talented singers and songwriters around the various theatre scenes in NYC for the past ten years.  He is very excited to work with Peter and Damon again after serving as musical director for Fat Asses: The Musical and Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow.  You probably haven’t seen him before unless you frequent the 1 train to the Upper Upper West Side on a regular basis.

We have set our goal at $4000 but if we reach that, please keep giving! Every cent raised on this site will absolutely go to the funding of this production. 
Please spread the word! Tell your friends about us. Visit our Facebook page. And please, above all else, come and see the show! We would love to see everyone there.

The Players


PETER ZACHARI (Director / Playwright / Music &
Lyrics) wrote, produced and directed Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to
the End of the Rainbow for the New York International Fringe Festival. He has
also written Fat Asses: The Musical, The 3rd Gender, Lighten Up!, which was produced
off-off-Broadway, as well as Loosen Up!,
Shake It Up!, Live It Up!, and One
Love. His ten-minute play, I Am
Seventy Going on Eighteen was selected for production at the Boston Theatre
Marathon VII.  Mr. Zachari’s directing credits include Into the Woods, Footloose, Rumors, Grease, They’re Playing Our
Song, Return to the Forbidden Planet and Moon Over Buffalo (Summer Theatre at Salem) as well as West Side Story (Marblehead High
School.)  For several years, Mr. Zachari taught Acting and Directing for
the Department of Theatre at Salem State University.  He received his
Master of Fine Arts from the University of Florida and his Bachelor of Fine
Arts from Salem State University.  Peter is forever grateful to every
individual who contributed to this production.  Follow Peter @zachatack
on Twitter.
DAMON MAIDA (Music & Lyrics) is a singer and
songwriter based in New York City.  As a performer, he has appeared at
some of New York's premiere listening rooms (The Bitter End, Symphony Space,
Piano's and Triad).  Damon is a frequent co-writer and is excited to be
working with Peter Zachari fresh from their success of Fat Asses: The Musical and Parker
& Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow.  When not
writing songs with Peter, Damon can be seen singing with his vocal band The
Perspective.  Also an actor and voice-over artist, Damon's voice can be
heard on a number of children's video games, commercials, and the newest
"World of Warcraft: Cataclysm" video game.  Damon is currently
writing music for the follow-up to his debut album "Only Child,"
available through CD Baby and iTunes.



JOEY MIRABILE (Choreographer) choreographed Parker & Dizzy’s Fabulous Journey to the
End of the Rainbow for the New York International Fringe Festival as well
as Fat Asses: The Musical for Theater
for the New City.  His collaborations as choreographer with Peter Zachari
have included Into the Woods, Grease and
Footloose (Summer Theatre at Salem) as well as West Side Story (Marblehead High School).  Joey has also
choreographed Oklahoma! and Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat
(Marblehead Little Theatre) as well as teaching musical theatre dance classes
at A Dancer’s Dream.  Joey Mirabile shares his love with the cast and
crew, and reminds them to live, love and “just dance.”  Paws up, Little
Monsters.  Follow Joey @JoeyMirabile on Twitter
DOUGLAS MAXWELL (Musical Director / Arranger) has been
lucky to work with incredibly talented singers and songwriters around the
various theatre scenes in NYC for the past ten years.  He is very excited
to work with Peter and Damon again after serving as musical director for Fat Asses: The Musical and Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the
End of the Rainbow.  You probably haven’t seen him before unless you
frequent the 1 train to the Upper Upper West Side on a regular basis.

story:
What is “Stronger Than the Wind?”

This show is about my journey with my son, Aidan, who had a stroke at 2 weeks old due to hospital bacteria.  He subsequently had 6 brain surgeries, hydrocephalus, cerebral palsy, cognitive impairment, and ongoing seizures.

It is the story of my family, a middle class family that lost everything (including our sense of humor for a while), due to an unexpected medical catastrophe.  This is the journey from fear to love, anger to acceptance, depression to joy. It is an honest account of our ongoing roller coaster ride - one that is familiar to special needs families and those who’ve suffered chronic illness.

I taught acting at Harvard, and have worked in theatre, commercials and film.   I have been writing and performing autobiographical shows for 20 years, but this one is extremely special.  The overwhelming response I have received from people who’ve heard my story or seen it is; “Everyone must see this show.  It is important.” 

I want to share this story with as many people as possible, not just your average theatergoer.   I plan to take it to numerous theatres and organizations in as many cities as possible.  The types of organizations I believe can benefit from this performance are:  Special Needs, Healthcare, Parenting, PTSD, Psychology, Women’s groups, Spiritual, Motivational and Comic.

 

My intention is to “use my gifts” of acting and writing to bring catharsis, comfort and laughter to others who have been through trauma or are currently struggling. 

 

 

What We Need and What You Get

 

1.  This is the funding I need:    $40,000.00

To co-produce the show in Los Angeles and Washington, D.C.

The Money raised will be used for:

Theatre Rental

Lighting Designer

Video and Sound Designer

Music

Stage Manager

Lighting Technician

Marketing

Director

Actor

Theatre Staff

Costumes

Set and Props

Transportation

                      

I will continue fundraising beyond this initial goal.  My intention is to raise $300,000 so I can perform the show all over the world, in as many theatres and for as many organizations as possible.

  

The Perks 

Because Duct tape is “stronger than the wind,” and my daughter Caroline happens to love making  “ductcessories,”  we’ll be offering one of a kind duct tape creations as our gifts to you for any donations over $50.00

                          Bracelet!

                                                                        Earrings!

                          Wallet!

                                                                        Necklace!

                         "Spongebob" Tie!


                                                                               Purse!

                        Shoes!

                                                                               Shorts!


****If you’re not able to contribute monetarily, you can help spread the word about this show.   Send it to anyone interested or involved with any of these issues:  Healthcare, Special Needs, PTSD, Parenting, Motivational, Spiritual, Women’s groups, or anyone interested in experiencing a great show.  Pass it on through word-of-mouth, through Facebook, e-mail, Twitter and any other social media you enjoy.

Thank you for supporting “Stronger Than the Wind!”

Special Thanks to all the generous people who have helped and encouraged this journey with “Stronger Than the Wind.”   To name just a few…

Carl Reiner, Annie Reiner, Helen Hand, Geoffrey Dwyer, Judy Nagy, George Shapiro, Bess Scher, David O’Malley, Sally Schaub, Nancy Staack, Harvey Chao, Mark Travis, Jennifer Kocek Saggiao,  Juliette Marshall, Mary Monreal, Elizabeth and Bridget Benninger, Carole Graham Lehan, William H. Graham, Laura Graham Fetters, Emily DeLaney Pedante, Chris Griffiths, Liz Forer, The Venice Family Clinic, Dr. Campbell, Dr. Tom Walter, Drs. Tom and Ann Belin, The Huffpost, Sarah Brokaw, Drs. Bonnie and David Paul, Freedom to Choose Prison Project, Jennifer Lear, Marisa Putt, Paul Jerome,  Michael Magenta, Robin Brennan, Isaiah McGee, Sybil Walker, Damon Burks, Bryan Bellomo, Craig Wallace, Greg Foster, Kim Israel, Charles  Dayton, Terri Cavanaugh, Janit Baldwin, The entire Manning family, The entire Hubbard Family.

story:
Parasol Arts is a non-profit organization that advances and promotes the arts of Argentine tango through professional performances and educational outreach. Tango is transformative for participants and viewers alike. Parasol Arts is passionate about sharing this vibrant art form as both a social activity and as a performance art for all to enjoy. 

Support this special fundraising effort aimed to help us underwrite an original tango production with world-class tango dancers and musicians. You are key to making this dream possible for the artists and for our enjoyment of our community. As a start-up non profit organization, we have yet to become eligible for many grants and since ticket sales alone do not cover the costs of theatrical production -  artists fees, costumes, and lighting - your support is critical. 

What We Need & What You Get

The premier performances of El Corazon de Tango will take place at the Vintage Theatre in Aurora, Colorado on February 8 and 9, 2014. 

We hope, with your help, we will achieve our goal of raising $5,000. to underwrite this original dance work. 

Donor benefits include:

* Priority ticket purchasing 

* Program listing indicating your support of Parasol Arts

* Invitation to our Meet The Artists post-performance reception

* Complimentary tango class with a member of the cast

Where We Began

On February 9, 2013, Parasol Arts produced Tango Love at the Vintage theatre to a sold-out enthusiastic audience. The positive feedback inspired us to plan the upcoming show and continue to raise awareness of our company and our community engagement efforts, which include in-school performances for area students.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help this project and other work of Parasol Arts by spreading the word about our work with your friends and contacts through social media links or email. If you can volunteer time, please drop us a line at info@parasolarts.org

story:
Hi! I'm Kyla and I'm the Artistic Director of Key West Contemporary Dance Co.  We're working hard to fund our 2013-2014 season because we believe that dance is a vital part of every community.  We want Key West to have a strong and viable dance scene.  Over the past five years, we've done some great shows, like 1969 for example, but so far we've only been able to work on a project-to-project basis...Now we're ready to take the next step: A 30 week annual season!

When you help fund this campaign, you are supporting passionate and gifted dancers by giving them the opportunity to do their work in a small, regional setting that would otherwise have very little dance.  With your support, the artists will be able to...

1. work with and inspire local children

2. provide free dance performances for the community

3. enhance, diversify and strengthen the cultural fabric of our very small island

Currently our only scheduled perfomance this year is the A-T benefit at Lincoln Center, hosted by Priscilla Lopez, produced by Eric Weinberger.  Yes! We're at Lincoln Center, but we currently have no funding for shows in Key West.  You can help us change this.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to...

1. Employ 6 local dancers, full-time for a 30 week season annually.  $500/week ($90,000) 

2. Employ 4 visiting dancers full-time for 6 weeks.  $400/week ($9600)

-total per diem ($2982)

-total airfare ($1200)

-housing (We are currently seeking generous donations from local hotels.)

Total Artist Costs:

$103,782

The total sum of $103, 782 will ensure the following outlined goals happen:

1. Create & Present
We will create and present 3 original, full-length shows over the span of a 30 week season at local theatres, parks, and other venues each with a legit run and ample preparation time to ensure artistic excellence. These performances would vary in price range (FREE & Up!), to ensure that everyone can be exposed to dance.  
 
2. OutReach
We will implement a dance program in which company members go into the schools to teach, inspire and perform with and for the children of Key West.
This would last over a period of several weeks, twice yearly; With a steady focus on inspiring creativity, encouraging self-expression and boosting self-confidence.
 
3. Tour Locally
Key West, Marathon, Key Largo.  We will perform throughout the Florida Keys in schools, parks, theatres and other venues.  We believe that dance is a vital part of every community and should be accessible to all.
 
4. Partner 
We will partner with local agencies to aid in fundraising through dance performance. We'd like to be able to perform at benefits free of charge.  Dance is a language that we all speak.  It Inspires; It Heals; It Unites!
 
What you get is....
 
The satisfaction of knowing that you just supported a dedicated, talented group of artists.... And one of our awesome perks over there to the right---->

If we don't reach our entire goal, your donation is certainly not in vain.  It simply means that we will keep plugging away, and working as hard as we possibly can until we do get there.

The Impact

Kyla:  When we make the assumption that good dance is 'out there', that it is reserved for NYC/LA/etc...We're making the decision to, in a way, silence part of our voice as a community.  Dance is such an innate, expressive, direct reaction to our surroundings, and since I consider myself mostly a 'jazz' dancer, this statement rings so true to me: it's in my heart. When I create movement, it's simply my soul using my muscles to say what it wants.  I'm not even aware of why or how, it just happens.  And it's such a force, that I can't stop it, I can't judge it and I certainly can't quit it - No matter what.  It's such an honest force.  I need to share it.  I need to share it because children deserve to be inspired by people who lead their lives with their hearts.  I need to share it because Key West is starved for dance.  I need to share it for reasons that I don't even understand.

But who the heck are we?!

CHECK OUT OUR 2012-2013 ARTISTS HERE.

We've been around for four years now. We're housed by the generous CoffeeMill Dance Studio.  We've received funding four times from The Florida Keys Council of the Arts and we are a 501c3 nonprofit.  We've had shows produced by The Waterfront Playhouse, and additionally we've presented shows at The Tennessee Williams Theatre, The San Carlos Institute and The Tropic Cinema.  We've done an enormous amount of good work on a shoestring budget.  This past August we were invited to show an excerpt from our popular show 1969 at Dixon Place as part of NYC10. Also, as I mentioned earlier, we have a performance coming up at Lincoln Center in April.  We are a delicious blend of local and visiting artists and we are committed to making this happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

Every single penny counts! But if your gift to us does not necessarily have to come in monetary form. Please know that simple 'sharing' this via email or though any of your social networks, rocks our socks off!

Thanks so much for taking the time to check out our campaign.  

Wishing you love and happiness!

Kyla & Company

Other Ways You Can Help

Thanks so much for taking the time to check out our campaign.  
Wishing you love and happiness!
Kyla & Company

story:
Written by Mara Wilson
Directed by Max Reuben

At the New York City International Fringe Festival 2013

It's a summer day during Bush's reign, and Nick is determined to save the world, score some pot, make Soo-Min his girlfriend, and have his LaVeyan Satanist brother talk his best friend Alberto out of enlisting. SHEEPLE is about what to do when "everything you know is wrong."

Mara Wilson is a recovering former child actor best known for her roles in the films Matilda and Mrs. Doubtfire. These days she writes plays, fiction, nonfiction, and regularly performs as a storyteller. Mara and her work have been seen at Ars Nova, Theatre 80, The Tank, 3LD Art and Technology Center, The Strawberry One Act Festival, The Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, UCBeast, The People’s Improv Theater, Le Poisson Rouge, Arlene's Grocery, and Union Hall. Her writing has been featured on Cracked.com, Theatermania.com, The Nostalgia Chick, RISK!, The Story Collider, Jezebel, The Huffington Post, Yahoo! News, and on her own website, MaraWilsonWritesStuff.com.

Max Reuben is an actor, director, and playwright. As a founding member of AGGROCRAG, a Brooklyn-based theater company dedicated to the creation of original work, his work has been seen at places like Ars Nova, Theatre 80, The Brooklyn Lyceum, Underground Arts in Philadelphia, The Philadelphia Fringe Festival, and The Bleeker Street Theater. He currently teaches first year playwriting at Playwrights Horizons Theater School, an undergraduate drama studio at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts.

SHEEPLE stars Chris Cafero (Awesome 80’s Prom, SNL) Fernando Gonzalez, Cecilia Kim, Benj Mirman (The Discipline Committee on Funny or Die and Glamour Magazine), and William Vaughn. The production team includes Gary Reuben (Set Designer), Robert Wuss (Lighting Designer), Anna Lauren Farrell (Producer), Megan Ermilio (Assistant Director/Stage Manager). 

What We Need & What You Get

Donations come in all shapes and sizes, and every amount will be instrumental in helping us give this play the attention it deserves. A $25 gift will go towards the purchasing of a track jacket, a fundamental piece of clothing in the play. With a contribution of $50 you will be a team player in helping Mara's dream of bringing future productions of Sheeple to university campuses across North America come true. $100 will support one of our actors, Cecilia Kim has flown all the way from Los Angeles to New York City just to star in this play!

If we exceed our goal of $3,500, any and all funds will be donated to Publicolor, an organization with programs to engage at-risk youth in their education through a collaborative revitalization of community spaces.

http://Publicolor.org/

Other Ways To Get Involved

www.sheepletheplay.com

https://www.facebook.com/sheepletheplay?ref=hl

SHEEPLE runs 8/10 at 2:30pm, 8/11 at 7:30pm, 8/15 at 4:15pm, 8/16 at 6pm, 8/17 at 4pm at The Kraine Theatre located at 85 E 4th Street, NYC. Performance dates are as follows:

Saturday, August 10th at 2:30pm *talk back following the show
Sunday, August 11th at 7:30pm
Thursday, August 15th at 4:15pm
Friday, August 16th at 6:00pm
Saturday, August 17th at 4:00pm

News, and on her own website, MaraWilsonWritesStuff.com.

As a founding member of AGGROCRAG, a Brooklyn-based theater company dedicated to the creation of original work, his work has been seen at places like Ars Nova, Theatre 80, The Brooklyn Lyceum, Underground Arts in Philadelphia, The Philadelphia Fringe Festival, and The Bleeker Street Theater. He currently teaches first year playwriting at Playwrights Horizons Theater School, an undergraduate drama studio at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts.
SHEEPLE stars Chris Cafero (Awesome 80’s Prom, SNL) Fernando Gonzalez, Cecilia Kim, Benj Mirman (The Discipline Committee on Funny or Die and Glamour Magazine), and William Vaughn. The production team includes Gary Reuben (Set Designer), Robert Wuss (Lighting Designer), Anna Lauren Farrell (Producer), Megan Ermilio (Assistant Director/Stage Manager). 


What We Need & What You Get
Donations come in all shapes and sizes, and every amount will be instrumental in helping us give this play the attention it deserves. A $25 gift will go towards the purchasing of a track jacket, a fundamental piece of clothing in the play. With a contribution of $50 you will be a team player in helping Mara's dream of bringing future productions of Sheeple to university campuses across North America come true. $100 will support one of our actors, Cecilia Kim has flown all the way from Los Angeles to New York City just to star in this play!
If we exceed our goal of $3,500, any and all funds will be donated to Publicolor, an organization with programs to engage at-risk youth in their education through a collaborative revitalization of community spaces.
http://Publicolor.org/

Other Ways To Get Involved
www.sheepletheplay.com
https://www.facebook.com/sheepletheplay?ref=hl
SHEEPLE runs 8/10 at 2:30pm, 8/11 at 7:30pm, 8/15 at 4:15pm, 8/16 at 6pm, 8/17 at 4pm at The Kraine Theatre located at 85 E 4th Street, NYC. Performance dates are as follows:
Saturday, August 10th at 2:30pm *talk back following the showSunday, August 11th at 7:30pmThursday, August 15th at 4:15pmFriday, August 16th at 6:00pmSaturday, August 17th at 4:00pm

story:
Bare: A Pop Opera (Off-Broadway production @ York Theatre Company)

June 6th - 16th

Order tickets via Eventbrite:
http://barenyc-efbevent.eventbrite.com/

 

“BARE” OFF-BROADWAY BENEFIT PERFORMANCES FOR FOR HOMELESS LGBTQ YOUTH

 

Sponge Theatricals is in partnership with The Midtown Arts Common and the Saint Peters Church to bring the pop opera “bare” back to NYC from June 6th – 16th. “bare” is a benefit performance for Trinity Place Shelter for LGBTQ Youth. All proceeds from the production are given to Trinity Place Shelter, a non-sectarian, 10-bed transitional shelter for homeless LGBTQ youth located in Trinity Lutheran Church. The show is playing at The York Theatre Company at St. Peters on 54th st and Lexington Avenue. This limited engagement Off-Broadway run of “bare” is a beautiful example of the community giving back. The entire cast and crew have volunteered their time and talent to this project. It is dividing the production between the Sanctuary at Saint Peters Church and the York Theatre at Saint Peters.

 

Director Devon James, who also works as a professional actor and producer in the city has just come off his successful production of Hairspray in Westchester, says “bare” has captured the hearts of so many. I'm honored to bring this story back to the NYC theater community and spread the message of love and self acceptance now in a historic time of change for equality for all.” This production features new Choreography by Christopher Nofkee and original Costume Designs by Angela Borst. Their goal with this production of “bare” is to bring a fresh edgy look to the popular story that fans have come to love.

 

While this show is hoping to give financial assistance to the shelter, it's also hoping to inspire the audience to be honest and comfortable with their own identity. BARE is set in a co-ed Roman Catholic boarding school where a storied love triangle with female classmate, Ivy, complicates Peter and Jason's closeted relationship. Jason spirals has he faces rejection from his parents, peers, priest, and lover.“It took a show like 'bare"'to give me that final push to accept myself and take the leap of faith that my family and peers may or may not accept me. "bare" moved me and I want to share this show with others in the hopes that they will feel the same way about it as I do. As the show says 'God don't make no trash' “ says Dalles Wilie, who plays Jason in this story of two boys struggling to hide their love from their peers.

 

Tickets are $25 at the door, $20 online before June 1st at www.spongenyc.com. Evening tickets (June 7th, 8th, 13th, 14th, & 15th @8pm) are going fast so advanced reservations are strongly suggested. Added matinee tickets (June 6th @ 3pm& 16th @ 2pm) are now available. (The York Theatre & Saint Peter's 619 Lexington Ave. entrance on 54th street. 6, E, & M train at 51st)

 

"bare" is presented through special arrangement with and all authorized performance materials are supplied by Theatrical Rights Worldwide (TRW), 1359 Broadway, Suite 914, New York, NY. 10018. (866) 378-9758 www.theatricalrights.com

 

 

-----------------------

YOU CAN BE A PART OF SOMETHING BEAUTIFUL! PLEASE TAKE A MOMENT TO LEARN ABOUT THIS PROJECT

 

"Who are we?"

Sponge Thearicals is a group of creative spirits who have brought many productions to completion in NYC. Sponge performed a limited engagement of the musical "bare" in Albany to celebrate the legalization of Gay Marriage in New York. For more details on Sponge, visit www.spongenyc.com

 

 

"What is this "bare" thing about?"

This show has had such an emotional and creative impact on our company and cast. Doing this show even brought one of our cast members out of the closet!

“bare” is a pop opera that takes place a private Catholic School. We follow the emotional journey of group of friends as they reach the end of their Senior year. Dealing with currently relevant issues like sexual identity, teen pregnancy, drug abuse, bullying, obesity, and the daunting task of accepting yourself are a few of the show's themes. We follow Jason and Peter, two star crossed lovers who have to hide their same sex relationship from the judgmental voices of their peers and the school.

We now have the opportunity to bring this show back to NYC. This Version hasn't been done in NYC for a very long time. The version we are performing has many differences from the recent Off-Broadway version that played at New World Stages this past year. Both productions beautifully shared the same message and we are thrilled to continue spreading it.

It doesn't matter which Version is the Best, 'cause "God Don't Make No Trash"!

"Why are you doing it"

Sponge theatricals is doing this production as a fundraiser to help support the Trinity Place Shelter in NYC. Trinity Place Shelter is a non-sectarian, 10-bed transitional shelter that is open all year to provide LGBTQ youth/young adults with a safe place to sleep, eat, store belongings, have access to transportation, individual/group counseling, and additional independent living supportive services.

There are as many as 8,000 LGBTQ youth/young adults currently living homeless in NYC and only 250 beds or fewer that are specifically available for this population. These youth often experience abuse and trauma in other shelters and on the streets.

Sponge Theatricals is donating ALL proceeds from this show to Trinity Place Shelter. 

The more donations we get, the more shows we can perform and bring in more donations for Trinity. 

"What do you Need and what do I get?"

While NYC is the ideal place to bring a full production of "bare" it isn't the cheapest. 

We have many things that need financial attention. All of which either need a lot of money to pay for them or the involvement of the community to work together.

Venues cost thousands of dollars. Costumes are being made from scratch. Sets, mics, lights, sound, musicians, and promotional materials are all things that we need to fund.

                                              

We need your help to do this. WITHOUT YOU . . . This becomes a one weekend run instead of a two week limited engagement. This show will have to use pre recorded tracks instead of live instruments. The cast will have to get costumes from Conway rather than custom designed and built items by Angela Borst! We will have to cut down on elaborate staging and choreography because the rehearsal space will be too expensive.

PLEASE help us tell this story.

*CAST CONFESSION*
There are musicals that get your feet tapping or make your eyes sparkle from the pyrotechnics. "bare" is a show that grabs your heart. Just like it grabbed mine.

Hello, my name is Dalles. I play Jason in this production of "bare". I first did this show back in 2011.At that time I was battling my own emotions and insecurities. I spent most of my life hiding the fact that I was gay. It took a show like "bare" to give me that final push to accept myself and take the leap of faith that my family and peers may or may not accept me. "bare" moved me and I want to share this show with others in the hopes that they will feel the same way about it as I do. "Someone gets me" is what I thought when I first discovered this show. The show isn't about being gay, it's about being true to who you are.

"Being someone else for someonelses sake. That would be the greatest mistake" is how the show puts it and has been the driving words that have let me finally see who I am, now that I am being honest about it. I am passionate about bringing this show back to NYC! I want to let this show give others the courage it gave me. I am finally living life without a mask, no walls, and full honesty. I am living "bare".

- Dalles

"Are There Other Ways I Can Help?"

We want you as involved as possible. "bare" is about community and coming together in times of need. We have some perks here to thank you for your donations. But we also encourage you you to contact us with ideas, advice, or the name of someone you know that can help us reach our goals. 

please email us at spongetheatricals@gmail.com or contact us at our website www.spongenyc.com.

Thank you so much for your time and belief in the importance of our project.

Show Facts

"bare"
Book by Jon Hartmere & Damon Intrabartolo
Music by Damon Intrabartolo
Lyrics by Jon Hartmere

 

"Forever You and I" Dalles Wilie & Matt Corr. Photographed by Taylor Hooper

bare is presented through special arrangement with and all authorized performance materials are supplied by Theatrical Rights Worldwide (TRW), 570 Seventh Avenue, Suite 2100, New York, NY 10018 (866) 378-9758 www.theatricalrights.com

story:
THREE MEN, A LADY and A BABY... MAYBE.

"Tom, Dick & Harry" is the story of Sally Ryan, a 35 year old, divorced writer of children’s books and the three men in her life: 

  • TOM, a graduate student thirteen years her junior with whom she’s trying to get her dating mojo back;

  • DICK, her ex-husband

  • and HARRY, Dick’s lover

Dick and Harry have come over to Sally’s apartment to inform her that they would like to have a baby together… and they’d like Sally to be the surrogate mother. The production features a seasoned cast that will take the audience on a rollercoaster ride on this controversial subject of same sex marriage and family values which asks the question, “Does love end just because a marriage does?”

But nothing quite goes as planned in this comedy about the lengths people will go to keep love alive.

Sally - Risa Cohen
Tom - Anthony Rella
Dick - Adrian Gorrissen
Harry - Scott Garland

WHAT WE NEED and WHAT YOU GET

With your generous support, we are able to get costumes, set pieces, props, a rehearsal space, sound effects, gas money.. essentially, with ANY amount, you are helping us to produce the show (Have you ever been called a 'producer' before ?  Now's your chance!).

Plus all donations come with tax receipts!  (if you are a business or corporation wishing to sponsor us, please note that higher amounts come with better perks!  Please contact us at castinc@cogeco.ca for details).

BE SURE TO CHECK OUT ALL OUR PERKS!

Or come out to Hamiton to see the show at the beautiful CITADEL THEATRE over on Rebecca St. (Show Times: Sat, July 20 6:30pm; Sun, July 21 2:00pm; Mon, July 22 9:30pm; Wed, July 24 6:00pm; Fri, July 26 6:00pm; Sat, July 27 9:30pm; Sun, July 28 12:30pm). Tickets are $10!!

For more information about CAST INC, please visit www.castinc.ca. And for more information about the 10th annual Hamilton Fringe Festival, please visit http://hamiltonfringe.ca/

story:
"No one who speaks German could be an evil man!"

Aaron Gocs has been a friend of mine for nearly two years now, and I've never known the man to have a bad word to say about anyone -- except himself. He's a man of simple pleasures. Whether he's spending time with his two kids, running a five minute comedy set at his local, or cruising around in his taxi, the man's an absolute champion. I've set up this campaign to help Gocsy achieve his dream of a full-chest Simpsons-themed tattoo, namely Sideshow Bob's legendary "Die Bart, Die" (translation: The Bart, The).

Gocsy has been performing comedy for several years now, and is beloved across the town for his gutsy, down-to-earth style. He's the classic Australian everyman, a true bloke, without the racism or fighting. With a wristwatch tattoo, he's partway there, but he needs your help, because tattoos are expensive!

The main budget will be used to give Gocsy his first dream tattoo, as well as a secondary favourite -- "Starland Vocal Band" on his bicep.

All funds leftover from the tattoos, and all over the requested amount will be donated to SIDS and Kids, a charity dedicated to helping end sudden infant deaths, and assisting bereaved families.

Please help Gocsy achieve his dream! He's seriously a fantastic dude.

I picked up a guy last night who had a massive Ned Kelly tat, The Simpsons means more to me than Ned Kelly
-Gocsy

story:
Hello!

My name is Molly Spain, and I'm 16 years old. I've been doing theatre for over a decade of my life, and I love it more than anything. It has been my dream to attend school in London for years. This summer, I was accepted into two courses at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Arts. The thing is, London is the most expensive city in the world. Because of the cost, I might not be able to stay the entire time. Donating money would help me with the chance of a lifetime! 

What I Need & What You Get

All the money you donate will be split between renting an apartment, plane tickets and the actual course fees. (Each course is 1400 American Dollars.) We will be renting a short term apartment- your money would help pay the rent for that as well. Some perks include: British Tea, candy, a hand-written postcard, a t-shirt or sweatshirt, a care package, etc. 

Of course, any amount you can donate will help! 

The Impact

I've wanted to attend school in London since I was 9 years old. LAMDA is one of my top two colleges. (Fun fact! Benedict Cumberbatch also attended LAMDA.) Attending these courses would give me the foot in the door that I would need to attend this school in my future.  

I've been dedicated to the Theatre since I was six years old. I currently work at Boulder's Dinner Theater, and attend Actor's Academy of the Preforming Arts. I spend at least 10 hours a week taking acting classes, dance classes, voice lessons, as well as teaching, choreographing and helping with various odd jobs. (An above picture is from my last show, Shrek the Musical. It is of me helping prep before a show.) Attending these LAMDA course would give me the base I need to finally begin professionally acting, as well as set me up for my future education. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate money, share this around! Tell any one and everyone! Share this on social media! Help me reach my dreams! And as always, thank you so much for your support!

story:
"Elektra" presented by Stokastik Theater Ensemble

An original take on an age old story. Re-written in a more approachable style, our production of "Elektra" will be something unlike anything you've seen before at the theater. Great characters, even better actors, and a design team hard at work making sure this is the best show presented by Stokastik Theater Ensemble yet. There will be music, there will be laughter, and there will be blood. 


929 E. 2nd Street #105
Los Angeles, CA 90012
(Corner of 2nd & Vignes)


Show Nights

Saturday, November 12th; Sunday, November 13th; 
Thursday, November 17th; Saturday, November 19th; Sunday, November 20th; 
Saturday. November 26th; Sunday, November 27th; 
Saturday, December 3rd; Sunday, December 4th; 
Thursday, December 8th; Saturday, December 10th; and close on Sunday, December 11th.

Thursdays at 8pm

Saturdays at 8pm

Sundays at 7pm


The Impact

By donating to our production of "Elektra," your money goes straight into the production itself. Costumes, sets, lights and sound all cost money - and while we are trying to be economy savvy and artistic in our choices, there are just some things that need to be bought. Marketing is also a huge part of getting people out to the theater in L.A. and every bit of change you can throw at us will help.

What We Need...and What YOU get!

Really, $500 isn't a lot of money at the end of the day, but as a bunch of friends in our 20's and 30's - we can really use every little bit! Theater isn't cheap, and we want to give you the best show possible. A good portion of the show will be paid out of pocket by the design team and Stokastik Theater Ensemble itself. We don't ask for much, but you aren't just throwing your money away either - we want to pay you back for your generosity and friendship. Sooooo...


Donate $30 and we will get you two tickets to any night of "Elektra" you would like (That's $10 off the list price for two tickets!) We want you to come, we want you to enjoy yourself - and we want to give you a break for helping us out.


Donate $75 and you will get a signed copy of our specially designed graphic novel program, two vinyl stickers with the special Elektra Promo images, and two tickets to our show!


Donate $125 and you will get everything mentioned above! In addition - you will get a bottle of champagne for you and a guest to share while you walk the stage before the show guided by the Director and Managing Director, talk with cast members, and enjoy the rest of the show from your front row seats!


Donate $200 and you will get everything mentioned above! Aaaaaand...for our actor friends: An actor Reel/Headshot package with two 30 seconds scenes written, directed, edited and casted by 'Semaphore Photo' and a headshot photo shoot with one look and retouching. Pretty cool deal!

For our non-actor friends: Everything mentioned in the $125 range, and in addition the Director of Elektra and cast will get drinks and food with you after the show, send you a production video of the play, and bring you up on stage during our curtain call for "Elektra" to thank you for being so freaking awesome.


And P.S - if you are my mother or father you will get all of this anyways. :)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate - don't worry! You can help in other ways! Post this video on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, and tell your friends about what we're working on! We'll love you all the same.
story_txt:
"Elektra" presented by Stokastik Theater Ensemble
An original take on an age old story. Re-written in a more approachable style, our production of "Elektra" will be something unlike anything you've seen before at the theater. Great characters, even better actors, and a design team hard at work making sure this is the best show presented by Stokastik Theater Ensemble yet. There will be music, there will be laughter, and there will be blood. 

929 E. 2nd Street #105Los Angeles, CA 90012(Corner of 2nd & Vignes)

Show Nights
Saturday, November 12th; Sunday, November 13th; 
Thursday, November 17th; Saturday, November 19th; Sunday, November 20th; 
Saturday. November 26th; Sunday, November 27th; 
Saturday, December 3rd; Sunday, December 4th; 
Thursday, December 8th; Saturday, December 10th; and close on Sunday, December 11th.

Thursdays at 8pm
Saturdays at 8pm
Sundays at 7pm


The Impact
By donating to our production of "Elektra," your money goes straight into the production itself. Costumes, sets, lights and sound all cost money - and while we are trying to be economy savvy and artistic in our choices, there are just some things that need to be bought. Marketing is also a huge part of getting people out to the theater in L.A. and every bit of change you can throw at us will help.

What We Need...and What YOU get!
Really, $500 isn't a lot of money at the end of the day, but as a bunch of friends in our 20's and 30's - we can really use every little bit! Theater isn't cheap, and we want to give you the best show possible. A good portion of the show will be paid out of pocket by the design team and Stokastik Theater Ensemble itself. We don't ask for much, but you aren't just throwing your money away either - we want to pay you back for your generosity and friendship. Sooooo...

Donate $30 and we will get you two tickets to any night of "Elektra" you would like (That's $10 off the list price for two tickets!) We want you to come, we want you to enjoy yourself - and we want to give you a break for helping us out.

Donate $75 and you will get a signed copy of our specially designed graphic novel program, two vinyl stickers with the special Elektra Promo images, and two tickets to our show!

Donate $125 and you will get everything mentioned above! In addition - you will get a bottle of champagne for you and a guest to share while you walk the stage before the show guided by the Director and Managing Director, talk with cast members, and enjoy the rest of the show from your front row seats!

Donate $200 and you will get everything mentioned above! Aaaaaand...for our actor friends: An actor Reel/Headshot package with two 30 seconds scenes written, directed, edited and casted by 'Semaphore Photo' and a headshot photo shoot with one look and retouching. Pretty cool deal!
For our non-actor friends: Everything mentioned in the $125 range, and in addition the Director of Elektra and cast will get drinks and food with you after the show, send you a production video of the play, and bring you up on stage during our curtain call for "Elektra" to thank you for being so freaking awesome.

And P.S - if you are my mother or father you will get all of this anyways. :)

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate - don't worry! You can help in other ways! Post this video on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, and tell your friends about what we're working on! We'll love you all the same.

story:
We've made it to $8.5K!! This is our minimum goal. See below for why we would love to get to $11K!

NY-based Parijat Desai Dance Company performs a blend of Indian classical and Western contemporary dance. We’re raising funds for our first-ever tour of India! During September 2011, we’ll be performing in New Delhi, Mumbai, Kolkata, Hyderabad, Bangalore, and Chennai. We're being presented by The Park's New Festival, produced by Prakriti Foundation and Park Hotels. This is an international festival presenting contemporary artists in different disciplines, from India and abroad. We’re taking 5 Dancers AND our Lighting Designer/Stage Manager to present Make Space and Songs To Live For, both created my residencies ('09-10 and '10-11) at Tribeca Performing Arts Center.


Why Go?
PDDC is a rare voice in dance — uniquely grounded in both Indian classical and American modern dance. Because of the growing interest in contemporary dance in India, it's an exciting time to go. Dance is a means to build connections and understanding between people, and The New Festival includes performances, lecture/demos, and workshops — so we’ll get to share our work, and dialogue with audiences/artists across India. Also, India's a happening place. We're excited for collaborations that come through this tour. And we’re confident this tour will help us raise our profile at home in the U.S.


What We Get, Need, and Can Give You

The New Festival is generously covering all domestic travel, hotel, and food, and providing performance fees (in Rs). Between festival fees and funds PDDC has already raised, we are close to affording our international tickets. So we are definitely going!

But! There are significant costs yet to handle: We need to raise a minimum of $8.5K toward remaining airfare; visa costs; studio rental, tour lighting design, audio recordings, and visual elements; promotion; and—most importantly—dancer pay.


Our talented, dedicated, and, well, kick-ass dancers are rehearsing fiercely. These artists work jobs that allow them to rehearse for several daytime hours (read: “they ain’t rich”), and they’ll be leaving those jobs for 1 month+ in order to tour. Since the economy does not remunerate most dance labor, as a community, we must find a way to reward dancers' contributions to our collective well-being...

To thank you for your help, we've come up with some fun, beautiful gifts including photographs of PDDC, DVDs, invite-only rehearsals, tote bags, and even original paintings.


$8.5K is our minimum. The festival will give $5K, and we've already raised $4K. With $11K from this campaign, we can come closer to our total budget of $24K:

BREAKDOWN

Airfare for 6: $7,680

Rehearsal/Performance Fees: $7,500

Lighting Designer/Stage Manager Fees: $1,500

Visual Projection/DVD Prep: $500

Studio Rental: $900

Video Recording: $400

Costume Prep: $300

Visas: $800

Travel Insurance: $1,500
Vaccinations: $1,500
Admin/Promo/Audio&Video Editing/Fees: $1,600

TOTAL BUDGET: ~24K

NOTE: INDIEGOGO TAKES 6% OF OUR FUNDS RAISED. IF YOU'D LIKE TO GIVE AND DON'T NEED A TAX DEDUCTION, INQUIRE AT info@parijatdesai.org.


Other Ways You Can Help

Like this page on FB! (Use the share tools above) Or, e-mail the campaign link to your friends!

Itinerary: parijatdesai.org/calendar.php

story:
The Wrecking Project: An experiment in making dances and re-imagining them.


18 dances. 

9 choreographers from 5 different cities. 

16 performers.

3 separate programs over 1 weekend.


The Wrecking Project brings together nine choreographers (three trios) to work with wrecking as a creative methodology and present original works next to their wrecked versions illuminating the fluid nature of authorship and the provisional nature of meaning making.

 Julie Mayo and Kate Corby have invited a group of rigorous dance-makers with distinctive sensibilities to wreck, or re-imagine, one another's finished work, inspired by choreographer Susan Rethorst's work with wrecking dances in the mid 1990's.  The "wrecking process" parameters stipulate that the original work's performer(s) must remain the same, but everything else is fair game.

The Wrecking Project is a part of a Links Hall Artistic Associates festival.

April 12 - the New York Trio

Laurel Atwell

Tess Dworman

Caitlin Marz

April 13 - the Chicago Trio

Paige Caldarella

Kate Corby

Hope Goldman

April 14 - the Tri-Coastal Trio

Christy Funsch

Colleen Leonardi

Julie Mayo 

The Wrecking Project will feature performances by: Samantha Allen, Laurel Atwell, Kirstan Clifford, Isabelle Collazo, Tess Dworman, Christy Funsch, Colleen Leonardi, Caitlin Marz, Cara Newman, Sydney Noble, Dalton Rhodes, Michelle Scurlock, Luis Segoviano, Cristina Tadeo, Destine Treadwell and Jessie Young.

 

The Need

Travel expenses will make up the majority of our project budget, in addition to documentation and rehearsal space rental. Our focus for this campaign is to cover the airfare costs incurred for the performance of the Wrecking Project and to partially cover our documentation and rehearsal space rental. Our total project budget is approximately $9700.


The Details

Airfare: $1200

Documentation costs covered by this campaign: $400 (of $1050 total)

Rehearsal space rental for wrecking rehearsals: $400 of ($1000 total)


Total: $2000

story:
PAE provides financially-accesssible classical theatre

Our free Shakespeare-in-the-Parks has become a Portland summer tradition, reaching over 33,000 audience members during our last six seasons!  Shakespeare-in-the-Parks is now as much a part of Portland summer as roses and sunshine! PAE enhances our community’s quality of life, offering live performances free of charge to all.

PAE past and present

PAE has produced at least one Shakespearean play every summer for over forty years, making us one of the oldest continuously operating theatre companies in the city.  We believe that the power and beauty of William Shakespeare's work should be accessible to everyone, so we bring theater directly to Portland neighborhoods with two Shakespeare-in-the-Parks plays each year.  Each production features at least one sign-interpreted performance.  For many of our audience members, particularly families with children, our free productions may be their first or only theatre experience.

Your annual contribution will help us to engage and retain the best local artists to provide consistently memorable productions.

Perhaps you, your family, and friends have built a decades-long tradition of Shakespeare-in-the-Parks.  Maybe you have yet seen only one (or none) of our performances.  No matter how many performances you have enjoyed, now is your opportunity to become a 2012 member of Friends of PAE and enjoy the benefits of annual membership.

Join Now!

Gifts are tax-deductible (except for the fair value of the swag).

Larger Gifts

If you are able to make a gift greater than $1,000, please contact us at portlandactors@gmail.com to discuss benefits and arrangements!  We welcome the opportunity for larger partnerships, and would be happy to discuss one with you!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute funds, there are many other ways to help promote the mission of Portland Actors Ensemble:

  • Share this campaign via Facebook or Twitter, or using the share tools found on this site.
  • Volunteer to help at performances.  Email paevolunteers@gmail.com to volunteer.
  • Arrange for your workplace to sponsor PAE.
  • Spread the word about this campaign using email, Facebook, and Twitter.
  • Help us advertise our performances in your community.  Become a Facebook friend of PortlandActorsEnsemble for news and updates.
  • Become an advocate for the arts in your community.
  • Make sure that there is an audience tomorrow. Bring children and grandchildren to the performances.
Good Will for all!
Michael Godsey
Artistic Director, Portland Actors Ensemble
 
*Video clip provided by Heather Welch!  For more of her videos of PAE, see www.youtube.com/user/HMWelch76/videos

story:
Our Story

Hello, we are the Very Personal Trainers. We are a new band from Millburn, New Jersey consisting of four very passionate, very personal teenagers: Eric Shepard (guitar, vocals), Michael Matchen (lead guitar), Charlie Marshall (Bass), and Rob Goldman (Drums). Our passion and drive comes from our love for music, our love for our band, our love for each other, and most importantly, our love for our fans. We are participating in the Break Contest to play at Bamboozle, and if you help us get there, we can promise you an amazing show (both at the preliminaries and Bamboozle), as well as love from us, and maybe some other goodies that are TBD ATM. Thank you! Check us out on myspace at www.myspace.com/theverypersonaltrainers


The Impact

We live in a world where auto-tuned pop music rules the radio and angry death metal dominates the underground. Why can't there be a band out there that rocks out honestly and intimately, sharing our emotions and words with their fans in a comfortable and entertaining way? There is such a band, and they are called The Very Personal Trainers. If you support us, we will be able to spread our beautiful message of rock to the entire world, so that everyone can enjoy our art. If you do not support us, the world will explode.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to proceed in the Break Contest, we need to sell at least 40 tickets, each for $12. In total we need to make $480. We also need lots of people to come and cheer their butts off for us and vote for us. If you donate any money at all, you will get our upcoming demo. If you donate $10 or more, you will receive a signed copy of the demo. If you donate $12 you will, of course, receive a ticket to watch us perform at the Break Contest February 13th! If you donate more than $12 dollars, you will receive a DVD of our music video for our cover of Kids by MGMT. If you donate $20, you will get two tickets, saving $4!!!!!


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell ALL YOUR FRIENDS AND FAMILY to help us out and donate money! Also, bring loads of people to our show, that way you get to have lots of fun watching us with your friends and we'll get to have lots of fun entertaining lots of people!!!

story:
The Situation:

Since 2001 some 2000 soldiers have been killed in Afghanistan
 
More than 5000 young people have been killed on Chicago's South Side over the  same period of time.

In 2012 there were 532 murders. Over 60 of them were children.

Children have been killed. Sons, daughters and loved ones have been taken down by gun violence year after year with no end in sight. If this isn’t a domestic war zone, we don’t know what one is...and it's time to do something about it.

 
SUMMER IN CHICAGO sets out to go directly into the area affected the most by violence and hopelessness and do whatever it takes to start change that sticks.
 
By donating to SUMMER IN CHICAGO, you're helping us take one step further toward the solution.

What We Need & What You Get

We're expecting an amazing turn out of both volunteers and locals. Money donated to the SUMMER IN CHICAGO Event will go toward volunteer tools, on site water and food, security, location expenses, tent rentals and more.

All donations will go toward ensuring our SUMMER IN CHICAGO event runs as smoothly as possible.

What Is SUMMER IN CHICAGO?

The first day of summer is Friday June 21st. On that day we will enter the high schools with a bevy of motivaltional speakers and surprise celebrity gustes who will motivate the children to take part in the weekend's event.

That Saturday, we will flood the streets of Chicago's south side with one mission: To Collect Dreams.
 
Our mission is to go directly to the people and speak to them one on one. We want to know their stories and learn more about who they are on a personal level.  Every SUMMER IN CHICAGO volunteer will document the people they speak with, establishing their needs, goals but most importantly…their dreams.
 
Anything from getting a good job, going to college or starting a small business --
we will take that person’s information with the intention of seeing that dream through to fruition.

What happens after we collect the dreams?

We find people willing to SUPPORT those dreams with their time, resources or
finances, giving chance and opportunity to voices often left unheard.

We’re not an organization hoping to profit money. Instead, we’re here to collect opportunities for young men and women giving them hope for their future and renewed motivation to move toward their goals and dreams.

With SUMMER IN CHICAGO we want people to know that if they take all the necessary steps, their dreams are waiting for them on the other side. We believe in our youth and the families that look after them. Here is an opportunity to show you believe in them too.

If you can't donate financially we hope you can donate your time and join us on Friday June 21st and Saturday June 22nd as we journey into what will undoubtedly be a life changing event for all involved.

More details on the weekends events will trickle down the closer we arrive to June 21st. Keep checking in! Learn more about our event by visiting our website at: www.blacklifematters.org/SUMMERINCHICAGO

Please help us get the word out about our indiegogo campaign!! Share us on your Facebook page, tweet us or just tell somebody about what we're doing and how they can help!

 

 

Crystal Holmes

-Founder of Black Life Matters & Chairman of the Summer In Chicago Event

story:
The Elk In The Attic – A Musical

by Christopher Hoy from his original children’s story of the same name.
Music & Lyrics by Don Charles and Deb Gessner with additional lyrics by Judy Clothier

                                            The Story:
A large number of drought-weary forest animals temporarily take up residence in Prescott, and 9 year-old Tim Armstrong discovers a huge bull elk named Bill living in the attic above his bedroom. He is not the only one at school with new animal friends.  The kids don’t have a problem with animals in town - but the grown-ups are not happy with the animal invasion and the situation erupts at a Town Council meeting. In the ensuing aftermath, Eagle returns from a trip to the top of the world with important news about the future of all living things.

Who/Where?

The Elks Opera House Foundation, a 501(c)3, brings the 2nd Annual production of The Elk in the Attic, to the historic 108-year old Elks Opera House Theatre Stage, in Prescott Arizona! July 25-28, 2013

Honoring and Supporting The Artists Who Make this Happen

We know we have to market a show and generally most grants and businesses find that easy to support. We are doing that AND the budget for this year’s production of The Elk in the Attic includes Artistic Personnel.

We will offer some financial support and recognition to all associated directly with the show - more than 25 - including director, musicians, choreographer, light and sound designers and operators, stage manager, actors and dancers. This covers rehearsal, skill-building workshops for the young cast, and performances.

We believe in stepping up to the value of the arts by putting some dollars toward supporting those who provide live theatre in our community. The performing arts are a joy and gift as well as an essential thread in our cultural experience.

Your contribution will help us to cover the cost of travel to and from rehearsal and performance; recognize the expertise of professionals involved with this production (designers, director, musicians), and actively demonstrate to our young actors that the performing arts is a respected, valuable component of our society.

We want to bring this original family musical to the 108-year old Elks Opera House stage AND show respect and support for keeping the arts alive in our communities, leading by example in our work and our budgets.

YOUR financial contribution will support both the production of The Elk in the Attic
AND demonstrate to all the very real value of the performing arts and those who work so hard to give it to us.

Putting Our Money Where Our Passion Is

We have a cash budget of $24,000, plus $16,000 of in-kind including the superb costumes and masks from last year’s production.

Today we are asking for $8,250 to compensate the Director (2,500), Musicians (2,000) Light/Sound Designers & Operators (1,750), Choreographer ($500), Stage Manager ($1,000) and a total small stipend for each actor (500)
This is half of the ideal Artistic budget of $16,500.

Additional funds are being sought through grants, sponsors and program ad sales. These will support marketing and PR costs first and then the rest of artistic personnel costs.

The show will go on regardless of these funds being fully raised or not but it will be without the capacity to offer the financial recognition due to those who bring their expertise to make The Elk in the Attic the high quality production it will be.

All contributions are tax deductible to the full extent allowed by the law and include the small site percentage to Indiegogo and for transfer fees.

Putting YOU in the Program!

When you support The Elk in The Attic you will be recognized in the printed program, on the website and for really Big amounts ($1,000 +) as a Drought Breaker Show Sponsor and dinner with the playwright and director!

We have signed programs, posters, and the book on which this was all based signed by the author. And, of course, tickets to the show!  We will even have a few audio CDs of the show if you can’t make it in person and want to be a ‘Bill’.

Choose from various categories and join us as a Forest Animals, (Squirrel, Skink, Raccoon wily coyote), one of the Birds (Raven, Owl and Eagle) or as Bill the Elk!

The Impact - The Arts & Environmental Awareness

The Elks Opera House Foundation (EOHF) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit AZ corporation, dedicated to promoting the standing of the historic Elks Opera House and to actively supporting and participating in the performing arts, cultural and economic values of the Central Arizona Highlands.

The EOHF has been primarily responsible for the restoration and historical recognition of the Elks Opera House (EOH) for more than 10 years.  Advocating for the building, the Foundation has been present at all of the developments in its history over the last decade. and has segued into producing events in the EOH. In 2012, the AZ Centennial year, the EOHF mounted two world premieres by local playwrights, and this one is Back!

                                          A Double-Whammy!
• Artistic Opportunity and Support to a local playwright, musicians, mask makers, costumers and actors - including adults and young people. The experienced older actors will be mentors and models as well as team players with enthusiastic young actors through workshops, rehearsal and performance.

• Consider how we will live with the competing demands on the natural resources and encroaching urban development on the natural habitat. Balancing environmental concerns and needs is at the heart of this original musical suitable for entire families, providing entertainment as well as thought-provoking material.

Extra: We are also dedicated to keeping ticket prices low enough to enable families to attend together, seated together in the beautifully restored 108year old theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know you can’t all make a financial contribution and that is fine - we know how that goes!  BUT we still need you!  Get the word out, tell your friends, pass this site on, find us on Facebook and Like us, and maybe later get a ticket for your little brother, Aunt or Grandmother or that raccoon living in your garage.

Take advantage of the handy easy-to-use share tools!

(And when you see a thirsty, confused, anxious little critter or bird somewhere unusual he/she may have wandered out of the play and into your yard! Don’t panic, just pray for rain. Of course, a large Bull Elk may be more startling but is probably just as nervous as you are!  Our Bill - the Elk in the Attic - finds the Tim - the Boy in the Bedroom - to be unsettling as well! But they become firm friends in the end.)

              SPECIAL THANKS

• to the cast of last year's premier production
     whose faces and voices apear in the clips and photos.
• to Playaweddings for the still images and 2012 video footage.
• to Big Picture Video for the utube clip.
