story:
Ladies and Gentlemen, please welcome MARLENE!

'MARLENE - The Competition' is a solo show by Eva Magyar, an award-winning actress, dancer, choreographer, and director. Oh, did we just say it 'is'? Well, it will be, if you help us to give it a final push. 

After running her own theatre company for a decade, Eva took a bold move and left her career and life in Hungary behind. Restarting her life in London at the age of 49, she began working with the best companies like The National Theatre or The Royal Shakespeare Company, so you may ask, what's the problem to solve here?

Over the last years Eva has been dreaming about creating her own show but being an independent artist in London is not easy. And it's especially difficult if you are an immigrant.

And that was when we met. Three Hungarians in London, three strong-headed independent women working their way through loneliness, despair and the shame of having to restart from zero. Together we became a team and decided to laugh fate in its face. 


Let's write a happy ending to MARLENE's story together

Have you ever felt being a stranger? Being put in a box you struggle to escape? Did you ever had the feeling that the big city just swallows you as if your existence didn’t even matter? Then MARLENE is about you.

Using the lightness of cabaret, it talks about the fight for survival from the viewpoint of a 50-something female artist trying to rebuild her life in London. Marlene’s journey is happening here and now, in front of our very eyes, and how it ends is still unknown. But together with you, we can write a happy ending. 

What we have done so far

We are not starting from scratch. In fact, we've already put a lot of work, thought, and well, hard-earned money into pushing MARLENE's lovely behind on stage. (To give a bit of a behind-the-scenes reality, Flora works as a Personal Assistant, and Sara sells linseed products in a London market over the weekends. Now that is hard-earned money.)

We've also received support from professional organizations and not just a little, but tremendous help from our friends. Amongst others:

  • We have won a grant of £3000 from Arts Council for research&development.
  • Soho Theatre and Tristan Bates Theatre supported us by providing space for two showcases. (And yes, both went amazingly well!)
  • We would be nowhere without the lovely people of Shoreditch Town Hall who offered us free rehearsal space.
  • Katona Jozsef Theatre in Budapest helped us with space, technical support, and some very friendly priced costumes, props, and sets.
  • The wonderful Andras Monori composed the most beautiful music for the show but we still haven't had the money to pay him which makes us feel terribly guilty.


So why do we still need your help?

Because we can't go any further without you. We've put everything into this project we have, our time, dedication, money - but we just don't have more. We have drained ourselves and our friends' good will beyond what can be expected. But we know it will all pay off once MARLENE is on stage.

We need to raise £10,000 to finish MARLENE. For this we will be able to:
  • finally have designed set instead of having to work with whatever we found on the street
  • buy proper costumes and props to replace the ones we've been borrowing from our own wardrobes (and which never really fit anyway)
  • buy two-weeks of rehearsal space to finish the show
  • pay for transporting and storing set, costumes and props
  • after months of bad consciousness call Andras, our beloved composer, to write those three more songs MARLENE still needs
  • film and edit the final show without which we don't even have the chance to find a venue
  • build enough noise around MARLENE via PR, media work and social media to make sure that once it's on stage, everyone who needs will know about it.

 

CONVINCED? Then please check out our perks. We've put a lot of effort into making them as attractive as possible. 


SHORT OF MONEY? It's fine, we've all been there. You can still help.

We know how it is when you’d love to give but just can afford it. Living on the edge as independent artists, it is something we really know. So please don’t feel bad if you can’t support us financially, there are plenty of other ways you can help!

  • Thanks to Indiegogo, sharing our campaign with people has never been easier. Just click on the links below.
  • Look at our Facebook page and LIKE IT if you like it.
  • Email us, call us, find us in London to let us know what you think about our campaign, how you think we should do better, or just to give us a friendly pat on the back - we so need it!


Hereby we would like to thank all the great artists who have been working with us in creating MARLENE:


Ildikó Tihanyi, designer

József Pető, lighting designer

Judit Tölli, props

Annamária Radnai, dramaturg

Aliz Győri, assistant

Film: Gábor Perjéssy, David Baksh, Justin Leighton
Photo: Csaba Mészáros, Dániel Dömölky, Niki Brozsek

story:
Short Summary

'Dar Winners' by BodyScape

BodyScape is a collective of four artists together: Virág Arany, Júlia Hadi, Stephane Kozik, Damien Pairon.

https://www.facebook.com/pages/BodyScape/1642022302704300?fref=ts

Virág and Júlia are dancers and choreographers from Hungary, Stephane is a sound artist, Damien a video artist, both coming from Belgium.

We met at a residency in 2012, Hungary. Soon after we decided to work together, since we all shared interests in creating live multimedia performances, searching for new perspectives in multidisciplinary art.

You can have an insight to our previous works on the links below:

http://stephanekozik.be/
http://damienpairon.com/

http://bodylotioncodance.com/

Dar Winners is the title of the performance we are working on at the moment. We started researching in 2013 but due to distance and lack of finances we had to make a pause in 2014. This year, we got the chance to continue our collaboration, three residencies and a premier date at Trafó House of Contemporary Arts in Budapest. This is a wonderful opportunity for us to present our project to the public, but we still need some support to cover our expenses.

By contributing to our campaign you make it possible to finalise a two-year long creation process and support an independent, young, democratic collective, in which artists and art-forms share an equal role in creation, organization, management and finances. We strongly believe in this way of working and would like to share the outcome with as many people as possible!

Special thanks to: 

Zsolt Végh and Etrange Prod for makinfg our campaign video!

What We Need

  • FEED THE ARTISTS 

    We still miss meals for 10 days for our four team members. You can contribute by 25 EUR covering the catering of one artist/day.

  • BRING US TOGETHER 

    Damien and Stephane are coming to Budapest by car, so that they can bring all the technical equipment needed for our show. We miss 700 EUR for the petrol plus highway tolls for their 2880 km long journey. Each 10 euros cover 33 km!

  • DRESS THE ARTISTS

    Since we are all four on stage, we need 100 euros each to have suitable costumes.
  • MORE MAGIC

    We still need to buy some special sensors and led lights to create a unique atmosphere. In total they cost 500 euros.
  • CAPTURE THE MOMENTS

    In order to ensure a sustainable future for the performance we need to make professional documentation about it and edit a teaser, an artistic trailer and a full-length version of the piece. The fees of 3 cameramen for four days plus the editing of three videos cost 1400 euros altogether.
  • REWARD OUR VOLUNTEERS

    We are so lucky that we have a lot of people helping us in the creation process: two people working on the management, two people writing texts and mentoring the project. We would really like to give something in return, 250 euros/person would be great to appreciate their efforts.

What You Get

Support us by:

10 EUR - we thank you for supporting us by adding your name to the list of sponsors in our full-length production video and communication surfaces

25 EUR - we share with you the secret of one of our special instruments by sending you a 'DoItYourself' manual

50 EUR - we send you the making-of about the residencies and the preparation before the show, sharing with you exclusive moments of the creation process

100 EUR - become a VIP guest of our premier in Budapest or if you cannot make it we send you a movie version of the live performance


Other Ways You Can Help

  • please share the link of our campaign, make some noise about it / you can share through Indiegogo/Facebook/Twitter or any social platform you use we will appreciate it. thanks for your help.

story:
Hello, I'm Kat and I'm a belly dancer and horror-nut. Ever since I was young, I would force my friends to watch cheesy 50s horror films and would cover my walls and notebooks with Evil Dead, Vincent Price, and Creature from the Black Lagoon. Normal teenage girl stuff. Later in life, I discovered belly dance and soon started putting on shows. Beginning with Fables, a fairy tale themed show, we rented our own space and asked local performers to participate. It was a success. We decided to continue with different themes each time. Next came 8 Bit: A Video Game themed show, and Antonio's Animal Rescue Benefit Show. In 2015, our themed show series took a turn when we decided to take on Horror Films. The first show was a huge success, selling out even our extra seats. The next year grew twice in size and was clear that our audience still wanted more. 

We are asking for your help. The show has grown and needs to expand to a larger venue. We have chosen to work with the Tacoma Broadway Center and negotiations have already begun. The space itself holds over 700, has a huge stage, trained staff, and professional lighting. We are thrilled to hopefully call this venue our new permanent home. 

With your patronage, our show can get a head start with rental deposit, costuming, rehearsal, and props. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are asking for $1500 to cover partial rental costs. Any extra funding will go to costuming, dancer pay, props, and marketing.

  • Our perks will include: Early access ticketing, VIP Tickets, Private Belly Dance lessons, Official Horrific Merchandise, special behind-the-scenes access, and raffle tickets.

  • If we do not reach our goal any money will go directly to rental costs.

The Impact

Horrific is a fun experience that's meant to make you laugh, scream, and cheer. We want to spread that fun for the macabre to others. Seeing as this show has been a huge success in the past we looking forward to becoming better and better every year. 

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge will be financial stability. Creating shows is always a risk, but it's one we're willing to make. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Feel free to share this to friends, family, and ghouls!

Horrific is a fun experience that's meant to make you laugh, scream, and cheer. We want to spread that fun for the macabre to others. Seeing as this show has been a huge success in the past we looking forward to becoming better and better every year.

Our biggest challenge will be financial stability. Creating shows is always a risk, but it's one we're willing to make. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Feel free to share this to friends, family, and ghouls!

story:
Short Summary

Room 29 Theatre are proud to be presenting 'It Shoulda Been You' the Broadway musical comedy at the Edinburgh Fringe this summer and we need your help to make it the best possible show it can be! 

We are new Scottish based theatre company and excited to present the fringe premiere of this wonderful show.  To make sure we can deliver the highest standard of production we are hoping to raise funds to support our wonderful cast and crew putting on this show.  The money raised from this campaign will go directly to the lavish wedding costumes, set and marketing/PR materials. 

You as a contributor will be helping a new theatre group put on a hilarious show to a new audience.  As a thank you for contributing, we are offering rewards such as tickets to the show, seat reservation privileges, video thank you messages and show t-shirts. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need £1000 to support our production costs this year. Staging any sort of production poses a lot of financial challenges, and particularly those in the Edinburgh Fringe.  We have got this far through traditional fundraising (such as concerts, ceilidhs and pub quizzes) but we need this extra boost to help us hit our target.  

The money raised will go directly to the following things: 

  • Costumes - this show is set in a modern-day wedding, and just like a real wedding these outfits don’t come cheap!  Our costume designer is finding cost effective ways to create these costumes and we have budgeted £300 to this. 
  • Set - as a fringe production the set is very minimal but we will be creating our own mirrors and moving chairs that will also need to be collapsible to keep in the small storage space available - £200
  • Props - we require some very specific props including a bridal bouquet, countless fake bottles of bubbly, and even a panni maker - £100
  • Company insurance - this is something we must pay for to ensure our actors, crew and band are covered in case we have any accidents - £200
  • PR costs - we have a lot of publicity planned and have created a flyer and posters that we would like to distribute throughout Edinburgh and every day of the run on the Royal Mile. We already have slots ready on the royal mile stages where we will be previewing some of songs to the passers-by - £200

If we can raise our target of £1000 this will go a long way and provide a lot of support for a fresh, new theatre company that is taking on the mammoth task of taking a show to the Edinburgh Fringe. 

The Impact

The impact will be great on those taking part in It Shoulda Been You and for the audience that will see this show.  Our campaign goal is relatively small compared to our overall budget, however as outlined above with careful planning this can go a long way to give our production that extra bit of wow factor to help us stand out in the every busy Fringe programme.

Room 29 Theatre might be a new company but as individuals we have plenty of experience. As a producer, James Leggat achieved success when he led Dundee Uni's musical theatre society to a success with the The Addams Family.  That year the society also achieved most progressive society for our hard work turning the group around. 

Our director, Neil Lavin, directed the five-star European premiere of Heathers: The Musical and has had a wealth of experience working on productions all across Scotland, and even in Virginia Beach, USA with Tidewater Stage.

Room 29 are very excited to also have Steven Segaud and Nel Springrose as a part of the team.  Steven's musical director credits include EUSOG's Little Shop of Horrors and Edinburgh Uni's Footlights version of Urinetown.  Nel Springrose our choreographer has worked with G&T productions was also the choreographer for Edinburgh Footlight's Rent.  

We have an excellent team of people with plenty of theatre experience and we are all excited to be working together for the first time on this fantastic show with a wonderful, talented cast. 

Risks & Challenges

Every show, especially those in the Fringe, has an element of financial risk to it.  The Fringe environment is very competitive with hundreds of shows to see.  To break even, we need to sell a certain number of tickets.  

We are very confident that we can achieve this because of our experience and our strict and well prepared budget.  Furthermore, although we are a new theatre group with no reputation we do however have an experienced cast and creative from from all over the UK, with our company coming together from Dundee, Edinburgh, Aberdeen, Glasgow, London and Plymouth.  We are certainly excited to bring together this great mix of performers from different backgrounds together to take part in the biggest arts festival in the world, on its 70th anniversary.  

Other Ways You Can Help

While our primary goal is fundraising, you can also show your support by buying tickets to our show, and spreading the word to all of your family and friends! We run from the 12th – 19th of August at 20:15 in Venue 45.

story:
PEER GYNT

The New York Times called The Immediate Family's PERCEVAL "smart, droll theater on a shoestring." This December, The Immediate Family returns with a fast-paced adaptation of PEER GYNT!

HERE’S THE STORY…

Peer Gynt is a Norwegian boy enamored of folktales about trolls, giant reindeer, and emperors wealthy beyond imagining. As he grows up, his gift for spinning fanciful lies takes him on many adventures all over the world, but he soon loses sight of his true self within the fantasies he creates. Will he reclaim his identity before it's too late?

We've stripped down Ibsen's sprawling four-hour opus to a ninety-minute, actor-driven roller coaster ride. To add to the excitement, composer Mackenzie Shivers will re-imagine Edvard Grieg's celebrated score ("In The Hall of the Mountain King," "Morning Mood," "Solveig's Song") and once again perform live with us onstage!

PLEASE CONSIDER MAKING A CONTRIBUTION...

PEER GYNT is our most ambitious project yet! An exceptional team of collaborators will gather to create a bold version of Ibsen's Norway inside the White Box Theater at Alchemical Theatre Laboratory's new location. In order to do so, we are seeking $5,000 to help compensate for the costs of this full-scale production. 

YOUR DONATION MEANS THE WORLD TO US!

Every dollar helps! $20 buys us a full hour of rehearsal space. A donation of $50 would pay for one of our set pieces, while $150 covers the cost of insuring all of our performers. If you can't contribute now, please consider volunteering as an usher to see the show for free (AND receive a delicious cookie)!

WE COULDN'T DO IT WITHOUT YOU!

Thank you in advance for your generosity. We can't wait to see you at the theater in December!

DECEMBER 5th through 20th

Fridays at 8 pm 

Saturdays at 3 & 8pm 

Sundays at 3pm

by HENRIK IBSEN

Adapted by SCOTT RAKER

From the English translation by WILLIAM & CHARLES ARCHER

Directed by HAAS REGEN

With Original Music Written & Performed by MACKENZIE SHIVERS, inspired by EDVARD GRIEG's Score

Featuring: BRITANNIE BOND*, JESSICA CRANDALL*, REBECCA HIROTA*, DAVID JACOBS, LIZZIE KING-HALL*, KHRIS LEWIN*, SCOTT RAKER*, JUDE SANDY*, and RUDI UTTER*

Illustration by ADAM SCOTT MAZER

*Appears Courtesy of Actors’ Equity Association.

story:
ON POINT DANCE IN COLLABORATION WITH UNREEL FILMS & YOU 

                                        are creating an eight part dance series.

 STRIVING

We believe the choices made in the ebb and flow of everyday life affect the artist on a personal level; thus the voice they strive to share.

We are capturing the journey of artists as they strive to create; and we are telling that story through dance. 

Our setting is the New York cityscape. As each of these dances unfold, the lives of the artist's connect and intertwine. The audience gets to see how the artists' choices not only affect others but the whole patchwork that is our art and our society.

 When the effect of life's shifting circumstances are forged with passion, creativity, and imagination... The result is captivating visceral artistry. Let's nurture the artist's voice and encourage collaboration from the ground up. Lets create something meaningful and beautiful together! 

Join the movement!

#STRIVING 


Who We Are: 

We are On Point Dance. Our goal is to create, and help others create beautiful, meaningful art. Art that touches people and makes them realize what they can do, and who they can be. Thanks for taking the time to watch our video and help in our cause! Come Create with us!


Jeffrey Nunez (Executive Producer):

Jeffrey is the founder and CEO of On Point. He got his B.F.A in Musical Theatre from Penn State and then was seen in various regional productions and readings eventually leading to performing on the second national tour of In the Heights where he got to work with Michael Balderama, Alex Lacamoire, Andy Blankenbuehler, and Tommy Kail. After tour he created the On Point Dance App and conceived/produced the “Royals Tap” video (see below).


Gina Duci (Director of Choreography/Producer):


Gina has been dancing since the age of 3 under the mentorship of Broadway veteran Mary Jane Houdina. She received her B.F.A in Musical theatre from Penn State University. After graduating she worked regionally until being cast as Diana Morales in the national tour of A Chorus Line under the direction of original cast member Baayork Lee. While on tour she taught master classes of the original ACL choreography across the country and then continued to teach master classes in NYC and various dance schools in the Tristate area. Gina has always believed that dance is about emotion and feeling. If you stumble, make it part of YOUR dance.


Eric Mann (Director of Photography/Producer):


Eric founded Unreel Films, LLC in 2013 and has since directed, produced, filmed, edited, written, and photographed over 70 projects including the SAG Short Film "Alistair's Wednesday," the documentary Just Go, the TV Pilot "Looking Up," the documentary web series "Climate Countdown," dance and music videos, commercials/promos, weddings, concerts, reels, and regularly shoots for The Juilliard School.  As an actor, Eric has toured with the National Tour of A Chorus Line, worked at North Shore Music Theatre, Cape Playhouse, Bay Street Theatre, North Carolina Theatre, Arkansas Repertory Theatre, and was in the NYMF production of Cloned!  He has a BFA from Elon University, studied at the Michael Chekhov Studio, Upright Citizens Brigade, Ballet Arkansas, and Broadway Theatre Project.  



WITH YOUR HELP

With your help we will be able to pay for all of the production costs of these 8 videos along with being able to pay a small amount to the directors and performers for each video 


Total - $2,500 per video 

Grand Total - $20,000


- 3 crew members

- 2-4 actors/dancers per video

- Filming throughout the end of summer/early fall

-First video to launch in October


The videos will be shot in NYC within the next few months. Anything you can contribute will be extremely helpful (check out our awesome perks)!


OTHER WAYS TO HELP

-Make sure you follow us on facebook, instagram, twitter, and pinterest

-Spread the word on social media. Nothing is more helpful than this!

    www.onpointdance.com

    www.facebook.com/strivingseries

    www.twitter.com/onpointdanceapp

    www.instagram.com/onpointdanceapp

#onpointdance

#striving

#nico&vinz


THANK YOU!

This project is for the dreamers. It is for anyone who has followed their dream and had to take a detour. Anyone who knows someone out there fighting to make their dreams a reality. Join us by collaborating with us on this dream. Thanks again for giving us your time and we can’t wait to get started on this project!

"What you do speaks so loudly that I cannot hear what you say."  - Ralph Waldo Emerson



Royals Tap On Point Dance - www.onpointdance.com Natalie Weiss - www.natalieweiss.net Allie Pizzo Gina Duci Felipe Galganni Andrew Hodge Alex MacDonald Produced by Jeffrey Nunez - On Point Dance Filmed and Directed by Eric Mann - UnReel Films Choreographed by Allie Pizzo www.unreel-films.com



This is what we did during Winter Storm Juno "It's Time" - Imagine Dragons Gina Duci Nathan Lucrezio Eric Mann Johnny Stellard Kaia Rose www.unreel-films.com

story:
Dear Bedlamites. We need your help in a major way right now. 

Since 1993, Bedlam has continued to provide a steady supply of original, avant-garde performances for The Twin Cities and regional audiences. Bedlam supports a year-round calendar of local, national, and international artists in theatre, dance, music, puppetry, performance art, and more. We like to try new things, so no year in twenty-two has ever been exactly like the last. In this last year, we've tried another HUGE thing; we opened Bedlam Lowertown!

Over the last few months, we’ve doubled our monthly revenue at Bedlam, our labor and expense costs are dropping, and we are at the point where we see what a sustainable Bedlam looks like. However, the bold faced numbers show that we still have a shortfall. We need to raise $400,000 in a capital campaign, and we need to do it by December for our 2016 to start right. Without these funds, we face complete closure, both in Lowertown and as an organization. 

This Indiegogo campaign will supply $75,000 to our capital campaign and allow us some much needed immediate relief, with the rest of the money coming from 21 Bedlam Beer nights, major donors, and entrepreneurial activities. You can check out our whole plan of action here on our website. 

What We Need & What You Get

This $75,000 will go to:

  • Paying artists
  • Replacing the cooler that just went out in our kitchen 
  • Helping to pay our amazing, dedicated crew of staff
  • Supplementing our rent and utilities payments
  • Relieving the pressure of upcoming sales tax
  • Helping to cover music licensing fees 

Bedlam is a 501c3 nonprofit. Your donation is tax deductible!

The Impact

More than anything, we want to continue the work we're doing in Lowertown. You’ve helped us do some incredible things this year: you showed up for over 358 individual events, drank more than 44,000 beers, and scarfed down 17,000 condiments with your meals. We've hosted amazing performances (Beaverdance, Black Bitch, Space Girl, Short Shorts, and many more), incredible concerts  (For The Love, Jazz Fest, Saun & Star, Tickle Torture), freaking awesome dance (Morgan Thorson, B-boy competitions) and so much more, leading us to be named "Best Artsy Hangout Spot" by CityPages. Your financial support will help keep our doors open to do all that we do, with you, through 2015 and beyond.

Risks & Challenges

We're up against a time crunch. We need to make this goal by September 15th, or we will not be able to continue as an organization. If you believe in Bedlam, please support us in this time of crisis! Your contribution is what will make the difference. 


The 5 Things You Can Do To Help

  1. Contribute with your dollars. Give to the IndieGogo. Match funds from the IndieGogo campaign. Show your support through the moneys, and share this campaign with your friends!

  2. Come in and have a beer! Bring your friends. Introduce new people to Bedlam. Eat the food and share the love, every Tuesday and beyond. Check out what's playing here.

  3. Volunteer! Run box office for an event, or staff a phone bank, offer us professional consultations, or flier the neighborhood. We'll be posting ways to get involved in this Facebook group.

  4. Bring your event here! Birthday parties, office gatherings, meetings, etc. Or, if you have a show or event and want it to happen here, that’s great, too! Check out this page for a rundown on our box office splits, info about the space, and the series of dates and times we have available in the next two months.

  5. Be a reward. Help us out with our IndieGogo campaign by donating visual or performance art. If you’re interested in contributing something to the campaign, let us know at at alana@bedlamtheatre.org

story:
The Project

Founded in 2005, Bellingham Repertory Dance (BRD) is a nonprofit collective of dancers in Bellingham, WA. New things are on the horizon for season 11 and we invite you to be a part of it!

This year, BRD will be presenting 7 exciting works of dance at the Firehouse Performing Arts Center, for students at Western Washington University, and for Seattle audiences down south. This show is more elaborate than we're used to and requires special props like lounge chairs, fancy socks, and a glamorous tailor-made dress, in addition to all of our usual overhead expenses.

The Goal

We hope to raise $2,750 for the project. Your contribution will go directly towards:

  • Props and costuming expenses
  • Choreographer fees
  • Rehearsal space expenses
  • Promotional costs
  • Performance venue and technical support
BRD is run entirely on a volunteer basis. No one is paid for the hundreds of hours of rehearsal, performance, teaching, and administrative work that we do for the company. When we reach our goal for this campaign, we hope to offer partial stipends to each dancer for performance time. Our purpose is not to make money, but to do what we love and bring dance into people's lives. We hope to make BRD as sustainable as possible so we can continue this mission!

The Impact

In Bellingham. Since we are focusing on one show this season, we will have time and energy to bring it to its full performance potential! The work will premiere for local audiences at the Firehouse Performing Arts Center on January 20-21 and 27-29. BRD will also feature select works from this show for elementary school students at the Children's Educational Matinee on February 17, to show these young students the varieties and possibilities of contemporary dance. On February 18, BRD will share the stage with the Seattle-based group, AU Dance Collective, in a split-bill performance at Western Washington University to add even more diversity to the show and expand the dance experiences of our Bellingham audiences.

And beyond. Season 11 also has a touring component to it. Following our Bellingham presentations of this show, BRD will hit the road in the spring of 2017. Last year, BRD sold out two performances at Velocity Dance Center in Seattle and we reached 200 new audience members this way; many of which had likely never seen dance out of Bellingham before. We hope to achieve this and more this season, but we can’t do it alone.

Everything helps!

Seriously... everything. Feel free to peruse our list of contribution perks on the right side of the page. We completely understand that not everyone can donate, but if you find this project inspiring and you want to help make it happen, here are some FREE ways to do so:

  • Tell your friends and family
  • Share the video on Facebook
  • Tweet about it
  • Plop it in an email
  • Send it to your colleagues at work
  • Etc.

Let's make some art together! We cannot thank you enough.

Sincerely, the Season 11 Bellingham Repertory Dancers 

All photos used for this campaign were taken by Nolan Alan McNally.

story:
The Major Matt Mason Theatre Collective (MMMC), in association with Sage Theatre, is proud to announce the second annual Wildfire National Playwriting Competition.

We are accepting submissions from playwrights 30 and under; we want fresh scripts that embrace risk, grit and evocation. The Wildfire National Playwriting Competition allows young playwrights from all walks of life across the country to send in a script for consideration. It’s also an opportunity for Major Matt Mason and Sage Theatre to get to know the emerging playwrights of this country, and build a dialogue and working partnership with each of them, even if they are not selected as the top two winners.

What are your donations going towards?

The winning playwrights:

1st place will receive:

  • A $1000 cash prize

  • A personalized one week workshop in Calgary with MMMC based completely on the wishes of the playwright. The winning playwright will have access to choreographers, designers, dramaturgical support, a director, actors - whatever resources they feel their script needs to get to the next stage of development.

  • A reading at Sage Theatre’s IGNITE! Festival For Emerging Artists in June 2016.


The runner up will receive:

  • A $350 cash prize

  • A public reading of their play at Sage Theatre’s IGNITE! Festival For Emerging Artists in June 2016. 


In addition to the prizes, we are utilizing the remainder of the funds raised from this campaign for…

  • Travel costs to bring the playwright to Calgary

  • Printing and other extraneous production costs

  • Honorariums for jury members and workshop participants such as actors, directors, and dramaturgical support


** In addition to your donations, both the Major Matt Mason Collective and Sage Theatre will be donating resources in the forms of money, time, and workshop space **



The Wildfire National Playwriting Competition is a chance to create something big.


It is an opportunity to shine a light on new Canadian talents and foster a new age in Canadian theatre. 2016 will mark IGNITE!’s twelfth anniversary. In the years since IGNITE!’s inception, hundreds of young artists, including MMMC alumnus, have used the festival to bridge their theatrical background to the professional theatre community; between amateur and professional; between a hobby and a career.


We believe that the Wildfire National Playwriting Competition is the next step in continuing IGNITE!’s legacy of support for young theatre artists.


By donating, you are making a difference in the lives of young theatre artists across Canada. Thank you for your support!


Submissions for the Wildfire National Playwriting Competition are until March 20, 2016  at www.mmmtheatrecollective.com/wildfire



Can’t donate? Here’s how you can help! Like and share this campaign and support us on social media!

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/MMMCollective

Twitter: @MMMCollective

Instagram: majormattmasoncollective

story:
Welcome and thank you for visiting “Sounds of Arts Festival 2012” fundraising page!

Who is Multicultural Sonic Evolution (MuSE)?

We are MuSE, a non-profit organization co-directed by composer Yui Kitamura and percussionist Chihiro Shibayama. (Click our names to learn more about ourselves individually) Each season we produce unique showcases that provide talented artists who embrace musical elements in their work with a platform for sharing their craft. Our collaborators include dancers, film makers, animators, writers, fashion and hair stylists, and so on.

To this date, we have produced 1 full-musical production, 2 musical theater cabarets, 6 classical chamber music concerts, 2 kimono shows, 1 multimedia, 2 dance concert, 1 Jazz/holiday concert, 1 poplar/folk music concert and 4 salon concerts in New York tri- state area and New Jersey. 

The MuSE logo is a tri-colored asterism (* this symbol) , and each of its asterisks represents one of the core values of the organization: red stands for passion, blue for trust, and green for dreams. MuSE’s goal is to bring these values to bear at the crossroads where various traditions and disciplines meet. The result promises to be one that draws on the past to create a bright and promising future.

What’s “Sounds of Arts Festival (SOAF)”?

We had our first “Sounds of Arts Festival 2011” in November 2011. We had wanted to create a multidisciplinary show that combined elements of film, dance, fashion and music.  If all of these artforms were infused with music, what would that sound like?  It was through this creative process that the "Sounds of Arts Festival" was born.  We now have an opportunity to build on the success of the first show by presenting the "Sounds of Arts Festival 2012": a five-day-long event showcasing five different programs, including the world premiere of many exciting works that will bring together the artistic talents of over 40 artists in the realms of film, dance, and musical theater.

<5 Programs>

Program A - 11/28/2012（wed）@8pm  ($500 to go!)
Treasuring the Moments - II (MuSE String Quartet Concert)
MuSE String Quartet
      Chie Yoshinaka & Ashley Windle; violins
      Jules Lai, viola
      Jeanette Stenson, cello
Cristina Spinei, composer

Program B - 11/29/2012（thurs）
@8pm & Saturday, December 1, 2012 @2pm   ($1200 to go!)
Multimedia Live Showcase -music & theatre & dance & film-
      
       A collection of new works by Emerging Artists   
       “murmuRing-shimmEring-smuDging“ *
                       Wei-Chieh Lin, composer
             Cadillac Moon Ensemble, music performance
       “A Dancing Koi - Love 愛” *
             Music and concept by Yui Kitamura, composer        
             Kana Takahashi, dance
             Takahisa Shiraishi, film
             Cadillac Moon Ensemble, music performance
       “Boring the Tall Blond to Death” *
             Choreography by Clare Cook
             Music by Donny Codden
             Text by Leah Miles
       “botlek redux” *
           Choreographer: Shannon Gillen
             Dancer: Troy Ogilvie
             Music: Toshuba
*world premiere

Program C - Friday, November 30, 2012
@8pm & Saturday, December 1, 2012 @7pm
Welcome To New Yawk! - A Five-Borough Musical Tour   ($2500 to go!)
       Works by:            
       <Staten Island>
           Clive Chang & Molly McQue
       <Brooklyn>
           Sebastian Fabal
       <Queens>
           Yui Kitamura & Lauren Epsenhart
       <Manhattan>
           Andrew Heyman & Chris Widney
       <Bronx>
           Donny Codden & Leah Miles
This is an all-world-premiere production.

Program D - Sunday, December 2, 2012 @2pm  ($400 to go!)
MuSE 1st Young Composers’ Competition Awards Concert
      Program includes works by young composer winners performed by
      MuSE String Quartet
      Chie Yoshinaka & Ashley Windle; violins
      Jules Lai, viola
      Jeanette Stenson, cello          

Program E - Sunday, December 2, 2012 @7pm   ($400 to go!)
RESET 
produced and performed by Troy Ogilvie
choreography by Austin McCormick, Shannon Gillen, Harumi Terayama, and Margie Gillis
costumes by Marion Talan
music by Mikael Karlsson and others
 
*Due to the schedule change caused by Hurricane Sandy, the performance of "Thesis Defense" (originally planned) will be postponed and replaced by "RESET".

What We Need & What You Get

<Raised>

We have been fortunate enough to receive grants from Queens Council on the Arts to cover the following costs:

Venue Fee $2100 (performance and some rehearsal) 

Instrument & Equipment rental/delivery fee: $600

Flyer, program, ads printing fee: $300

<Still in Need>

$5000 for:
Some extra rehearsal venue fees and Artists' Fees 

PROGRAM A  ($500 to go!)

PROGRAM B  ($1200 to go!)

PROGRAM C  ($2500 to go!)

PROGRAM D  ($400 to go!)

PROGRAM E  ($400 to go!)

 

<What you get when you donate>

All your donations made for MuSE will be tax-deductible because we are a non-profit group registered under 501(c)3.

Exciting perks include:

    • $15 (MuSE original postcard & mention in MuSE website)

    • $25 (MuSE original calendar magnet & all of the previous perks)

    • $50 (SOAF2012 Program C “Welcome to New Yawk!” demo recording hard copy & mention in the SOAF program & all of the previous perks)

    • $75 (MuSE original desk calendar & all of the previous perks)

    • $100 (2 tickets to any future MuSE events &  BLUE-asterisk sponsor title & all of the previous perks)

    • $250 (1 MuSE VIP ticket which gives access to all future concerts in 2012-13 season &  GREEN-asterisk sponsor title & all of the previous perks)

    • $500 (2 MuSE VIP tickets which give access to all future concerts in 2012-13 season & RED-asterisk sponsor title & all of the previous perks)

    • $1000 (4 MuSE VIP tickets which give access to all future concerts in 2012-13 season & RED-asterisk sponsor title & original composition written just for you by Yui Kitamura & all of the previous perks)
    • $2500 (2 VIP passes -for you and your friend- for SOAF2013 which give access to any SOAF2013 shows in fall 2013 & Tri-colored Asterisk sponsor title & an original composition written just for you by Yui Kitamura (premiered at SOAF2013) & all of the previous perks.)

Even if we do not reach our entire funding goal, all artists will be given a small amount of compensation. All donation will help us with future productions.

Thank you, thank you, thank you!

1) Thank you so much for taking the time to read our campaign and consider donating.

Please note that you have an option to stay anonymous if you prefer.

No amount is too small - if you want to skip the perks and chose the smaller donation amount, you can do so after you click on “contribute now” button.

All donation is tax-deductible!

 

2) Thank you so much for spreading the word.

We understand that making a financial contribution can be difficult for some people. You can be a huge help by simply telling your friends about our campaign.

3) Thank you so much for coming (in advance) to SOAF 2012.

We would love to see you at one or more programs that we offer at SOAF 2012! We assure you that you will have a great time. To purchase tickets to any of SOAF 2012 programs please visit here >>https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/cal/1681/1351814400000

story:
Short Summary

Breathe for those who can not.

Drawing on our experience as theatre practitioners, healers, and movers we are compelled to help the survivors of this tragedy. We believe that theatre is inherently healing and therapeautic. We hold grief in the body even when we don't know it. We are creating a workshop that allows pariticipants to explore, create, and connect with other members of the community through contemporary theatre practices, yoga, and meditation.

 

Nikki Weaver is a new mother of six month old, Margot Penny Weaver. She holds a BFA in Performing Arts from The Australian Academy of Dramatic Arts and an MFA in Classical Theatre from The George Washington University. She is the Education Director of Portland Playhouse, a certified yoga instructor, and a registered massage therapist.

Shelley Virginia is a performer and educator focused on ensemble based generative work.  She holds an MFA in theatre from Columbia University where she studied with Anne Bogart and Kristin Linklater, among others. Shelley has a background in mental health and is currently teaching a creative movement class at PHAME academy, the Portland region's fine and performing arts organization serving adults with developmental disabilities. 

What We Need & What You Get

Your funding will provide a full day workshop for survivors in need of additional support. Your gift will allow participants to understand grief and give a space for healing to occur. Remaining funds will be donated to the students and staff at Sandy Hook Elementary.

 

The Impact

"Collective trauma is a blow to the basic tissues of social life that damages the bonds attaching people together and impairs the prevailing sense of community."

-K. Erikson

It is better to light candles than to curse the darkness. Your contribution carries weight. Thank you for believing in the light.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page with your friends and family, and help us come together as we look towards the future.

story:
Our Tenth Season

Hudson Warehouse was founded nine years ago with the mission of providing free classical theater to all.  We are an outdoor theater company, located in Riverside Park in the heart of The Upper Westside of New York City, along the Hudson River.   Audiences rave that experiencing our theater productions, against the backdrop of the setting sun along the Hudson River, is a thrilling and unique experience.  And it’s all for FREE.

"We congratulate Hudson Warehouse on their 10th year presenting Classics to the public in Riverside Park. We are thrilled that they have made their home with us and hope they will continue to enchant Riverside Park's neighbors and all other guests with their theatrical mettle for years to come."

-- Zhen Heinemann, Director of Public Programming, Riverside Park, New York City Parks Department, February 14, 2013

Who are We?

We started out presenting one show over two weekends.
Now we produce a three show season that spans the entire Summer.

Over The Past 9 Years We’ve Grown Enormously.

We now have both the ‘Shakespeare in the Bar’ and the ‘Writers-a-Go-Go’ reading series.  Our outreach includes colleges, youth organizations as well as our own ‘Hudson Warehouse Shakespeare Workout’ which is held three Saturdays during the Summer season. 

A Two Show Winter Season is Upon Us.

We have grown from one production a summer to a three show season that spans the entire summer and this winter I’m excited to announce that we will be moving indoors. We will be producing a show at the Bernie Wohl Center here in NYC this November for a three week run . We will follow that up with another production to be produced in March of 2014, thereby extending our season all year around.

Our 10th Year! 

This year your donations go towards our Summer Season in Riverside Park, our Education and Outreach and our First Full Season Indoors.

The Impact

We have spent Nine Years bringing Free classical theater to the public on the North Patio of the Soldiers’ and Sailors’ Monument.  We have attracted people from as far away as New Zealand and Taiwan. Rotterdam and London. We are part of the fabric of the Upper West Side, part of New York City, part of people's lives. People who are from all over the world, people who just find us.  People who look for us.

Why?

Though we are a non-for-profit corporation we have continued to exist by public donations, not by corpoate grants.  We have stayed "grass roots" in order not to lose touch with our basic belief: that theater is an esential part of being human. So we look to our family, our friends, the Warehouse company members and our loyal audience, for it’s their donations that allow us to continue to exist and to grow.

The Hudson Warehouse is a 501 (c) 3 non-for-profit company. Donations are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by the law.
story_txt:
Our Tenth Season
Hudson Warehouse was founded nine years ago with the mission of providing free classical theater to all.  We are an outdoor theater company, located in Riverside Park in the heart of The Upper Westside of New York City, along the Hudson River.   Audiences rave that experiencing our theater productions, against the backdrop of the setting sun along the Hudson River, is a thrilling and unique experience.  And it’s all for FREE.
"We congratulate Hudson Warehouse on their 10th year presenting Classics to the public in Riverside Park. We are thrilled that they have made their home with us and hope they will continue to enchant Riverside Park's neighbors and all other guests with their theatrical mettle for years to come."
-- Zhen Heinemann, Director of Public Programming, Riverside Park, New York City Parks Department, February 14, 2013
Who are We?
We started out presenting one show over two weekends. Now we produce a three show season that spans the entire Summer.
Over The Past 9 Years We’ve Grown Enormously.
We now have both the ‘Shakespeare in the Bar’ and the ‘Writers-a-Go-Go’ reading series.  Our outreach includes colleges, youth organizations as well as our own ‘Hudson Warehouse Shakespeare Workout’ which is held three Saturdays during the Summer season. 
A Two Show Winter Season is Upon Us.
We have grown from one production a summer to a three show season that spans the entire summer and this winter I’m excited to announce that we will be moving indoors. We will be producing a show at the Bernie Wohl Center here in NYC this November for a three week run . We will follow that up with another production to be produced in March of 2014, thereby extending our season all year around. 
Our 10th Year! 
This year your donations go towards our Summer Season in Riverside Park, our Education and Outreach and our First Full Season Indoors.
The Impact


We have spent Nine Years bringing Free classical theater to the public on the North Patio of the Soldiers’ and Sailors’ Monument.  We have attracted people from as far away as New Zealand and Taiwan. Rotterdam and London. We are part of the fabric of the Upper West Side, part of New York City, part of people's lives. People who are from all over the world, people who just find us.  People who look for us.
Why?
Though we are a non-for-profit corporation we have continued to exist by public donations, not by corpoate grants.  We have stayed "grass roots" in order not to lose touch with our basic belief: that theater is an esential part of being human. So we look to our family, our friends, the Warehouse company members and our loyal audience, for it’s their donations that allow us to continue to exist and to grow.
The Hudson Warehouse is a 501 (c) 3 non-for-profit company. Donations are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by the law.

story:
Why you should support this project

The Walltown Children’s Theatre in Durham, North Carolina is embarking on another GREAT production and we need your help!

We are in the early stages of producing Indigo Blue, a play that was written especially for our theatre by local award-winning playwright, Howard Craft. In order to bring this beautiful creation to life, we’re asking you to make a contribution. Our goal is to raise $5,000 to help pay for production costs like set design, costumes, and an original music score. As a small non-profit organization, we simply cannot produce this play without your help.

Indigo Blue is not your typical children's play. Audiences will be riveted by Howard Craft's unique and inspiring adaptation of the classic tale of the Pied Piper. When you contribute to Indigo Blue you are supporting both underserved youth in our community as well as local artists and original local theater.

At Walltown Children's Theatre we believe it is important to give children the opportunity to perform in a professional atmosphere. By doing so, we communicate the seriousness of our investment in their talent. Again, and again, we have seen Durham youth rise to the expectations we set for them. This is why it is important to stage this production in an excellent venue with professional support staff.

Give what you can -- we’re grateful for any amount to help us reach this goal!

More about Walltown Children's Theatre

Walltown Children’s Theatre is a non-profit that inspires positive social change by developing and reconnecting diverse, under-served youth in Walltown and the surrounding communities through exemplary performing arts programming, after-school academic tutoring and collaborative leadership opportunities. We opened our doors more than 10 years ago with a mission to bring the arts into the lives of children of all racial backgrounds, regardless of their ability to pay. You can find out more about our organization and programming at walltownchildrenstheatre.org.

More about Indigo Blue, by Howard Craft

This adaptation/interpretation of the classic fairy tale takes place in the multi-cultural mythical city of Milele Baada Ya. It follows the journey of ten-year-old Mariposa as she struggles to find and free her younger brother who has, along with the other children of Milele Baada Ya, been kidnapped by Maestro Marvin The Magnifico, aka the Pied Piper. To aid her on her journey she enlists the help of Lavern the gossiping lamp post, Tarik the talking cookie turned professional wrestler and the incomparable genius, Floyd, a platinum turtle. Music, song, and dance are used to guide the audience through this magical land. Staying true to the lessons of the Pied Piper, the importance of integrity and the consequences of lying, this updated version goes a step further and teaches that even when one is confronted with situations or obstacles that seem insurmountable, with a strong belief in self and the support of like minds, even the impossible becomes possible. Find out more about Howard Craft's work at http://about.me/howardcraft.

Where your money goes

Our total budget for the production is $15,000. We expect about third of these costs to be met by ticket sales. Another third will be raised through grants and commercial sponsorship. For the final $5,000, we are turning to you, our community! When you see Indigo Blue on the stage and experience the magic of live performance, you will be proud to know that you had a hand in opening the curtain for Durham’s young artists.

Your contribution will help us pay for

  • Set Design
  • Costumes
  • Lighting Design
  • Sound Production
  • Musical Score
  • Musicians
  • Adult Actors
  • Stage Director
  • Stage Manager
  • Publicity
  • Theater Rental

Can we exceed the goal?

Absolutely! Our budget goals are extremely conservative and anything beyond what we are asking for will ease our pressure to seek additional support. If you are a local business owner and you are interested in a commercial sponsorship, please contact us at walltownchildrenstheatredurham@gmail.com.

Other ways to help

Spread the word! We would really appreciate it if you would share our Indiegogo campaign with your friends, colleagues and families on Facebook, Twitter, and through email. Note the easy "share" buttons provided so that you can easily pass this information along. We also hope you will encourage your children to audition for the show and attend with your families!

Please don’t forget to share this campaign with your friends!

story:
See What I Hear

The Murphy/Smith Dance Collective [MSDC] was founded in January of 2011 by Pittsburgh based choreographers Jamie Erin Murphy and Renee Danielle Smith. After establishing themselves as independent emerging choreographers they joined together to form the Murphy/Smith Dance Collective. They have performed in several venues including the Kelly-Strayhorn Theater, New Hazlett Theater, the Grey Box Theater, The Union Project, Dance Alloy and John Ryan Theater.

Murphy/Smith Dance Collective's premier of See What I Hear explores the relationship between sound and human instinct.  In our everyday life the sounds around us create an environment, a source of communication and even our general feeling of safety. What can happen when our famiiliar soundscape becomes distorted or even disappears? MSDC investigates how sound, or lack of sound, affects our way of life and communication. 

What We Need & What You Get

Funding for this project will include:

  • Artist Fees For Dancers, Composers, Set Designer, And Light Designer
  • Rehearsal/Performance Space
  • A Large Set For A Proscenium Stage 
  • Costumes For Seven Dancers And Costume Design

Fund MSDC Because:

  • They are an integral part of the Pittsburgh Dance Community
  • They are a project based dance company contingent upon sponsoring and fundraising
  • They are young artists with fresh perspective and have ideas larger than their bank accounts!
  • They are really nice
  • If they do not receive all of the required funding, they will present the show on a smaller scale. No funds will be wasted.

WHAT YOU GET!!!

If You Donate:

$10: You will be listed as a project sponsor in the program, on the website, and in any upcoming newsletters!

$25: All of the above + a Facebook Shout Out!

$50: All of the above + you will receive a personalized Facebook/YouTube Video Thank You From Artistic Directors Jamie Erin Murphy and Renee Smith!

$100: All of the above +a Hand Written Thank You from Artistic Directors Jamie Erin Murphy and Renee Smith!

$150: All of the above + a Signed Photo of the See What I Hear cast!

$200: All of the above + a Brand New Original Murphy/Smith Dance Collective T-Shirt

$250+: All of the above +a DVD of See What I Hear

The Impact

This project began as a performance piece created to explore how individual lives are affected with the loss of sound.  The piece has developed from being specifically about hearing loss to how sound and lack of sound directly affect people in groups and in isolation. See What I Hear uses an intricate set, projection, and an original score to build environments and soundscapes to transport the audience into a sound filled world of grace and distortion. The dancers work through audio and physical boundaries through desolation, stillness, a range of vocal volumes, and matching movement to sound memories.

Murphy and Smith are extremely grateful for the generosity their company has received through fundraising campaigns and recognize that this project would not be possible without all of your support. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

The best way to help support MSDC is to come see See What I Hear!

November 15th @ 8pm and November 16th @ 2pm and 8pm

Kelly-Strayhorn Theater


5941 Penn Ave Pittsburgh, PA 15206

To stay updated on Murphy/Smith Dance Collective's 2013/14 season check out their website:http://www.murphysmithdance.org

This project would not be possible without the help of the Heniz Endowments Small Arts Initiative and the Kelly-Strayhorn Theater.

The Heinz Endowments support efforts to make southwestern Pennsylvania a premier place to live and work, a center forlearning and educational excellence, and a region that embraces diversity and inclusion.

story:
“Thrilling! This isn’t just an ambitious show for the Fringe festival: it’s the creative standard to which companies should be pushing themselves.”

—Aaron Riccio, Theater Talk’s New Theater Corps (2009)


BRINGING IT ALL BACK 'HOUSE

We have the opportunity to present our original play Powerhouse at the prestigious New Ohio Theater in New York City this November. This will be the official premiere of the show—a moment we’ve been working toward for the last five years.

In 2009, our FringeNYC workshop production played to sold-out crowds and garnered rave reviews from the New York Times and Time Out New York, among others. The production won an award from the festival for “Outstanding Ensemble” and was one of 12 shows selected (out of over 200) as part of the FringeNYC Encores Series. 

Since then we’ve continued to develop the play, uncovering new research, and creating more material. In 2010, we did a private development workshop. In 2012 the script for Powerhouse was a finalist for the Eugene O’Neill National Playwrights Conference. In 2014, we booked the New Ohio.

We’re most of the way there. Now we need your help.



ABOUT THE SHOW

Inspired by swing music, animated cartoons and futuristic machines, Powerhouse takes the audience inside the mind of Raymond Scott. He wrote fast-paced, tightly orchestrated compositions, attempting to reinvent swing in the 1940s. Wildly successful in his own time, his music would be completely forgotten were it not for its use in countless Looney Tunes cartoons of the 1940s and 1950s. But Scott never watched a cartoon in his life.

Informed by interviews with family members and colleagues, and dozens of phone calls recorded by Scott, Powerhouse uses music and puppetry to spin a kaleidoscopic, kinetic story about the tension between a man’s pursuit of artistic transcendence and the destruction he leaves in his wake.

More info at www.powerhouse-theplay.com

YOUR DONATION AND WHERE IT WILL GO

We need to raise an additional $10,000 to get to our opening night on November 2nd. Powerhouse is the biggest production Sinking Ship has ever created, and this fully-realized version is many times more expensive than the Fringe workshop. Ticket sales will pay for about 30% of the cost, and much of the rest will be covered by donations from generous (and attractive!) people like you. Your help will have an enormous impact on our company, on our artists, and on the audiences who get to see Powerhouse thanks to your contribution. We are so very grateful!

We have already raised more than half of what we need to get to opening night, partly through grants from the New York State Council on the Arts, the Jim Henson Foundation, and ART/NY. It is your generosity that will take us the rest of the way.

Your donation will make possible:

  • PAYING ARTISTS - For the first time in our company history, we’re paying fees to performers, designers, producers, the writer, director & stage management team.
  • SPACE RENTAL - Theater and rehearsal studio rental.  
  • SET, COSTUMES, PUPPETS & PROPS - We've got incredible designers creating the world of the play. This takes materials, shop space, and labor.
  • MARKETING & PUBLICITY - Without an audience, there'd be no play.
  • INSURANCE, ETC - Boring, but necessary.
Transparency: Making theater is expensive, and we’re keeping costs to a minimum. If you’re interested in seeing how we’re doing it, and where your money is going, please have a look at our budget. 


OUR TEAM

Josh Luxenberg - Writer, Co-Creator

Jon Levin - Director, Co-Creator

Dina Vovsi - Producer / Production Manager


The Performers

Erik Lochtefeld - Raymond Scott

Tyler Bunch - Chuck / Puppeteer / Ensemble

Jessica Frey - Pearl / Ensemble

Spencer Lott - Carl / Puppeteer / Ensemble

Hanley Smith - Dorothy Collins / Ensemble

Eric Wright - Mel / Puppeteer / Ensemble


The Designers

Carolyn Mraz - Set Design

The Puppet Kitchen - Puppet Design

Nicholas Houfek - Lighting Design

Erin Schultz - Costume Design

Sean Brennan - Sound Design

Sara Morgan - Props Design



HERE’S WHAT THE PRESS HAS TO SAY ABOUT POWERHOUSE

All reviews are from the FringeNYC workshop production.

“Powerhouse, which somehow manages to pack very funny puppetry, exuberant dance numbers, fascinating historical tangents, a mountain of narrative and a vivid sense of period mood into one steam train of a drama, is the rare Fringe show that lives up to its title.”
—Jason Zinoman, The New York Times

**** [FOUR STARS] "To learn something new at the theater—at the Fringe, no less—is worth celebrating. Take this 75-minute biodrama by the splendid company Sinking Ship Productions… Aiming to honor the mad, creative urge to perfectly transmute ideas into art, this work succeeds beautifully.”
—David Cote, Time Out New York

"The direction and pacing are pitch perfect. We’re whisked from reality to cartoon pantomime to dream sequence and back to reality with just the right amount of brevity. Scenes bleed into each other like a series of spliced celluloid.”
—AndrewAndrew

“...a special rare joy... A word-of-mouth hit at the Fringe Festival... A pitch-perfect performance by Erik Lochtefeld... Both Levin and Luxenberg should be praised and put assuredly on your list of up and comers.”
—Patrick Lee, Just Goes To Show You

“Holy crap, that was awesome. From the moment it begins this show does not skip a beat… It’s really what live theater can be that no other medium can match… A brilliant, exciting piece of theater.”
—Theater Is Easy

“I’d put money on this show being one of the tightest, most entertaining productions you’ll see in the festival. Don’t miss it.”
—Emily Otto, NYTheatre.com


ABOUT SINKING SHIP

Sinking Ship Productions is a Brooklyn-based company dedicated to the creation of dynamic, physical, thrillingly visual theater using puppetry, object manipulation, music and movement.

Sinking Ship was founded in 2008 by Josh Luxenberg and Jon Levin. Our productions have grappled with concepts such as the creation and destruction of the universe as imagined by science fiction writers (There Will Come Soft Rains) and how a man’s search for connection could ultimately lead to complete isolation (Powerhouse). Flatland, a 2010 EST/Sloan commission, explores the limits of human understanding through the search for extra dimensions of space in theoretical physics and math. We like big ideas.

In addition to producing original work, Sinking Ship also runs the popular quarterly puppet and music series Puppet Playlist, which has played to sold-out crowds since 2009, becoming one of New York’s premiere venues for original short-form puppetry.

For more, visit www.sinkingshipproductions.com

story:
English Readers click HERE! (and click for subtitles on the video)

 

PREMESSA

In Italia, terra di confine tra il benessere dell'occidente e i territori colpiti dalla povertà e dalla guerra, si sta diffondendo in modo pericoloso la paura del diverso, inteso come rappresentante di una differente cultura, religione, stato sociale e visione del mondo.

Per questo vogliamo parlare insieme a voi di migranti in modo diverso.

Nasce perciò l'idea di costituire la prima compagnia teatrale umoristica, composta da immigrati ospitati nei centri di accoglienza italiani.

L'umorismo è un linguaggio universale, diretto e popolare, funzionale a unire i diversi punti di vista e a sdrammatizzare le esperienze tragiche. Attraverso il suo utilizzo è possibile fare incontrare su un terreno comune culture differenti, ribaltare gli stereotipi e stimolare l'autoironia sia di chi osserva sia di chi lo pratica.

OBIETTIVI

  • Costruire attraverso laboratori di umorismo occasioni di crescita e benessere per le popolazioni immigrate, oltre che opportunità professionali e di autostima per chi vuole far parte di una compagnia di teatro comico.
  • Ripercorrere con il linguaggio dell'umorismo l'esperienza dei migranti e le difficoltà legate all'ospitalità degli italiani, attraverso una visione meno negativa e conflittuale dell'intercultura.
  • Superare le barriere culturali e ribaltare gli stereotipi attraverso la messa in scena in chiave umoristica delle esperienze legate alla vita in Italia da extracomunitari e migranti.
  • Valorizzare la diversità culturale e la ricchezza derivante dalla condivisione di diversi saperi anche in ambito teatrale.
  • Stimolare media ed opinione pubblica a modificare il paradigma con cui sono raccontati gli stranieri in Italia (poveri di risorse e/o pericolosi per la società).

PROTAGONISTI

Migranti appena arrivati in Italia o con riconoscimento della protezione internazionale. Ospiti dei centri di prima e seconda accoglienza. Comunità di stranieri già attive sul territorio.

IL PROGETTO

  • Costituire una COMPAGNIA DI TEATRO COMICO, con attori extracomunitari provenienti da paesi diversi, accomunati da una buona capacità scenica, un certo senso dell’umorismo e soprattutto la disponibilità a mettersi in gioco.
  • Allestire uno SPETTACOLO multiculturale e multilinguistico sulle loro esperienze, dal viaggio alla permanenza nel nostro paese, per presentarlo al pubblico in Italia.
  • Distribuire lo spettacolo nel circuito teatrale italiano, rivolgendosi prima alle scuole, quindi a un pubblico generico e scuole.

 

  • Produrre un lungometraggio DOCUMENTARIO. Seguire il percorso della compagnia attraverso sensazioni, voci ed immagini, per raccontare una storia di un incontro. Quello di un regista italiano con i ragazzi migranti e quello dei ragazzi con il pubblico italiano.
  • Distribuire il documentario nazionalmente ed internazionalmente, a partire dalle scuole.

 

  • Pubblicare un LIBRO che raccolga i racconti di autori stranieri residenti in Italia già da qualche anno. Anche in questo caso il linguaggio scelto sarà quello umoristico. In appendice ai racconti, alcuni tra i maggiori ricercatori di umorismo approfondiranno l’argomento per dimostrare quanto  come l’umorismo possa essere un prezioso strumento di confronto e di interazione tra persone, popoli e culture.

 

 

LO SPETTACOLO TEATRALE

Il Sogno di Enea sarà uno spettacolo corale, immaginato insieme a chi, in questi anni, sta emigrando verso il nostro continente. La commedia ha come protagonisti alcuni profughi e rifugiati giunti nell’ultimo periodo, in gran parte attraverso il mare mediterraneo, su mezzi di fortuna e ospitati nei maggiori centri italiani di prima e seconda accoglienza.

Attraverso le loro testimonianze, lo spettacolo intende seguire l’avventura di chi, per fuggire a fame e guerra, è stato costretto ad attraversare il mare in cerca di nuovi spazi in cui vivere. Sarà un’alternanza di momenti di riflessione e impreviste situazioni buffe, risolte con sketch talvolta parlati, altre volte visuali, altre ancora a brevi monologhi in puro stile stand-up comedy.

Insieme a loro, sul palcoscenico, si muoveranno due attori professionisti africani ma da anni residenti in Italia, entrambi protagonisti del nostro panorama culturale: Mohamed Ba e Samuel Hili (il primo Senegalese ma residente a Milano, il secondo Ivoriano ma da anni a Mantova).

Il Sogno di Enea vuole essere innanzitutto uno spettacolo comico, che stimola il riso attraverso linguaggi e stili diversi. Dalle prime battute fino alla fine dello spettacolo, però, l’umorismo non è mai semplicemente un gioco liberatorio, finalizzato al divertimento e allo svago, bensì utilizzato come strumento di integrazione tra persone, popoli e culture.

Perché l’umorismo (a differenza della musica o del teatro, per esempio) non è un linguaggio universale: se ognuno di noi ride per cose differenti, già all’interno della stessa famiglia, possiamo immaginarci le differenze tra popoli, culture, religioni, età diversa.

La conquista sarà quindi ridere, ridere tanto e ridere insieme, perché se possiamo ridere tutti delle stesse cose allora non siamo poi così diversi l’uno dall’altro. Lo spettacolo alternerà momenti immaginifici, in stile quasi fiabesco, a passaggi puramente comici.

E ridendo, possiamo riflettere sulla realtà di questa epoca, nella quale due mondi, divisi dal Mar Mediterraneo, si affrontano e si confrontano, si attraggono e si respingono: un mondo che cerca pace e un minimo benessere materiale e un altro che ha il disperato bisogno di sogni e di speranze per ritrovare se stesso.

Ad accompagnare l’intero spettacolo saranno musiche evocative, alcune originali, altre necessariamente note, utili all’identificazione storico-culturale tra il pubblico, la storia e i suoi protagonisti. Nell’impianto scenografico ci sarà posto per alcuni contributi video, funzionali all’evoluzione della storia.

Lo spettacolo sarà in parte in lingua italiana e in parte nelle lingue dei protagonisti: inglese e francese ma anche lingue dei paesi di provenienza.

A interpretare i personaggi dello spettacolo saranno 5 ragazzi scelti in questi mesi nei centri di prima e seconda accoglienza in Puglia e che hanno partecipato ai laboratori ed al corso che si sta svolgendo tra settembre e novembre.

 

IL DOCUMENTARIO

Il documentario Il Sogno di Enea è la storia di un incontro, umano e professionale, tra un protagonista, italiano, e un gruppo composto da vari co-protagonisti.

Il viaggio nasce dai primi incontri tra Matteo Androne, autore, regista, docente teatrale e studioso di pensiero e linguaggio umoristico, fondatore e direttore dell’Accademia Nazionale del Comico, con un gruppo di migranti che vivono in alcuni centri di accoglienza, di vario tipo, arrivati da pochi mesi in Italia.

Lavorando fianco a fianco durante un percorso di 3/4 mesi, Matteo e i suoi co-protagonisti daranno vita e corpo a uno spettacolo interculturale e multilinguistico, basato sulle esperienze dei migranti, dalla vita nel paese di origine, al viaggio per giungere in Europa, fino alla permanenza in Italia, per presentarlo poi al pubblico in una tournée nazionale.

Il documentario seguirà l’evoluzione del progetto, dai primi incontri, dalle prime idee dei ragazzi, dai loro racconti, fino al complesso momento di creazione di uno spettacolo comico. Un percorso affascinante ma di non semplice attuazione: per i comprensibili ostacoli burocratici, le difficoltà tecniche e logistiche, l’emergere continuo di differenze culturali, comportamentali e relazionali e, non ultimo, le traversie legali che i migranti devono affrontare per vedersi o non vedersi riconosciuto lo stato di rifugiato.

Attraverso il vivere e lo scrivere insieme, i partecipanti al laboratorio daranno un’opportunità nuova e unica al pubblico di rovesciare il paradigma in cui il cittadino europeo si trova incastrato, frutto dell’apparentemente incontrastabile dicotomia “immigrato come “vittima” o “rischioso pericolo sociale”.

Il conflitto è anche la sfida che tutti i protagonisti lanciano al pubblico stesso, nello scegliere una forma e un linguaggio meno convenzionale, quello dell’umorismo, per affrontare temi personali e spesso drammatici ma reali e quotidiani.

Il documentario infine vuole evidenziare l’arricchimento personale che può nascere, per i tre soggetti coinvolti, l’insegnante, i ragazzi migranti e per il pubblico stesso, dal poter vedere ed ascoltare l’incontro e lo scambio tra Matteo, uomo di teatro dallo sguardo ironico, sensibile e onesto, e un gruppo di persone, spaesate in un sistema sociale non familiare, che hanno tuttavia il diritto di vivere e lavorare in libertà e con dignità, dopo aver compiuto una scelta difficilissima come quella della migrazione.

 

 

COME VENGONO IMPIEGATE LE VOSTRE DONAZIONI ?

Creazione e gestione dei laboratori di formazione

Ideazione e drammaturgia

Prove compagnia teatrale

Regia e allestimento dello spettacolo

Logistica

Sound location

Post-produzione documentario Montaggio, Coloring, Grafiche, Mixing audio,

Composizione e Diritti Musicali

Promozione, Festival e Distribuzione

 

PROGETTO CAMBOGIA

Parte del ricavato de Il Sogno di Enea sarà impiegato per aiutare 142 bambini a frequentare un anno di studi presso la Angkor Tree School, una scuola sita in una delle zone più povere del mondo. Per mantenere aperta la scuola servono circa 9,000 $ all’anno e le donazioni annuali arrivano a un massimo di 4,500 $. La restante parte abbiamo deciso di mettercela noi, devolvendo parte dell’incasso proprio de Il Sogno di Enea.

E' un’operazione che avrà una ricaduta concreta, per dare la possibilità a bambini molto poveri di continuare a studiare. Avrà però anche un valore simbolico, dal momento che a contribuire ai loro studi saranno proprio un gruppo di migranti in Italia, anch'essi fuggiti dalla guerra e dalla povertà. Tutto questo attraverso l’arte, il teatro e l’umorismo.

Per provare a spiegare meglio il significato dell’operazione, ci affidiamo alle parole di Roberto Cesarone, fondatore di Erasmus Theatre.

“ La scorsa estate, durante un viaggio nel sud est asiatico, ho incontrato una volontaria argentina che prestava servizio in quella che è una delle zone più povere del mondo. Grazie a lei ho conosciuto due professori cambogiani che stavano costruendo, in un piccolo paese, una scuola per bambini. Si trattava di 142 bambini in gravi difficoltà economiche, senza genitori e, molti di loro, vittime di sfruttamento minorile. Conoscere questa realtà mi ha fatto ancor più comprendere quanto io e le persone con cui quotidianamente vivo e lavoro, siamo fortunati ad essere nati nella parte ricca del mondo. E quanto potremmo fare, con un piccolo sforzo, per chi è nato in un paese povero come la Cambogia, dove lo stipendio medio è di $ 40 al mese.Per questo motivo ho deciso di contribuire, per quanto potrò, a rendere migliore la vita di questi bambini e a provare a dare loro minimo sostentamento, beni di prima necessità e la possibilità di studiare, giocare e crescere.“

 

PARTNER

Gruppo Umana Solidarietà - ONG che da molti anni si occupa di assistenza a migranti (in particolare con progetti SPRAR) ed opera nel sociale

No Walls Associazione di Promozione Sociale - Associazione che gestisce la scuola di lingua italiana del centro di accoglienza Corelli di Milano

Rivista El Ghibli - Rivista di Letteratura della Migrazione

Centro Ricerca Umorismo - Istituto per lo Studio e la Ricerca dell’Umorismo

LEAV -  Laboratorio di Etnomusicologia e Antropologia, Università Statale di Milano

Baobab Experience - Centro di Prima accoglienza informale a Roma

CONTATTI             ➽             ilsognodienea@gmail.com

Produzione:   Erasmus Theatre 

Direzione Artistica:   Matteo Andreone

Promozione Spettacolo:   Egle De Pascalis

Direttore Musicale:   Manu Pagliara

Attori:   Mohamed Ba, Samuel Hili

Regia e Fotografia:   Tommaso Vitali

Sound:   Marzia Dalfini

Montaggio:   Tommaso Vitali

Editore:   Carlo Amatetti

Comitato scientifico:   Salvatore Attardo, Delia Chiaro, Giovannantonio Forabosco,

Matias Hermosilla Gutierrez, Giacinto Palmieri, Raffaele Taddeo

Social Media:   Benny Palmieri

 

BIOGRAFIE

Matteo Andreone

Sono un’autore, regista e formatore teatrale. Da molti anni studio l’intelligenza umoristica e la applico come strumento per la formazione e lo sviluppo delle risorse umane, il benessere personale e relazionale e lo sviluppo della creatività d’impresa. Nel 2001 sono stato tra i fondatori dell’Accademia Nazionale del Comico, di cui ho ricoperto, fino al 2013, il ruolo di direttore didattico e docente di tecniche teatrali, meccanismi umoristici e drammaturgia comica. Dal 2005 progetto organizzo e gestisco, in Italia e all’estero, corsi e stage di humour business e intelligenza umoristica applicata al marketing, alla creatività e alla comunicazione efficace. Dal 2008 sono membro dell’International Society for Humor Studies (Oakland, California USA), per cui ho presentato ricerche e organizzato conferenze, seminari e workshop sul pensiero umoristico presso diverse università in Europa, Asia e Stati Uniti. Ho pubblicato nel 2012 Una Risata Vi Promuoverà (Rizzoli Etas, Milano), nel 2013 Lezioni di Comicità (Dino Audino, Roma) e nel 2014 l'adattamento italiano del manuale di scrittura comica Step by Step (Sagoma Editore, Milano) dell’autore americano Gene Perret.

Tommaso Vitali

Molti anni fa sono arrivato in Italia dal Perù, educandomi a una cultura italiana e europea con estrema attenzione, per poi decidere di formarmi artisticamente come regista, autore e montatore nella scena milanese del cinema indipendente. Dopo aver insegnato qualche anno regia e montaggio, sono stato co-fondatore nel 2006 del L.E.A.V., Laboratorio di Etnomusicologia ed Antropologia Visuale presso l’Università degli Studi di Milano (Dipartimento delle Arti e dello Spettacolo), dove ho prodotto e diretto numerosi lavori documentaristici e partecipato all’attività didattica. I miei lavori mi hanno condotto ad essere selezionato da Werner Herzog per la sua Rogue Film School nel 2011. Nel 2015 ho prodotto e diretto il documentario This Was Hasankeyf, che è stato selezionato in diversi festival internazionali, ha ottenuto numerosi riconoscimenti e, sopratutto, è riuscito sempre a stimolare le riflessioni del pubblico. Le mie principali aree di interesse, nel cinema e nel documentario, riguardano temi quali Identità, Diseguaglianza sociale, Post-colonialismo, Educazione, Genere, Oralità, Tradizioni e Ruralità.
