Si trattava di 142 bambini in gravi difficoltà economiche, senza genitori e, molti di loro, vittime di sfruttamento minorile. Conoscere questa realtà mi ha fatto ancor più comprendere quanto io e le persone con cui quotidianamente vivo e lavoro, siamo fortunati ad essere nati nella parte ricca del mondo. E quanto potremmo fare, con un piccolo sforzo, per chi è nato in un paese povero come la Cambogia, dove lo stipendio medio è di $ 40 al mese.Per questo motivo ho deciso di contribuire, per quanto potrò, a rendere migliore la vita di questi bambini e a provare a dare loro minimo sostentamento, beni di prima necessità e la possibilità di studiare, giocare e crescere.“ PARTNERGruppo Umana Solidarietà - ONG che da molti anni si occupa di assistenza a migranti (in particolare con progetti SPRAR) ed opera nel socialeNo Walls Associazione di Promozione Sociale - Associazione che gestisce la scuola di lingua italiana del centro di accoglienza Corelli di MilanoRivista El Ghibli - Rivista di Letteratura della MigrazioneCentro Ricerca Umorismo - Istituto per lo Studio e la Ricerca dell’UmorismoLEAV -  Laboratorio di Etnomusicologia e Antropologia, Università Statale di MilanoBaobab Experience - Centro di Prima accoglienza informale a RomaCONTATTI             ➽             ilsognodienea@gmail.comProduzione:   Erasmus Theatre Direzione Artistica:   Matteo AndreonePromozione Spettacolo:   Egle De PascalisDirettore Musicale:   Manu PagliaraAttori:   Mohamed Ba, Samuel HiliRegia e Fotografia:   Tommaso VitaliSound:   Marzia DalfiniMontaggio:   Tommaso VitaliEditore:   Carlo AmatettiComitato scientifico:   Salvatore Attardo, Delia Chiaro, Giovannantonio Forabosco,Matias Hermosilla Gutierrez, Giacinto Palmieri, Raffaele TaddeoSocial Media:   Benny Palmieri BIOGRAFIEMatteo AndreoneSono un’autore, regista e formatore teatrale. Da molti anni studio l’intelligenza umoristica e la applico come strumento per la formazione e lo sviluppo delle risorse umane, il benessere personale e relazionale e lo sviluppo della creatività d’impresa. Nel 2001 sono stato tra i fondatori dell’Accademia Nazionale del Comico, di cui ho ricoperto, fino al 2013, il ruolo di direttore didattico e docente di tecniche teatrali, meccanismi umoristici e drammaturgia comica. Dal 2005 progetto organizzo e gestisco, in Italia e all’estero, corsi e stage di humour business e intelligenza umoristica applicata al marketing, alla creatività e alla comunicazione efficace. Dal 2008 sono membro dell’International Society for Humor Studies (Oakland, California USA), per cui ho presentato ricerche e organizzato conferenze, seminari e workshop sul pensiero umoristico presso diverse università in Europa, Asia e Stati Uniti. Ho pubblicato nel 2012 Una Risata Vi Promuoverà (Rizzoli Etas, Milano), nel 2013 Lezioni di Comicità (Dino Audino, Roma) e nel 2014 l'adattamento italiano del manuale di scrittura comica Step by Step (Sagoma Editore, Milano) dell’autore americano Gene Perret.Tommaso VitaliMolti anni fa sono arrivato in Italia dal Perù, educandomi a una cultura italiana e europea con estrema attenzione, per poi decidere di formarmi artisticamente come regista, autore e montatore nella scena milanese del cinema indipendente. Dopo aver insegnato qualche anno regia e montaggio, sono stato co-fondatore nel 2006 del L.E.A.V., Laboratorio di Etnomusicologia ed Antropologia Visuale presso l’Università degli Studi di Milano (Dipartimento delle Arti e dello Spettacolo), dove ho prodotto e diretto numerosi lavori documentaristici e partecipato all’attività didattica. I miei lavori mi hanno condotto ad essere selezionato da Werner Herzog per la sua Rogue Film School nel 2011. Nel 2015 ho prodotto e diretto il documentario This Was Hasankeyf, che è stato selezionato in diversi festival internazionali, ha ottenuto numerosi riconoscimenti e, sopratutto, è riuscito sempre a stimolare le riflessioni del pubblico. Le mie principali aree di interesse, nel cinema e nel documentario, riguardano temi quali Identità, Diseguaglianza sociale, Post-colonialismo, Educazione, Genere, Oralità, Tradizioni e Ruralità.

story:
Short Summary

Salisbury Fringe was set up in 2013, its mission to support and encourage writers and showcase new plays, stories and monologues, whilst also making theatre more appealing to potential theatre-goers. We were delighted to welcome Christopher Biggins on board last year as our patron.

In the last three years we have hosted numerous events throughout the city including short play events in pubs and cafes, live radio plays, monologue readings in galleries and the Salisbury Museum, one-woman plays, comedy, music and numerous workshops. Our aim is to provide free and accessible theatre and entertainment whilst also supporting local businesses and helping Salisbury celebrate its diverse and talented arts community.

For this, our fourth festival, we have yet another eclectic programme of events including: a brand new 'battle of the monologues', a John Constable inspired monologues event in association with Salisbury Museum, a new children's writing workshop and reading, events charting the history of Salisbury, workshops and short plays.

What We Need & What You Get

The Salisbury Fringe team, led by chairman Julian Demetriadi and artistic director, Andrew Thackeray, work on a completely voluntary basis, with events generously supported by local businesses, sponsorship or voluntary contributions.

The arts face continual financial challenges, and to help us meet our mission of offering free theatre to the public we are launching a crowdfunding campaign to help us meet part of the expense incurred when putting on the festival. This includes payment to actors, lighting and sound equipment rental, and promotional and marketing expenses.

Our target goal of £1000 is a small part of our expenses. All funds received will go toward covering our costs and helping us to keep the fringe free for the public.

We are offering several perks for backers, from featuring them as supporters on our website and in our programme to welcoming them to our launch night as our special guest. You also get to play a part in what is fast becoming an important event on the Salisbury calendar, and help community arts in Salisbury, and the surrounding regions, continue to flourish.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to back us this time, we would still be delighted for you to be involved with Salisbury Fringe as a volunteer. If you are in the Salisbury region and would like to be involved over the weekend of 30th September - 2nd October please drop us a line through the contact section on our website www.salisburyfringe.co.uk and do please spread the word!

story:
Help fund ACT 1's upcoming production of LYSISTRATA!

I always had a vision of directing a show that was in the public domain funded entirely by the public! Become one of our producers! We all know that theatre is not an inexpensive endeavor, so we need your help to make this production a success! We have one week to raise $500 or more! I believe that through the power of the Nashville community, this will happen! Everyone who donates will be in our "Producer's Club." You will be listed in the LYSISTRATA program under the category in which you donate - Platinum Producer, Gold Producer, Silver Producer, or Bronze Producer! The money raised for this campaign will help to cover all costs of producing LYSISTRATA - set, costumes, props, programs, posters, etc. Your support will mean the world to me and to everyone involved with ACT 1.

This will be a completely new concept for LYSISTRATA! This production will be set in a modern-day woman's prison and deal with two separate wars - the battle inside the prison for the inmates rights and the battle outside the prison to end the civil war a lot of the men are fighting in.

The production runs March 4 through March 19 at The Darkhorse Theatre in Nashville.

THE CAST: Cat Arnold, Austin Olive, Terry Occhiogrosso, Christen Heilmen, Maggie Pitt, Michael James Thomas, Holly Butler, Eric Ventress, Steven Howie, Philip Boston, Sarah Shepherd, Cate Jo, & Megan Blevins.

Thank you!

Bradley Moore, Director

story:
Please join us

There will be five performances June 27-30 at The Alchemical 104 W 14th Street, NYC.

Keeping it simple

We are approaching Romeo & Juliet from a minimalist, actor as storyteller standpoint. The company is exploring themes of family, bondage, independence, idolatry, violence, fate and destruction in the wake of love incubated in a hostile environment. 

Here's much to do with hate but more with love. -Romeo

About the artists

The actors, director, and team for this project are theater artists currently based in New York with artists originally from Australia, South Africa, Israel, and the United States. All trained at New York University's various acting studios, and several studied abroad attending NYU Tisch's Shakespeare in Performance at the Royal Academy of Dramatic arts in London.

The Cast:

  • Sam Finn Cutler - as Mercutio/Montague/Samson etc.
  • Thomas Hedlund - as Romeo/Paris etc.
  • Felix Jones - as Capulet/Balthasar/Gregory
  • Omri Kadim - as Tybalt
  • Maggie MacMeans - as Lady Capulet/Abraham etc.
  • Julia Rehwald - as Juliet
  • Rebecca Thompson - as the nurse/Prince Escalus
  • Yannick Trapman-O'Brien - as Friar Laurence/Benvolio etc.

Direction by Inge Crafford-Lazarus

Fights by Omri Kadim

Clothing by Jake Schlossberg

Lighting by Kelley Shih

Stage Management: Philip Kenner

What We Need & What You Get

No contribution is too small!

Funds raised here will contribute to the following:

  • Performance space: $2400
  • Rehearsal in performance space: $400
  • Clothes: $400
  • Set: $170
  • Props: $130
  • Weaponry: $250
  • Programs and printing: $200
  • Crowdfunding: up to $256
  • Any amount raised in sundry of the above budget will go to the artists who are not receiving wages for their work on this production.

There are a number of lovely perks available:

  • Roses
  • Signed programs and/posters
  • Free tickets
  • Shakespeare's complete works
  • A night at the ballet

Please Share

If you are not able to contribute but would like to help us out by sharing this page with others, please do! We appreciate your support.

And please come see the play - tickets are available here: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/960276.

story:
English below

Aidez Les Productions Lounge à créer leur troisième comédie théâtrale: "Le Divan". 

Le Divan est une mosaïque de moments fugitifs et cocasses dans la vie d’un couple multiculturel typiquement montréalais. Lui est malchanceux, sensible et à l’imagination fertile; elle est curieuse, tanagra et féministe. La pièce donne à voir tant leurs différends que leurs réconciliations au travers de bref aperçus du quotidien de ces deux personnes perspicaces.

Mise en scène
Jonathan Marquis et Martin Mercier 

Interprétation
Alice Tran, Jonathan Marquis, Kristina Sandev et Vanessa Jolivette

Conception d'éclairage

Bruce Lambie

Conception sonore

Francesco Neri

Régie

Amélie Perron


Les Productions Lounge est un organisme à but non lucratif bilingue vouée à la création et à la production de nouveaux textes pour le théâtre et autres médias. Elle favorise la communication et les échanges entre les artistes des deux langues officielles, à l’image de la culture montréalaise. 

L'aide financière donnée nous permettra d'offrir une compensation monétaire aux acteurs, metteurs en scène et autres concepteurs professionnel. Elle nous aidera aussi à financer les publicités, les séances photos, les décors, les accessoires, la papeterie, et tous autres effets nécessaire à la production.

Les productions précédentes ont connues un succès critique auprès de centaines de spectateurs. 


La première création "X, Y & Zed" fut présentée au théâtre Rialto de Montréal en septembre 2011. Une histoire romantique entre un écrivain, Steve « Zed » Zedrick, obsédé de Woody Allen, et une scientifique, Alexandra Albright, qui fait 
une recherche sur les chromosomes et les différences entre les hommes et 
les femmes. Une comédie en quelques chicanes, avec quatre personnages 
interprétés par deux comédiens.

 "Cette pièce francophone originale est un parfait mélange entre "Du soleil plein la tête" de Michel Gondry et un film typique de Woody Allen." - David Adleman, The Concordian, 13 septembre 2011.


La seconde pièce "Le couple en trois étapes" a pris place au Centre culturel George-Vanier au mois d'août 2013. Cette histoire nous fait connaître Catherine, une féministe affirmée qui doit faire une présentation seulement  armée des notes de son prédécesseur et ancien amant. Ce n'est pas ce qu'elle aurait envisagé pour sa première journée. Néanmoins, avec l'aide de Steve et Tatiana, deux volontaires zélés et naïfs, elle nous expliquera les trois étapes du couple: La rencontre, le rendez-vous et s'en débarrasser!

"La pièce « Le Couple en trois étapes » est une rigolote farce estivale sans prétention qui prend la forme d'une conférence portant sur les étapes de vie du couple et sur les techniques de séduction." - Yves Rousseau, Le Quatrième, 15 août 2013.

Nous vous remercions de toute aide apportée à notre projet.

Merci d'encourager les artistes créateurs Montréalais.

Jonathan Marquis

Directeur Artistique

_______________________________________________________________________

Help The Lounge Productions put up their third play "The Sofa". "The Sofa" is a mosaic of fugitive and odd moments in the life of a typical Montreal couple. He is unlucky, sensitive and imaginative, and she is curious, tanagra and feminist. The play shows their differences and their reconciliations through brief glimpses of the lives of these two insightful people.

Directed by

Jonathan Marquis and Martin Mercier

With

Alice Tran, Jonathan Marquis, Kristina Sandev and Vanessa Jolivette

Light design

Bruce Lambie

Sound design

Francesco Neri

Stage management

Amélie Perron

               

The Lounge Productions is a bilingual nonprofit organization dedicated to creating and producing new texts for the theater and other media. It promotes communication and exchange between artists of both official languages ​​in the image of Montreal's culture.

The financial assistance given will enable us to provide monetary compensation to our cast, crew and other creative members of the production. As well as to allow us to afford the set, costumes, props and many other things needed in order to put this production up.

Previous productions have experienced critical success with hundreds of audiences. 


The first creation "X, Y & Zed" was presented in September 2011 at the Rialto Theatre, Montreal. A romantic story between a writer, Steve "Zed" Zedrick obsessed Woody Allen, and a scientist, Alexandra Albright, who researches chromosomes and the differences between male and female. A comedy in a few quarrels, four characters played by two actors.

 "This original, lively play is a French-language mixture of Michel Gondry.s Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind and a typical Allen movie." - David Adleman, The Concordian, 13 septembre 2011.


The second creation "The couple in three parts" took place at the George-Vanier Cultural Centre in August 2013.
This story introduces us to Catherine, an assertive feminist, who must do a presentation only armed with her predecessor and former lover's notes. This is not what she had in mind for her first day. Nevertheless, with the help of Steve and Tatiana, two zealous and naïve volunteers, she will explain the three parts of the couple: The meeting, the date and getting rid of them!

"The play "The Couple in three parts" is a funny unpretentious summer farce that takes the form of a conference on the steps of married life and the seduction techniques." - Yves Rousseau, Le Quatrième, 15 août 2013.

Thank you for all the help given to this project

Thanks for supporting the Montreal theatre scene.

Jonathan Marquis

Artistic Director

As well as to allow us to afford the set, costumes, props and many other things needed in order to put this production up.Previous productions have experienced critical success with hundreds of audiences. The first creation "X, Y & Zed" was presented in September 2011 at the Rialto Theatre, Montreal. A romantic story between a writer, Steve "Zed" Zedrick obsessed Woody Allen, and a scientist, Alexandra Albright, who researches chromosomes and the differences between male and female. story:
My name is Bianca Moore. I was born in Taylor, Mi at Wyanndotte Hospital on Februrary 23, 1999. From the time I began elementary until the 4th grade I lived in Taylor and went to Blair Moody Elementary. When I was 6 years old, my father moved to Atlanta, Georgia. By the time I was 9, my family lost our house. Between my 4th and 5th grade years, our family moved from hotel to motel, and eventually ended up having no where to stay at all. We moved in with my aunt, she helped us get back on our feet and we ended up getting an apartment in Ypsilanti, MI. We lived in these apartments for a year or two, then my mom lost her job at Pfizer. We moved in with her boyfriend who lived upstairs at the moment, but he soon passed away from alcohol poisioning. We eventually were evicted and began to travel from hotel to hotel once again. When I was 14 we moved into a shelter called the Alpha House. The Alpha House helped us so much, If it wasn't for them we wouldn't have the apartment we have now in Hamilton crossings. Alpha House helped my mom get a job a Meijer which she eventually lost. My mothers signifigant other just passed away a few days ago from the same alcohol poisioning problem. He sort of helped with finances but now we have no income whatsoever.  My dad usually helps me when I need things but his health hasn't been to well lately and he's not able to work. I haven't gotten new clothes for the last two years and I dont necessarily plan on getting any anytime soon. I'm used to it so it doesn't really bother me anymore, I just try and look my best with what I have.


I am now in need of funds for this years homecoming at Huron High school. I wasn't able to go to homecoming freshmen year and now that I know more people, I really want to go. My father just introduced me to this website and we both figured that this would be a great help. Homecoming is all I have been thinking of lately. It would be a chance for me to show people how well I clean up and I would love to see the look on everyones faces if that would be possible. It would be the best feeling in the world. If you or someone else could help me It would be a great help. Raising money for someone to go to homecoming sounds really selfish and I do understand that but its more to it than just having a chance to be at homecoming. It's a chance to gain respect and show others who I really am and what I can really look like. Thank you so much.
story_txt:
My name is Bianca Moore. I was born in Taylor, Mi at Wyanndotte Hospital on Februrary 23, 1999. From the time I began elementary until the 4th grade I lived in Taylor and went to Blair Moody Elementary. When I was 6 years old, my father moved to Atlanta, Georgia. By the time I was 9, my family lost our house. Between my 4th and 5th grade years, our family moved from hotel to motel, and eventually ended up having no where to stay at all. We moved in with my aunt, she helped us get back on our feet and we ended up getting an apartment in Ypsilanti, MI. We lived in these apartments for a year or two, then my mom lost her job at Pfizer. We moved in with her boyfriend who lived upstairs at the moment, but he soon passed away from alcohol poisioning. We eventually were evicted and began to travel from hotel to hotel once again. When I was 14 we moved into a shelter called the Alpha House. The Alpha House helped us so much, If it wasn't for them we wouldn't have the apartment we have now in Hamilton crossings. Alpha House helped my mom get a job a Meijer which she eventually lost. My mothers signifigant other just passed away a few days ago from the same alcohol poisioning problem. He sort of helped with finances but now we have no income whatsoever.  My dad usually helps me when I need things but his health hasn't been to well lately and he's not able to work. I haven't gotten new clothes for the last two years and I dont necessarily plan on getting any anytime soon. I'm used to it so it doesn't really bother me anymore, I just try and look my best with what I have.   
I am now in need of funds for this years homecoming at Huron High school. I wasn't able to go to homecoming freshmen year and now that I know more people, I really want to go. My father just introduced me to this website and we both figured that this would be a great help. Homecoming is all I have been thinking of lately. It would be a chance for me to show people how well I clean up and I would love to see the look on everyones faces if that would be possible. It would be the best feeling in the world. If you or someone else could help me It would be a great help. Raising money for someone to go to homecoming sounds really selfish and I do understand that but its more to it than just having a chance to be at homecoming. It's a chance to gain respect and show others who I really am and what I can really look like. Thank you so much.

story:
Dance Alive National Ballet is a radiant jewel of a company.

Featuring an international roster of technically brilliant and entertaining dancers in an array of choreography that uplifts and astounds its audiences, the Company brings to the stage truly riveting dance.

Hailing from Russia to Hong Kong to Brazil, these exceptional dancers, many of whom have won international competitions, leap and spin into their audiences hearts. Standing ovations are the norm. Unique in the international touring community, it is that rare classical ballet troupe that is small enough to fit most stages and budgets. As a result Dance Alive National Ballet has an astounding rate of return engagements. 

Dance Alive National Ballet’s repertoire ranges from the quintessential classics such as the bravura pas de deux from ‘Don Quixote’ to the great George Balanchine’s neo-classical masterpiece ‘Apollo’ to the other end of the dance spectrum with Cirque du Soleil’s Rick Tjia’s contemporary look at the complex relationship between horse and master in his electrifying ‘Aeia Bridled’. Throughout this choreographic tapestry are woven the ballets of Artistic Director Kim Tuttle and Choreographer-in-residence Judy Skinner, masters of their art who particularly enjoy creating original ballets on the dancers.

Led by Executive Artistic Director, Kim Tuttle, highly respected choreographer, the company vision is clear and vital. Ms. Tuttle was formerly on the staff of the Stuttgart Ballet and Ballet Master of the Zurich Ballet before taking the reins of Dance Alive National Ballet as its Artistic Director in 1986 and bringing it to its position of national prominence.  During her tenure, Dance Alive National Ballet has toured 17 states, Costa Rica, Brazil  and Russia under the auspices of the National Endowment for the Arts, South Arts, Allied Concert Services, the Florida Department of State, and Siegel Artist Management. The company has the sole distinction of being named the State Touring Company of Florida since 1976. Their long-time touring experience insures an efficient and professional theatre experience for their sponsors.

Joining her as choreographer-in-residence is Judy Skinner, a gifted and prolific choreographer who is also the Director of Grants and Arts Education for the company.  Ms. Skinner is indisputably part of the team that creates the company style and general direction. Dance Alive National Ballet has a strong educational  component, directed by Judy Skinner.  The company, committed to spreading the word, offers dance through school performances, residencies and lecture-demonstrations with first-rate programming and curriculum materials.

The 13 dancers of Dance Alive National Ballet have a non-stop energy and love for dance that is at the source of the company’s undeniable success.  Elegant, exciting, dramatic, virtuosic, and reveling in the pure beauty of their art, they ARE dance.  Whether performing in the spectacular CARMINA BURANA, the family favorite THE NUTCRACKER, the children’s ballet, LADY BUG: ACTION HERO or the magnificent PHANTOM, they are 100% committed to bringing the best they, and dance, have to offer. Along with a committed staff and Board of Trustees, the future of Dance Alive National Ballet is bright and secure.  Dance Alive National Ballet is based in Gainesville, FL., home of the University of Florida.

“….admire the exquisite combination of techniques…the tradition of the Bolshoi, the spirit of jazz and the sensuality of modern dance in a first class spectacle”                               La Nacion, Costa Rica

COMPANY HIGHLIGHTS

  •  Dance Alive National Ballet has toured 17 states and Costa Rica under the auspices of the National Endowment for the Arts, SouthArts, Siegel Artist Management, Allied Concert Services and the State of Florida.
  • Dance Alive National Ballet has been on State Touring Program of Florida since 1976, receiving the highest score in recent panel hearings and selected through 2014.
  • DANB offers a 4 production season in its home venue, the Curtis M. Phillips Center for the Performing Arts in Gainesville, Florida.
  • DANB spent a week (April 2012) in North Ossetia, Russia performing at the request of that country.
  • DANB performed at a Gala Command Performance for HSH Prince Albert II of Monaco March, 5, 2011 in Ft. Myers, Florida at the request of HSH Prince Albert.
  • The Company was honored Company and featured at the International Ballet Festival of the Amazon in Belem, Brazil in September 2012.
  • The company is comprised of 13 contracted full-time professional dancers from all over the world, many of whom have won international competitions.
  • DANB was invited by the Broward County School System to perform Lady Bug:Action Hero at the Broward Center for the Performing Arts celebrating the 10th anniversary of its SEAS program.
  • DANB has expanded its local Florida base of operation to include Alachua County, Marion County, Columbia County and Lake County and has formed a partnership with The Villages in Lady Lake, FL. for summer residencies,  general programming, and master classes, reaching over 300,000.
  • DANB has a strong educational program with performances and residencies both within the community and throughout the Southeast.
  • The company serves the local community through children’s programming and reduced and/or free admission to  underprivileged and handicapped adults, seniors and children.

story:
White Elephant

Founded in 2011, WE are setting out to create our most large scale project yet. And we need YOUR help. For more on our story, click here.

WE know our next project will be:

*Original (world debut!)

*Collaborative (created with the help of many individuals and organizations, both arts- and non-arts identified)

*Uncaged (next Fall you may join us in a lush park, a decaying factory, a shiny shopping mall, a dusty basement…just not a theater)

Investing in WE is unique because...

*WE do not know what it will be about

*WE do not know where it will take place

*WE do not know who we will work with

Not knowing all of these things (yet!) is crucial to fulfilling our mission of pulling theatre out of its cage, unleashing the liveness, and re-harnessing it for the environment of now.

If you think this is as exciting as WE do, please donate to support:

 *6 months of regular developmental workshops (office supplies, artistic materials, storage fees, space fees)

........This will allow us to create the content of our project next Fall

 

*2 public workshop events (venue rental, production costs)

........This will allow the public to see previews of what we are working on and to participate themselves in our creative process

 

*Partnership search (business cards, web and graphic design)

........This will allow us to communicate with arts and non-arts partners, and eventually secure collaborations that will be integral to our next project.  Examples include performance sites, community access, audience development, content from across disciplines

 

Other Ways You Can Help

...Goods! (clothing, odds n' ends, office supplies)

...Services! (printing, marketing)

...Space! (rehearsal, performance, storage)

...Spread the word!

story:
We are going to LA to show some work we are really excited about.  We could really use your help to gather the resources to get there.  We need per diem for the awesome dancers, Mara Poliak and Ethan Cowan, gas money and rental car money (LA!)  and money for rehearsal space.  Your help would be great as we take this next step in GETTING THE WORK OUT THERE!

Thanks so much!

story:
WHO ARE WE?

Theatre Conspiracy taps the crosscurrents of international culture, society and politics to create, interpret, translate and curate theatre shows that speak beyond borders. The Vancouver-based professional arts organization was incorporated in 1995.  conspiracy.ca


WHAT IS EXTRACTION?   榨

A bilingual (English and Mandarin) documentary theatre show based on the experiences of non-actor performers from Beijing, Vancouver and Fort McMurray. Their stories — of the transitions from their native countries to new lives in foreign lands —intimately illuminate the highly charged political debates about tar sands development, Chinese investment in Fort McMurray, pipeline construction and Canada’s relationship with China. The play delves deeply into matters of translation, cultural nuance and the immigrant/expat experience.

Extraction is about real people. The performers play themselves: A former Canadian diplomat and journalist who spent the most of the past 20 years in China; a freelance interpreter from Beijing who has worked for James Cameron and Tony Blair, a recent Chinese immigrant trying to make a new life in Vancouver, and a worker from the Fort McMurray industry.

Extraction is participatory.  Conspiracy artistic producer Tim Carlson and director Amiel Gladstone worked with the innovative Rimini Protokoll on the acclaimed documentary theatre show 100% Vancouver (PuSh International Performing Arts Festival, 2011), which brought 100 Vancouverites together to tell the story of their city. Carlson also worked with Rimini Protokoll, which has produced work around the world, on Best Before, in which the audience used game consoles to shape a show that also featured real people telling their own stories. Best Before began in Vancouver and enjoyed 14 international engagements.

Extraction will draw on those innovations to explore globally important industrial development and the effects on people's lives.

“What a wonderful experiment. Thank you for taking on such a huge story, a down-home story right from our own backyard.” – Carey, Richmond


WHY FUND IT? WHAT YOU GET

After visits to China and Fort McMurray and a year of refining the concept for the show, we developed and rehearsed Extraction in July 2012 and presented a work-in-progress performance on July 21 at Your Kontinent: Richmond International Film & Media Arts Festival to great reviews. The premiere of Extraction is March 5-9, 2013 at the Vancouver East Cultural Centre in Vancouver, BC.

Your contribution towards Extraction will help Theatre Conspiracy bring together an international cast again, create a production that will shine at its March 2013 premiere and lead to an international tour that will put Vancouver theatre squarely on the international stage.

As a thank-you for your help, we have come up with some great perks. See the goods to the right.

Note that your contribution is tax deductible. Payment is through PayPal but you don't need to have an account to contribute. Simply log in as a guest; it's easy!

About Perk #5: Secret Spaces events are cocktail parties and intimate dinners in historically important buildings and inspiringly offbeat locations.  See our website (conspiracy.ca) for more details.

 

COMMUNITY IMPACT

Vancouver theatre does not adequately connect with the city’s vast array of cultures.  Extraction speaks to the contemporary experiences and interests of the Mandarin-speaking community through a bilingual show with live translation. The show will also engage petroleum companies and workers, academics, NGOs, artists and environmentalists interested in China, the tar sands and documentary theatre. 


What we bring to the project

Conspiracy works to create global connections for Vancouver theatre. Macbeth: nach Shakespeare (2011) was the official English premiere of a work by German theatre legend Heiner Müller. Live from a Bush of Ghosts (2009) took inspiration from a famed African novel and groundbreaking American musicians to create dance theatre that explored how the West exports its nightmares to the Third World. With Extraction, we continue to test the artistic boundaries between forms and countries.

Extraction is supported by the Canada Council, the B.C. Arts Council, the Province of B.C., the City of Vancouver Cultural Affairs, the Vancouver Foundation, the Leon & Thea Koerner Foundation and the Hamber Foundation. Theatre Conspiracy was honoured with the prestigious Rio Tinto Alcan Performing Arts Award to help develop and produce Extraction.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Make a donation, but please also spread the word about Extraction.  Promote it on facebook, twitter, email, and blogs...  See the helpful tools below.

Thanks. 谢谢

story:
Help us bring Gatsby to the Arts Theatre! 

We just need a little bit of help to raise funds to put costumes on our lovely actors, finish building the set, and pay for the hire of radio microphones and sound system. 

About the play: 

Ruby In The Dust's acclaimed adaptation of F Scott Fitzgerald's iconic Jazz Age novel returns to the London stage for a limited, exclusive showcase production at the Arts Theatre. Featuring the renowned Benoit Veillefon Orchestra, the on-stage talent includes Kim Medcalf, Matilda Sturridge, Ellie Nunn and Sebastian Blunt. FULL CAST LISTED BELOW  

Inhabiting the sizzling heat of a 1920s New York Summer, Jay Gatsby is the man who has almost everything. But one thing will always be out of his reach... Beneath the shimmering surface of his life he is hiding a secret: a silent longing that can never be fulfilled. Soon this destructive obsession will force his world to unravel. This is a portrait of a man who lives his life with all the heady, glitz and glamour of his age, a man whose name has become synonymous with an era, a man who beneath the veneer hides the seeds of self- destruction that, like the Big Crash that hung on the horizon, has come to symbolise the end of the American Dream.

When it will run:

Performances: 26th October to 16th November 2015 
Time(s): Mondays at 7.30pm 

More info:

http://artstheatrewestend.co.uk/whats-on/gatsby/

http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/lat...

http://www.broadwayworld.com/uk-regional/articl...

FULL CAST (in alphabetical order)

Simon Bailey (a West End regular, from 'Phantom of the Opera'. Les Miserables') plays Tom Buchanan

Sebastian Blunt, who featured in the Tom Cruise Sci-fi film 'Edge of Tomorrow' and made his West End debut in 'Stop Kiss' at the Leicester Square Theatre plays 'Nick Carraway'

Scheherazade Brathwaite is 'Lucille'

Maria Coyne, currently in Sondheim's "A Little Night Music" and who has just finished playing Glinda in "Wicked" is 'Catherine'

Kim Medcalf (Sally Bowles in Rufus Norris' West End "Cabaret", and Sam Mitchell from "Eastenders") plays the tragic 'Myrtle Wilson'

Ellie Nunn (from the West End's "Shakespeare in Love") plays 'Jordan Baker'

Nick Pack plays 'Owl Eyes', 'The Reporter' and 'Henri'

David Ricardo Pearce is GATSBY                                                                                           David wowed audiences and critics with his portrayal of the eponymous lead role in the stage adaptation of "Alfie"

James Lloyd Pegg plays 'Meyer Wolfsheim'

Christopher Staines (from TV's "Wolf Hall") plays 'George Wilson'

Matilda Sturridge is back as 'Daisy'

story:
My name is Naomi Flanders and I founded Echo Valley Community Arts in 2004 (a Vermont state non-profit) to bring local Vermont artists, of all art disciplines, together to produce classical theater pieces and new theater works to the stage. 


 To date we have produced five operas("Cosi Fan Tutte will be our sixth), five of Shakespeare's plays, eight Operafests, four G&S operettas, premiered two new plays, have had a traditional reading of "A Child's Christmas in Wales" for four seasons, and have successfully developed and run eight summers of Shakespeare camps for kids.We are currently raising money to help fund the salaries of our singers and crew  for "Cosi Fan Tutte" which is where all your contributions will go regardless of whether or not we reach our goal.

Your financial contribution goes directly to our fiscal sponsor (a 501c3 non-profit) The Center for Arts and Learning in beautiful downtown Montpelier, Vermont. By contributing to us, you will be also contributing to them.

 Please continue to support Echo Valley Community Arts by contributing to our recent project "Cosi Fan Tutte!"

****

NEW VIDEO: NICHOLAS HECHT and his set in progress for Cosi Fan Tutte by D Kaganova 

On Wednesday, Nicholas Hecht invited me to see his stage set in progress for Naomi A. Flanders upcoming production of Mozart's Cosi Fan Tutte so we could compare notes on sets and costumes (one of my gigs on the project),
Naomi is setting the opera in 1969, somewhere on the ocean near Boston; there's a war on and young men are being drafted. Two guys, two girls, a scheming professor and a clever housemaid combine for a hilarious and gorgeous romp through concealed identities, naughty wagers, shocking discoveries and love a la Woodstock in Mozart's funniest work ever.
Nicholas was composing a tune on his accordion in front of the set and I shot this video to capture the moment. Enjoy.

 

 

 

PERKS GALORE

Our friends in Montpelier have offered wonderful gifts for contributors to "Cosi Fan Tutte".

$25 donor receives a mounted copy of the Cosi Fan Tutte 

$50 donor...  1 pint of gelato or sorbet at Chill Vermont Gelato. Get your fav flavorite today.

 

$100... A luxurious gift bag from Splash. 5 available.

 

$200...Unique sculpture of the infamous Beanie the Dog by David Klein

$300 donation...Vintage etching of Mozart courtesy of Juliana and Simon at J. Langdon

$300 donation... Vintage opera glasses from Juliana and Simon of J. Langdon

$400 donation... "Color Study" original watercolor by Alana LaPointe

$500 donation... Self Portrait woodblock print from "15 Woodcuts" by Leonard Baskin

$1000 donation... 4' X 3' mounted photo from series "Creative Explosion" by Diane Kaganova

 

WATCH FOR NEW PERKS EVERY DAY!

SEE YOU AT THE SHOW!

story:
We want to bring this movie to you and zombie lovers everywhere in the world at the same time! And that is why we have chosen crowd funding.  We believe a film needs to be available to you – the audience – who decides when, where and how to view. That’s the reason we need your support.  Help us raise the money for the E-19 virus movie, the next best zombie movie and be a part of history

The whole production budget E-19 is  $75,000. From that we have secured $145,000 and $5,000 through an outside investor. Josh Pickel will star in the film

We need to raise $50,000 through crowd funding. Any contributions above and beyond our goal will be used in better makeup fx, visual fx, and of coarse CGI fx. We are putting every dime we have and that we raise into the film to produce the best product possible.

$50,000 isn't much to start a feature film, but it will pay for the broad strokes and many of the big ticket items we need like equipment rentals, locations, make up, food, labor costs, lumber for sets, some fees for zombie extras, and costumes. The rest we are getting donated in either free services or reduced rental contracts.

So, what we have here is a commando style production team of versatile film professionals working on a stellar movie concept with the best possible cinematic equipment at terrific locations with an extremely talented cast and production team. The movie is directed by award winning director Joe Ciminera

From it's inception, the movie was designed with the budget in mind. Since we are using one  location (CT) as our main location, we have very few company moves. That saves time and money. The interior sets will be constructed in a warehouse at another location where we can work more quickly  with controlled lights and moveable walls.

story:
DEAR MOMMA: A LOVE LETTER

Long-time collaborators Avital Shira (director), Megan Sweigert (playwright), and Max Maller and Amir Shirazi (producers) are teaming together again to bring to life a fresh and unique coming-of-age play that deals with exciting and challenging themes in tandem: identity, spirituality, and sexuality.

DEAR MOMMA: A LOVE LETTER is a one-act, ensemble narrative play (based on the playwright's life) that tells the story of a girl that was born in a cult, raised by her mother, and forced to put the pieces of her life together on her own. You've got to look into where you came from to find out where you're going...


We need more than pen and paper to tell this story...

Alright, folks. We've got this play that we're really excited about, and we can't wait to bring it to the stage in its presentation at Fertile Ground this January 30-February 8 at the Alberta Little Church. (Full details on performances below.) But we truly need your help to get us there. We need to raise $2,500 to get this show on its feet.

And that's where we hope that you'll join us! We can't do this alone, and pen and paper will only get us so far in get this play on its feet. Anything that you are able to contribute to this play will go directly towards performance space costs, costumes, props, printing costs, and most importantly and primarily towards honoring the time and talents of our team of artists.

And to show our appreciation for any contribution that you might be able to make, we've got some really cool rewards. Check them out!


Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that not everyone is able to make a financial contribution at this time, and we fully respect that. (Trust us, we get it... that’s why we have this campaign!) However, there are SO MANY other ways (and just as meaningful  to help make DEAR MOMMA a reality:

  • Donate your Facebook status, using the Indiegogo share tools at the top of the page!
  • Share our fundraising video on Twitter, Facebook, etc!
  • Send personal email appeals to your friends, family, and anyone else you might know who you think could be interested in supporting the arts!
  • Drop postcards at your local coffeeshops, gyms, and bookstores!
  • JOIN US January 30-February 8 to experience and engage with this awesome play

DEAR MOMMA: A LOVE LETTER
When: Jan 30 and 31, Feb 1, 6, 7, 8 
Time: 8:30 pm (runs approx 45 minutes)
Where: The Little Church
Address: 5138 NE 23rd Ave Portland OR, 97211
Tickets: $8, or $15 if seen with REVIVAL

Get your tickets HERE!

We are so deeply grateful for the generosity of our community in supporting our projects in the past and are so very excited to bring DEAR MOMMA: A LOVE LETTER to life, with your help.

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact the producer Amir Shirazi at amirbshirazi@gmail.com.

Deepest Gratitude,

"The Letter Writers" (Avital, Megan, Max, and Amir)

story:
Why We Are Fundraising

The desire to make a difference, to give back, to inspire; this is what brought our founders to form Fearless Young Artists. The goal of the organization is to put the needs of students first and prepare them without fail to be contributors: to the arts, to their community, and to society as a whole. And we need your help. Fearless Young Artists is a Texas non-profit corporation with tax exempt status pending. Your donation will help us continue to nurture a new generation of curious, engaged, and confident artists by providing access to our vibrant theatrical training and supporting the mentorship of talented students, especially those who would not otherwise be able to afford it. Funds raised go towards scholarships and operating costs for Fearless Young Artists.


About our Artistic Director

LaQuet Sharnell Pringle is a Dallas native and an alumni of the Arts Magnet HSPVA. At the school, she had intense training in ballet, modern, African, and compositional. While in HS she received numerous awards from NYC Dance Alliance, Company Dance, Jacobs Pillow, Broadway Theatre Project, and the National Foundation for the Arts. Upon graduation from the Arts HS she trained at the NC School of the Arts as a contemporary dance major. Broadway/National Tour: Lysistrata Jones, Memphis The Musical, The Lion King and Sweet Charity. Off Broadway: Make Mine Manhattan, Ave Q. Regional: Candide (NYC Opera), The Wiz, Ain’t Misbehavin, Princess-A New Musical, Chicago, Footloose, AIDA, Nights on Broadway III, Shrek The Musical, Jawbreaker The Musical and Caty Bridgewater A Musical. Television/Film: As the World Turns, Step Up 3D.

story:
FINDING GAVIN: UNEXPECTED SURVIVAL LESSONS:

This incredibly powerful, funny and poignant one-woman show by Margret Echeverria is about love, family, friendship, grief, and finding joy when it seems to have disappeared.

Gavin Xavier Expedite Cimorelli was born on November 3, 2011. 51 days later, he was lost to SIDS. "Finding Gavin: Unexpected Survival Lessons" tells the story of his family - how his mom and dad, Margret and Bobby (as well as his sister Aly), met, fell in love, welcomed him into the world, and survived losing him far too soon. 

"People who are going through this have a feeling, fundamentally in their bones, that they cannot survive this. And they can survive this, and not just survive it, but find laughter again... Bobby and I will never get over this, but we've survived and continue to survive because we broke some of the rules."

          -Margret Echeverria


WHAT IS SIDS?

Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) and Sudden Unexpected Infant Death (SUID) are the third leading cause of infant mortality in the United States and the leading cause of death among infants aged 1–12 months - approximately 4000 per year. It's a frightening prospect because it can strike without warning, usually in seemingly healthy babies. And we still don’t know exactly what causes SIDS or SUID at this time. 


WHY IS THIS SHOW IMPORTANT?

"SIDS is not talked about and it's time we talk about it and heal from it." 

         - Margret Echeverria

Margret is stepping out to let people know they are not alone, nothing they are going through is unsurvivable, and no matter how bleak it seems, there is light, there is laughter, and there is love. Margret and Bobby's story, sadly, is not unique. And it is because of that that people need to hear it. 

"The most valuable experiences we had as we moved through our grief and our loss were when others came to us and shared their loss and how they learned to live with it... It was such a blessing and a really extraordinary and healing thing... So if this show can be that vehicle to let others know that we're still here - that we found joy again after experiencing this loss - then that will make this show worthwhile."

         - Margret Echeverria

"One of the most important aspects, to us, when we set out to create this show, was that we did not want it to become a "How To Guide" for grief. It is the experience of one family.  Margret, Bobby and Aly  have been able to find a way to feel joy and love again because they gave themselves the freedom to grieve in their own way - sometimes that meant saying the things people told them not to and doing things that just felt right for them. Our goal for this show is that it gives others the encouragement to find that freedom to grieve however they need to."

          - Danny Ward


PUBLIC FEEDBACK:

On August 28, 2014, at The Cornelia Street Cafe in New York City, Margret performed a very early staged reading of "FINDING GAVIN: UNEXPECTED SURVIVAL LESSONS" to an audience of nearly 60.  We were blown away by the response. 

  - "An evening of raw honesty shared with gentle humor. A beautiful evening."

          - Corinna Makris

  - "Funny and heartbreaking. Margret takes us on a personal journey that is as raw as it is hilarious."

           - Tommy Minnix (producer of the award winning short film "Jigsaw Venus")

 "Margret allows herself to be vulnerable, she intelligently discusses meaningful events in her life, she pulls on your heartstrings, and makes you laugh as well. She connects."

          - Debra Green


WHEN WILL THE SHOW OPEN?

"FINDING GAVIN: UNEXPECTED SURVIVAL LESSONS", with your help, will premiere in New York City on Friday, April 17, 2015. We are planning a 3 day, 5 show run initially with hopes to extend the run.


WHAT WILL YOUR CONTRIBUTION BE USED FOR?

   • Rehearsal Space: Usually $10-13/hour, we will need at least 20 hours of rehearsal in a rehearsal space.  

  •  Props and Wardrobe: While we will be using mostly items we have, there are a few specific necessities we will have to rent and/or purchase. Total: $125

  •  Venue:  Most theaters in New York require that you rent the theater space for the performances. This is the bulk of the cost, as reputable theaters charge close to and more than $1000/day. 

  •  Marketing: Our website design and graphic design have been graciously donated by a friend. We will, however, have to have posters printed, flyers made, and programs produced. 

  •  Crew: We will need to hire a lighting and sound manager for the run of the show, and while Margret and Danny are more than willing to do this show for free, most quality technicians are not. 


WHO ARE MARGRET AND DANNY?

Margret Echeverria: Writer and Performer

Hailing from Cedar Falls, Iowa, Margret came to New York City in 1994.  She soon joined the award winning Newmyn’s Nose Limitless Theatre Limited, where she was introduced to New York’s experimental theatre scene.  Since, she starred in the critically-acclaimed, award-winning short film "JIGSAW VENUS" by Dean Kapsalis. She played the adorable “Fag Hag,” Audrey, in both films by Casper Andreas and Jesse Archer: "A FOUR LETTER WORD" and "VIOLET TENDENCIES" (a film loosely based on Margret’s own life).  She was cast along side P. Diddy as the Tough Nurse, not to be trifled with, in his show "MAKING THE BAND." And in 2005, she made her mark as a solo-performer with her first one-woman show "ORANGERIE" (an exploration of finding love in non-traditional ways), which premiered and held a six-month run at New York’s Bowery Poetry Club. 

Margret has been seen on stage and screen (both large and small) for nearly two decades now and is just getting started. She is incredibly excited to share “FINDING GAVIN: UNEXPECTED SURVIVAL LESSONS” with the world, as she feels it’s a show that “not only deserves to be seen, it needs to be seen.”

http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0248436/


Danny Ward: Director

A film, theater, and television writer and director, Danny has been one of Margret's closest friends for years. He directed her first one-woman show, "ORANGERIE" and has been Margret's partner on "FINDING GAVIN: UNEXPECTED SURVIVAL LESSONS" since she first started writing it two years ago. 

He is currently in production on a feature film, "CLEVELAND." www.clevelandthemovie.com. And last year released the pilot episode of his online sitcom "HIGHLIGHTERS" at www.highlighterstheseries.com

"I feel incredibly lucky and honored to be directing this show. It's so honest, so raw, so real, and yet funny. It's an amazing piece. And Margret is an amazing solo-performer. She has a way of bringing the audience in and making them a part of her performance. It's an incredible talent."

http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1792112/


HOW CAN YOU FIND OUT MORE ABOUT SIDS?

  •  http://www.cdc.gov/sids/

  •  http://kidshealth.org/parent/general/sleep/sids.html

  •  http://dhhs.ne.gov/publichealth/Pages/sids_facts.aspx

  •  http://sids.org


HOW CAN I HELP THE SHOW IF I CAN'T CONTRIBUTE FINANCIALLY?

Please, SHARE THIS PAGE! 

You can also find us on FACEBOOK: www.facebook.com/findinggavin. Like our page, share it with your friends and encourage them to Like us. 

If you have any contacts or people who might be interested in the show or interested in helping, please get us in touch. We are looking at a number of different theater spaces but have not yet made our final decision; we need crew; we need props; we will need stage hands on the nights of shows; and we NEED people to help us spread the word. 



Thank you so much for your support, your contributions, you support, and just for reading this far.  See you in April!

which premiered and held a six-month run at New York’s Bowery Poetry Club. Margret has been seen on stage and screen (both large
and small) for nearly two decades now and is just getting started. She is
incredibly excited to share “FINDING GAVIN: UNEXPECTED SURVIVAL LESSONS” with
the world, as she feels it’s a show that “not only deserves to be seen, it needs to be seen.”
http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0248436/Danny Ward: DirectorA film, theater, and television writer and director, Danny has been one of Margret's closest friends for years. He directed her first one-woman show, "ORANGERIE" and has been Margret's partner on "FINDING GAVIN: UNEXPECTED SURVIVAL LESSONS" since she first started writing it two years ago. He is currently in production on a feature film, "CLEVELAND." www.clevelandthemovie.com. And last year released the pilot episode of his online sitcom "HIGHLIGHTERS" at www.highlighterstheseries.com"I feel incredibly lucky and honored to be directing this show. It's so honest, so raw, so real, and yet funny. It's an amazing piece. And Margret is an amazing solo-performer. She has a way of bringing the audience in and making them a part of her performance. It's an incredible talent."http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1792112/HOW CAN YOU FIND OUT MORE ABOUT SIDS?  •  http://www.cdc.gov/sids/  •  http://kidshealth.org/parent/general/sleep/sids.html  •  http://dhhs.ne.gov/publichealth/Pages/sids_facts.aspx  •  http://sids.orgHOW CAN I HELP THE SHOW IF I CAN'T CONTRIBUTE FINANCIALLY?Please, SHARE THIS PAGE! You can also find us on FACEBOOK: www.facebook.com/findinggavin. Like our page, share it with your friends and encourage them to Like us. If you have any contacts or people who might be interested in the show or interested in helping, please get us in touch. We are looking at a number of different theater spaces but have not yet made our final decision; we need crew; we need props; we will need stage hands on the nights of shows; and we NEED people to help us spread the word. Thank you so much for your support, your contributions, you support, and just for reading this far.  See you in April!

story:
Hello! We are Children and Adults Theatrical Studios, a community theater based in Lubbock, Tx. For the past 20 years, we have been reaching out to children, teenagers, and adults in the area, providing a space for them to enjoy both watching and participating in theater. We would love to continue serving the community for at least another 20 years; we would also love to expand the service that we can provide. In order to continue forward, we need funds. 

With the money from this campaign, we will be able to fix up the backstage area of the theater. We would love to build an extra wall and divide some of our unused storage space into an extra room for more rehearsal and a more organized storage space. We will also be able to pay the royalties on more shows, allowing us to choose shows that can reach more members of the community. Moving into the future, we hope to expand the educational aspect of our organization. Some options we would like to advance would be summer camps for children, where they could get involved with theater, and classes for aspiring actors on subjects such as, how to audition. 

If you are unable to contribute, you can also help us by spreading the word! Let your friends and family know about our theater and how they can get involved. And stop on by and see our shows! Listed below are the shows featured in our very exciting 20th Anniversary season and we would love to see you there, either in the audience or on the stage!

story:
Greetings, Swamp Dwellers!

Who We Are

  • Lucas Acosta , Co-Founder - From horror tinged film-making to being a part of the world-famous "Knott's Scary Farm Halloween Haunt" event, Lucas has been a "haunter" for life. His home haunt began 7 years ago on a front lawn. What started as family and friends hiding behind trees eventually became the immersive experience "CDS" is today in Covina, CA. Lucas is currently an intern at Boneyard Fx.

  • Jose Cadena, Co-Founder - With several years of "home haunting" experience under his belt, horror aficionado and entertainment journalist Jose Cadena partnered with Lucas Acosta in 2013 to make "CDS" a reality.  Always one to pursue enterprising ventures (such as joining the ScareLA core team in 2013), Jose is involved with projects ranging from film to themed interactive entertainment.

What We're Doing

We’re an interactive home horror attraction with major expansion plans for Halloween 2014. With your help, we could produce an entertainment experience that is to die for.

Armed with strong related backgrounds, our team has successfully produced a thrilling home haunted attraction for the past several years. A sample of our production was brought out to the heart of LA for ScareLA, a Halloween convention with an attendance number of 4,000+.  A quick glimpse at some of our weekend reviews from the event show just how positive our feedback has been thus far:

  • Mice Chat - "Pretty damned ambitious. Scares were inventive and a lot of fun."

  • Hollywood Gothique - "This was the best of the free mini-mazes at the convention..."

  • Fangirl Nation - "...by far the most pleasant surprise of the entire weekend. An attention to detail and a dedication that is unrivaled."

So now that we've got the know-how and the vision, all we need is the materials. Carefully crafting this attraction with good materials is key here, so we're asking for donations.
Our goal is to raise approximately $2,500.00 dollars in 20 days. These 2,500 dollars would go to construction materials such as:
  • Lumber
  • Props
  • Lighting
  • Storage
  • Transportation
  • Food for volunteers (yep, we need to staff the event!)
  • Paint
  • Hardware
  • Wallpaper
  • Scents (for a more immersive experience)

Be a Certified Swamp Dweller

We want to provide some fun perks for our donors as well! Here’s a basic breakdown of the perks of being a swamp dweller:

  • $10 - exclusive event poster
  • $25 - ($10 perks PLUS:) exclusively designed T-Shirt
  • $50 - ($25 perks PLUS:) custom "lost" poster starring YOU
  • $75 - ($50 perks PLUS:) front-of-the-line pass
  • $100 - ($75 perks PLUS:) VIP lights-on tour of haunt with creators with souvenir photo 



In the event that we don’t reach our planned goal, we’re moving full-steam ahead regardless! This is first and foremost a passion project that we’re pursuing no matter the budget. All money earned will go to construction expenses as aforementioned.

Thanks to all who donate and spread the word about our home haunt. Visit us at feartheswamp.com for more updates as Halloween approaches. 
Happy Hauntings, swamp dwellers!

story:
Video filmed by Nicole Cobb and Sage Atwood.  Edited By Nicole Cobb.  Music by Jay Ribadeneyra

Overview

The Fox was written by D.H. Lawrence in 1923.  Renowned playwright, actor, and director, Allan Miller, adapted this controversial novella for the stage in 1981.

This three-person psychological drama, set in rural England in 1918, takes place in a farmhouse inhabited by two women endeavoring to live life away from society, on their own terms.  However, their efforts are thwarted at every turn by a cunning fox, who steals their hens and wreaks havoc on a daily basis.  Their sheltered world is shaken up when a young, mysterious, and capable soldier unexpectedly arrives and is invited to stay.  Who is this charismatic visitor who eventually dominates life on the farm?

We are excited to bring this production to the New York stage.  The Fox explores issues that resonate today--male/female power dynamics, femininity, sensuality, sexuality, and the complex relationship between our physical and mental desires.

With your help we will bring this electrifying revival to Manhattan for the first time since its New York premiere at the Roundabout Theatre in 1982!

The Production

The Fox will be performed at the historic Gene Frankel Theatre in downtown Manhattan. 

The cast is as follows:

Nellie.........Clea Straus Rivera*

Jill..............Elizabeth Elkins*

Henry.........Matt Savins


Directed by Jordan Dann


*Appears courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

How You Can Help

Independently producing theater in Manhattan is seriously expensive!

But creating theater that acknowledges the source material, has high quality production values, and respects the creative vision, collaboration, and dedication of the design team, is essential to our mission.

A quick rundown of expenses and how they will be utilized:

  • Artist/Design Compensation: $3500
  • Theater Rental: $3500
  • Rights and Insurance: $1100
  • Props and Set: $2000
  • Advertising/Media: $1500
  • Costumes: $500
  • Rehearsal Space: $1500
We are committed to opening The Fox on July 18, 2014, and we guarantee that every cent raised will go toward our production.  Your help will allow us to compensate our creative team for their dedication and time; it will allow us to give our costume, set, sound and lighting designers the creative freedom to bring this show to life;  and it will enable us to effectively market the show to reach the widest possible audience! Reaching our goal will allow us to produce a show of the highest caliber, given the independent nature of our company.  If we don't, the production will still go forward as planned, making the necessary sacrifices.

Thank You!

In appreciation of your generous tax-deductible gift, we offer a selection of perks, from a shout out on social media to your own bottled cocktail at a performance of your choice!  In addition, know that you are supporting local artists and artistry, strengthening our creative community, and allowing us to produce and share this amazing show!

We invite you to be a part of our collective team and help spread the word about our production in various ways:

  • Share this project with any and all!
  • Like our Facebook page, and share with others!
  • Follow us on Twitter!
  • And of course, come see the show in July!

story:
About The Wishing Tree

Hi, my name is Mustafa and I'm a third-year graduate theatre student at Columbia University's School of the Arts in the MFA Playwriting program. The Wishing Tree is my thesis, and I'm very excited to see it realized for three performances in April 2014 as part of Columbia's NEW PLAYS NOW Festival at Signature Center in midtown Manhattan!

The Wishing Tree is the heroic tale of a young, Middle Eastern woman who commits the unforgivable sin of breaking tradition, facing harsh consequences. Leyla is a young woman who lives in a small village in Turkey. When her husband shoots himself because he is impotent, Leyla must marry her brother-in-law, according to her village's tradition. When she refuses to marry him and follows her dream of true love and freedom, she does not see the danger that awaits.

This story was inspired by my own personal experiences growing up in Turkey. I named the play The Wishing Tree because tying pieces of fabric on the tree becomes the symbol of the unspoken desires of the women who long to be free of the oppressive rules of their society. I wanted to give a voice to the women of the Middle East and honor their struggle to break the long-standing cycles that push them into unwanted marriages. 

This is a very important project for me because it is a great opportunity to present my work to the New York City professional theater world, and I can't do it without your help!

Why We Need Your Help:

While Columbia University is generously providing rehearsal space and a small budget, we need to raise an additional $2,000 to cover the costs of a bare-bones production. Your contributions will be going directly towards:

  • Stipends for 6 actors, a director, a stage manager, and all the other amazing people who are helping make this production happen ($1,750)
  • Scenery and costumes - our scenic designer, Aaron Ethan Green, is building a life-size "wishing tree" out of PVC pipe, paint, and fabric and our costumes need to reflect the specific setting of a small Turkish village ($1,000)
  • Marketing materials - postcards and posters to promote the show and ensure a full house for our three performances, plus hiring a graphic designer ($300)
  • Miscellaneous expenses - Indiegogo processing fee (4% if we meet our goal), Playbill posts for auditions, transportation for load-in and strike

The Team

THE WISHING TREE

by Mustafa Kaymak / directed by Awoye Timpo

Featuring Melis Aker*, Gamze Ceylan*, Ahmet Devran Dayanç, Txai Frota, Ninoshka De Leon Gill, and Tauriq Jenkins.

Tuesday, April 15th @ 8pm, Wednesday, April 16th @ 2:30pm, Saturday, April 19th @ 2:30pm

Producer: Dina Vovsi / Production Stage Manager: Jennifer Toth

Scenic Design: Aaron Ethan Green / Lighting Design: Dante Olivia Smith / Sound Design: Ien DeNio / Props: Jess Adams / Dramaturgy: Selin Uludogan / Script Consultant: Lunga Radebe 

*An Equity Approved Showcase. These Actors are appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute because of your financial situation, we would be so appreciative if you can help us by spreading the word on Facebook and Twitter, and by coming to the show if you are in New York City next month! Performances are held at the Pershing Square Signature Center, 480 West 42nd Street, New York, NY, and are FREE and open to the public.


For up-to-date information and to make reservations for all events, visit columbiastages.org, or email newplays@columbiastages.org.

story:
Theatre Y is proud to announce their production of HAPPY DAYS by Samuel Beckett. Romanian director András Visky, Associate Artistic Director of the Hungarian Theatre of Cluj, directs the two-person cast featuring Artistic Director Melissa Lorraine and Evan Hill. The rarely-performed Samuel Beckett classic will be staged in a multimedia art installation designed by Hungarian intermedia and conceptual artist Peter Szabo. 

Summary

HAPPY DAYS follows Winnie, a woman submerged in a heap of garbage first up to her waist and then up to her neck. Comforted by the occasional visits by her husband Willie, Winnie remains resolved to find meaning in her life and attain her “happy days“ in Beckett's remarkably written tragicomedy.

“As is now expected from Beckett, this text awakens my worst and largest fears: 

‘What am I doing/No one is even noticing/I am lying to myself, always/I am not even present to myself here now.’

"I am acutely aware of the paradox I participate in day by day when I believe that I wish to live, as long as possible, but proceed to drown out the hours themselves.” comments Artistic Director Melissa Lorraine. “Now, in addition to these timeless fears, my generation has the added layer of virtual immortality, the performance of a cyber self…a hall of mirrors to distance us further still from reality. Conceptual Artist Peter Szabo will bury the actors in their own digital garbage – an installation of their actual virtual graveyard. I believe that Beckett’s Happy Days can be the liturgy with which we confront our fear of living, in this century.” 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising money for all aspects of a successful production: set, costumes, lighting, travel & lodging for visiting artists, and cast & crew stipends. 

We want the audience to be connected to our production, so our rewards are structured around your attendance at the show. We are offering multiple ways for donors to be invested in the production, including advance tickets, a backstage tour, a coffee date with members of our creative team, direct sponsorship of elements of the production, and the opportunity to be a producer of the show. 

    Your Impact

    Our mission: Theatre Y creates poetic and visceral theater, mines the contradictions of the human experience, and challenges audiences to find universally shared meaning.

    We embrace the spirituality of the human existence. We utilize international collaboration to foster greater understanding. We strive for artistic excellence and to bring quality craftsmanship to the stage. We seek to give voice to the marginalized in a global society. We take deliberate risks in pushing artistic, personal and ideological boundaries. We believe that our audience is critical in sorting through the ambiguity and completing our work. We practice personal integrity and accountability.

    Your contribution will help strengthen our mission and give us the ability to continue to create theater at the highest level. 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Even if you can't give, there are still ways you can participate. Come and see our show, tell your friends, and attend one of our community events. Find us on Facebook, Twitter or our website!
