story:
On October 24th and 25th 2014, INKED Dance will proudly present their 3rd full length evening dance concert, "The LA Symphony and other works."  The performance will take place at 8pm on Friday and Saturday October 24th and 25th at the Martha B Knoebel Dance Theater located on campus at California State University at Long Beach.  Tickets are $20 General Admission and $15 for students and seniors. 

Artistic director Brian Moe presents an explosive dance piece to vivid life with his 9 company dancers in his newest work, The LA Symphony.   Set to an original 4 movement symphony composed by Moe himself and inspired by the sights and sounds of Los Angeles and its surrounding areas,  this seminal work explores human connection, trust, love, and loss with dynamic and athletic movement and contemporary partnering.  The music intertwines beautifully with the orchestral score to take the viewer on a journey through the plights of the people of LA, primarily the vagrants and how we look view them as a society.
The second presents a series of other works choreographed by Brian Moe, starting with "Larks," set to Haydn's string quartet in D Major, op 64.   The quarter shares the name of "Lark," and it is this name that Moe found his inspiration for movement.  He uses his cast of 5 dancers to explore the majesty and tenderness of these flying beasts.  

There will be one 15 minute intermission between the acts of the concert.

Tickets are available at:  http://inked-dance.brownpapertickets.com

What we need is financial support to help us cover the expense of the theater rental that needs to be paid in advance of the concert.   INKED dance is a fairly new company in the LA Dance scene; however, we have been quite ambitious in our 2 years of existence.  Last year we presented 2 full length works, RANT in May (The ARC in Pasadena), and Nightmares in October (Highways Performance Space).

Dance, like all art forms, thrives on the support of its patrons.  Attending dance is one form of donation; however most fees are due in advance of the actual performance and therefore we require fundraisers to help us alleviate these financial pressures.  Our company hopes to raise enough funds so that we may successfully present this important dance work to the public, as well as continue to create work in the future.

For those who do donate, we offer a number of rewards.  These vary from free tickets and merchandise, to being recognized publicly on our website and in our program.  If you are a business and would like to have your company advertised in the program, this is an option as well for a higher donation.  

Funding is minimal in the art world, especially for emerging artists.  

INKED Dance is an emerging group of dancers, but a passionate and talented group that takes on enormous projects each year.  It is important to us to continue this trend in order to separate ourselves from other companies in the area.

If you can not donate yourself, then perhaps you can help by sharing a link, sharing a video, the company website, or attending the concert.
story_txt:
On October 24th and 25th 2014, INKED Dance will proudly present their 3rd full length evening dance concert, "The LA Symphony and other works."  The performance will take place at 8pm on Friday and Saturday October 24th and 25th at the Martha B Knoebel Dance Theater located on campus at California State University at Long Beach.  Tickets are $20 General Admission and $15 for students and seniors. 
Artistic director Brian Moe presents an explosive dance piece to vivid life with his 9 company dancers in his newest work, The LA Symphony.   Set to an original 4 movement symphony composed by Moe himself and inspired by the sights and sounds of Los Angeles and its surrounding areas,  this seminal work explores human connection, trust, love, and loss with dynamic and athletic movement and contemporary partnering.  The music intertwines beautifully with the orchestral score to take the viewer on a journey through the plights of the people of LA, primarily the vagrants and how we look view them as a society.The second presents a series of other works choreographed by Brian Moe, starting with "Larks," set to Haydn's string quartet in D Major, op 64.   The quarter shares the name of "Lark," and it is this name that Moe found his inspiration for movement.  He uses his cast of 5 dancers to explore the majesty and tenderness of these flying beasts.  
There will be one 15 minute intermission between the acts of the concert.
Tickets are available at:  http://inked-dance.brownpapertickets.com
 What we need is financial support to help us cover the expense of the theater rental that needs to be paid in advance of the concert.   INKED dance is a fairly new company in the LA Dance scene; however, we have been quite ambitious in our 2 years of existence.  Last year we presented 2 full length works, RANT in May (The ARC in Pasadena), and Nightmares in October (Highways Performance Space).

Dance, like all art forms, thrives on the support of its patrons.  Attending dance is one form of donation; however most fees are due in advance of the actual performance and therefore we require fundraisers to help us alleviate these financial pressures.  Our company hopes to raise enough funds so that we may successfully present this important dance work to the public, as well as continue to create work in the future.
For those who do donate, we offer a number of rewards.  These vary from free tickets and merchandise, to being recognized publicly on our website and in our program.  If you are a business and would like to have your company advertised in the program, this is an option as well for a higher donation.  

Funding is minimal in the art world, especially for emerging artists.  
INKED Dance is an emerging group of dancers, but a passionate and talented group that takes on enormous projects each year.  It is important to us to continue this trend in order to separate ourselves from other companies in the area.

If you can not donate yourself, then perhaps you can help by sharing a link, sharing a video, the company website, or attending the concert.

story:
FullStop Collective presents the world premiere of OUTFOXED at Access Theater, NYC, November 29 - December 16, 2012

Studying abroad in Italy, Alyssa gets caught up in a whirlwind of sex, drugs and violence...  Her Mother gets a phone call.

About the Project

FullStop Collective is a New York City-based multidisciplinary theater laboratory currently in its fifth season of groundbreaking new work.  We have been developing OUTFOXED through readings and workshops for the past eighteen months. Playwright Lucy Gillespie continued to develop the script during a residency at the MacDowell Colony earlier this year.

OUTFOXED is a headline-making story about a bookish American young woman who is swept up in a life of sex and drugs while studying abroad. After one particularly wild night, she finds herself at the center of a cultural, moral and legal maelstrom 6,000 miles from home.  

Your support will help FullStop pay our incredibly talented actors, book space to rehearse and experiment, and enable our designers to realize their visions in this dramatic, theatrical world.

We need your help. 

FullStop has produced fourteen productions in five years, and has consistently operated on a smartly balanced budget.  Your contributions are essential to our continued growth and increased production value.  

We are seeking $3,000 in contributions to:

  • Pay our actors ($1,000)
  • Pay for rehearsal space ($1,200)
  • Support our design elements ($800)

Funds raised above this amount will go to pay our designers and production team, boost our marketing strategy, and cover vital administrative costs associated with producing new theater in New York City.

In thanks, we offer an assortment of perks!  All donors will receive a personal thank-you from FullStop Collective, and donors over $25 will be thanked in the production program.  Donors above certain levels will enjoy FullStop merchandise, complimentary tickets to OUTFOXED performances, a personalized video thank-you from members the production, and a private wine reception with the cast and creative team!

The Impact

We care very much about this project.  It not only holds artistic and personal significance within the Collective, it is also a timely meditation on perceptions and behaviors across nationalities. The world has become an increasingly small place that we all must co-habitat. By supporting OUTFOXED, you will become part of a years-long vision for the development and production of artistically exhilirating and emotionally resonant theater.  This is a culminating piece for FullStop, our biggest independant endeavor yet, and we would be honored to partner with you in bringing this vision to life.

Looking for other ways to show your support?

There are many ways to support OUTFOXED in addition to a financial contribution! You can post this campaign to your Facebook and Twitter feeds, and email it to your friends.  Visit FullStopCollective.org to subscribe to our email list, and contact us at info@fullstopcollective.org to find out how to assist on fundraising events, audition for shows, or offer production support.  

And, most importantly: COME SEE THE SHOW!

Tickets are live and can be purchased at outfoxed.brownpapertickets.com Tickets are $15 in advance or $18 at the door.

Performance Dates:

Thursday, November 29 @ 8pm (Preview)
Friday, November 30 @ 8pm (Opening)
Saturday, December 1 @ 8pm
Sunday, December 2 @ 8pm
Saturday, December 8 @ 2pm
Sunday, December 9 @ 8pm
Monday, December 10 @ 8pm
Thursday, December 13 @ 8pm
Saturday, December 15 @ 8pm
Sunday, December 16 @ 2pm

At Access Theater
380 Broadway, 4th Floor
(between Walker and White Streets)

New York City

Directions
J, N, Q, R, Z, 6 to Canal St

OUTFOXED

Written by Lucy Gillespie
Directed by Brian Hashimoto

Executive Producer, Jack Sharkey
Producers, Leta Tremblay & John DeSilvestri
Press Representation by, Lanie Zipoy (lanie.zipoy@gmail.com)

Featuring
Lindsey Austen, Brandi Bravo, Brian Dunlop, Deanna Henson*, Stephen Conrad Moore*, James Oblak, Charity Shubert, Hannah Vaughn
*Appearing courtesy of the Actors’ Equity Association.

Creative Team
Jacquelyn D. Marolt - Set Designer
Sarah Bertolozzi - Costume Designer
Aaron Porter - Lighting Designer
Seth Asa Sengel - Sound Designer
Claine Kavanah - Props Charge
Sofie Miller - Stage Manager
LeeAnn DiCicco - Graphic Design
 
IndieGoGo Video Credits:
Filming and Photos by Brian Hashimoto
Editing by Mariah MacCarthy
Music: "Optimist" by Zoe Keating and "The Killing Type" by Amanda Palmer
Pictured: Lindsey Austen, Brandi Bravo, and Deanna Henson
Voice Over: Lindsey Austen

Thank you so much for your support!

story:
“That script, together with its songs of very interesting lyrical content, with very listenable, uniquely-melodic music, has caught my eye & ear because of its unusual theme, as well as what I consider to be its excellent score.” - James Rado (Co-writer of HAIR)

Hello from Mad haPPy, Rivka , Mike iLL (and now Rinah). We live in Pensacola, FL. We moved here from Hoboken, NJ a few years ago so we could enjoy the mild winter and cheap rent to focus on our music. This is our home / office / studio where we prepare food, garden (by hand), eat, sleep, stretch, study, create, teach, rehearse, network, promote and most importantly play.

Joys of Armageddon is a two hour Musical Theatre Production, performed as a reading in New York City, NY, in the Oklahoma City/ Norman, OK area, Amarillo, TX, Chicago, IL and on the 11th of September 2010 in Pensacola, FL. We’ve done full productions in New Orleans, LA, Hoboken, NJ, Brooklyn, NY and in November New York City, NY. We’ve been workshopping, performing, re-writing and editing for a couple of years now and have gone as far in debt as we feel safe. Maybe a little further. In order to continue in the realization of this vision, we need your support. As you can imagine, anything helps and we look forward to seeing you soon.

New York City, December the eleventh – twenty twelve. A small group of brilliant misfits call themselves the Mutiny Zoo. They’ve made preparations, should they survive the expected cataclysms of twenty twelve to camp our in an abandoned subway tunnel beneath Grand Central Station. More importantly the are working on Cybergenic Reincarnation, the possibility of the after life in cyber space.

Review
From apocalyptic sci-fi to naturalistic Grand Guignol to florid Southern melodrama, “Joys Of Armageddon” mashes together bits of Harlan Ellison, Tennessee Williams, and Douglas Sirk… It’s a unique experience, and will hopefully be staged again. -Jim Testa (NJ.com)

Budget
Here’s a simple outline of our Fall/Winter/Spring budget and what your donations will go towards manifesting:

November Production at the Red Room

  • NYC Theater Space Rental $525.00
  • Event Insurance $200.00
  • Fire Inspection Certificate $25.00
  • Rehearsal Space $500.00
  • Flyers/Posters $300.00
  • Props and Costumes $200.00
  • Video Projector Rental $250.00
  • Travel & Lodging $1500.00
  • Artistic Personnel $1800.00
    (10 Actors, Choreographer, Director, MultiMedia Team, Lighting Designer, Costume Designer, Hair/Make-up)
  • Technical Personnel
    (Lights, Sound, Props, Curtain, Projector, DJ) $500.00
  • Publicity $500.00
  • Operating Costs $2375.00
    (Equipment Rental and Maintenance, Application Fees, Office Expenses & Supplies, Living Expenses for 15 days, Surprise Expenses)
Total: $8675.00

19 Track Sound Track Recording

  • Studio & Operating Costs $9375.00
    (Equipment Rental and Maintenance, Application Fees, Office Expenses & Supplies, Living Expenses for 75 days, and any Surprise Expenses)
  • Manufacturing 1,000 CDs $1250.00
Total: $10,625.00

Winter Pensacola / New Orleans – 6 Shows

  • Operating costs $3125.00
    (Equipment Rental and Maintenance, Application Fees, Office Expenses & Supplies, Living Expenses for 70 days, and any Surprise Expenses)
  • Travel $500.00
  • Lodging $550.00
    (Specifically gassing up for traveling cast members)
  • Artistic Personnel $1800.00
    (10 Actors, Choreographer, Director, MultiMedia Team, Lighting Designer, Costume Designer, Hair/Make-up)
  • Technical Personnel
    (Lights, Sound, Props, Curtain, Projector, DJ) $500.00
  • Promo/Posters $150.00
  • Theater/Rehearsal Rental $1,000.00
Total: $7625

Spring NYC/NJ Joys of Armageddon show

Estimated Total: $8675.00

story:
Our Project

The Chicago debut of "Electra" by Euripides (newly adapted by Sonja Moser) has been made possible thus far by the generous efforts of  Carlo Garcia, an lllinois State University Alumni, and Mary-Arrchie Theatre Company. The cast of this imaginative meta-theatrical spin on Euripide's Greek tragedy consists of 17 Illinois State University Undergraduate Theatre students.  This project marks an unprecedented opportunity for actors, designers, and stage managers of the Illinios State University's School of Theatre to present a collaborative production in Chicago that showcases their creative efforts.

 

The Impact

This production of "Electra", presented by Mary-Arrchie Theatre Company in association with Illinois State University's School of Theatre, has created a rare opportunity for current theatre students and Chicagoland alumni to connect. For the cast, its a chance to showcase a production at a reputable Chicago Storefront that is 27 years in the making. Mary Arrchie's committment to the creation of intimate, high impact, craft-centered productions is precisely what we as young emerging theatre artists aspire to be a part of. The primary goal of this project is not only to create captivating work for our audiences, but to also gain knowledge from the experience of presenting this work at a Chicago Storefront that has opened its doors to us. Due to the faith and support of our production by Illinois State University's School of Theatre alumni Carlo Garcia  this project is possible. For this privelege, we are extremely grateful.

 

Where We Need Your Help

The 'Electra' cast is thrilled with this incredible opportunity to present their work, but we need some help getting there. The students involved will be commuting from Central Illinois to Downtown Chicago. Due to increasing travel expenses, the cost of most of the commutes are beyond the means of individual students involved.

Here's how your donations would be assisting us:

  • CTA month passes to transport students taking the Metra- from Union/Oligilvie station to the Angel Island Theatre(Redline-Sheridan stop) at the cost of $86 each. 
  • Gas. For members of our cast that are driving 2-3 hrs to and from the theatre, the cost of gas is definitely a stumbling block. Any amount to help supplement these costs would be extremely beneficial.
  • Living Expenses. Students that are subletting housing for the run of the production are in need of financial support to cover a small percentage of this cost.
  • There's no such thing as a contribution that is too small. Any help at all is greatly appreciated!

Our Show- Description

"Electra and her brother Orestes seek to avenge the death of their father at the hands of their mother and her lover. Set in John Deere country, this inventive meta-theatrical adaptation of the famous Euripides tragedy is filled with live rock music, humor, teen angst, and sweet, sweet muddy revenge. Don’t be afraid to get dirty."

Other Ways You Can Help!

Post this campaign on facebook, twitter,email to friends or just spread the word! 

 

Additional links:

  • For Early Bird discounted tickets!:  http://www.goldstar.com/events/chicago-il/electra-1
  • Our Facebook Event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/342314182493373/?ref=ts

story:
The Play

‘Once upon a time there was a country that existed only for one day…’

Adam, a castaway, believes that he is the lost prince of the country of Gildoray… but no one even believes that Gildoray exists. Still Adam journeys the world over, battling pirates and monsters, rescuing princesses, and doing daring deeds of heroism, ever searching for his lost kingdom.

‘The production is as impressive as it is flawless’ – St Andrews Radio

‘A swash-buckling adventure of epic proportions’ – The Tribe

From St Andrews to Edinburgh, epic fantasy invades the Fringe!

Who We Are

We are a group of students from the University of St Andrews in Scotland, taking our first show to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. We range from PhD candidates to first-year undergraduates, and hail from the U.K., the U.S., and Norway. Our director is a member of the Scottish Youth Theatre, and our producer is a graduate of NYU Tisch Drama. We had a successful run of The World Over at St Andrews in December, and are now bringing mythical creatures, heroic quests, and thrilling late-night swordfighting to Edinburgh!

What We Need

Bringing a show to the Edinburgh Fringe is an expensive operation and we're running solely on our own funds and partial funding from Mermaids (the University of St Andrews' dramatic society) and the Antony Tudor Fund (the University's grant-giving body for drama). Contributions to the show will go towards costs not covered by outside funding, such as a rehearsal space, additional props and costumes and daily running costs, as well as living expenses for cast/crew once production costs are met. 

Here's what your donation pays for:

$10: 1 medium-sized prop/costume piece

$25: 1/3 of the cost of rights for 1 performance

$50: 1 day in a rehearsal studio

$100: 80 posters + 1,500 flyers

$250: 2 weeks' accommodation for 1 actor

$500: Venue rental for 2 performances

What You'll Get

In return for your help we can offer you a variety of benefits ranging from special mention on our website for your services to free tickets, a copy of the script signed by the cast and crew, an invite to the cast party, and more! You'll be doing us (and the arts!) an immense favour and we'll do all we can to ensure that you feel our appreciation! 

Spread the Word

Tell your friends, your family, anyone who'll lend you their ears that The World Over is looking for support and we'll be your eternal servants.

Thanks for considering sponsoring The World Over at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe - see you when the curtain rises!

U.S.-Based Donors: The producer is planning to re-mount the play in the U.S. within the next 5 years. If you donate at a level that includes free tickets but will not be in the U.K. for the Fringe, we can save your tickets (and cast party invite, if applicable) for the U.S. run, or offer you an alternate thank-you gift - email worldoverfringe@gmail.com for a list of options.

‘A swash-buckling adventure of epic proportions’ – The Tribe
From St Andrews to Edinburgh, epic fantasy invades the Fringe!
Who We Are
We are a group of students from the University of St Andrews in Scotland, taking our first show to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. We range from PhD candidates to first-year undergraduates, and hail from the U.K., the U.S., and Norway. Our director is a member of the Scottish Youth Theatre, and our producer is a graduate of NYU Tisch Drama. We had a successful run of The World Over at St Andrews in December, and are now bringing mythical creatures, heroic quests, and thrilling late-night swordfighting to Edinburgh!

What We Need

Bringing a show to the Edinburgh Fringe is an expensive operation and we're running solely on our own funds and partial funding from Mermaids (the University of St Andrews' dramatic society) and the Antony Tudor Fund (the University's grant-giving body for drama). Contributions to the show will go towards costs not covered by outside funding, such as a rehearsal space, additional props and costumes and daily running costs, as well as living expenses for cast/crew once production costs are met. 
Here's what your donation pays for:
$10: 1 medium-sized prop/costume piece
$25: 1/3 of the cost of rights for 1 performance
$50: 1 day in a rehearsal studio
$100: 80 posters + 1,500 flyers
$250: 2 weeks' accommodation for 1 actor
$500: Venue rental for 2 performances
What You'll Get
In return for your help we can offer you a variety of benefits ranging from special mention on our website for your services to free tickets, a copy of the script signed by the cast and crew, an invite to the cast party, and more! You'll be doing us (and the arts!) an immense favour and we'll do all we can to ensure that you feel our appreciation! 
Spread the Word
Tell your friends, your family, anyone who'll lend you their ears that The World Over is looking for support and we'll be your eternal servants.
Thanks for considering sponsoring The World Over at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe - see you when the curtain rises!
U.S.-Based Donors: The producer is planning to re-mount the play in the U.S. within the next 5 years. If you donate at a level that includes free tickets but will not be in the U.K. for the Fringe, we can save your tickets (and cast party invite, if applicable) for the U.S. run, or offer you an alternate thank-you gift - email worldoverfringe@gmail.com for a list of options.

story:
We are Life Theatre Company, one of Philadelphia’s newest companies, and we’re proud to present our first full production of Bat Boy: The Musical for the 2013 Philadelphia FringeArts Festival. On behalf of the whole cast and crew, we are especially excited to be working on this project, and we can’t wait to share it with this wonderful thriving community!

Every one of us is incredibly passionate about what we do, and we truly love it. It would be amazing to have the funds necessary to pull off such a big project. Since we’re just starting out, unfortunately we don’t have those funds, but we do have the drive, passion, and talent to make it happen! We are all extremely dedicated to our art, and we work hard so that we can entertain audiences like you! That’s who we do it for!

And here’s where you come in! Anything you can give to support us will go towards the efforts of all of the artists involved and all the materials necessary to making this production possible, and we hope to repay you with a wonderful theatre experience. Every little bit helps! Thank you for taking the time to read this!

So much goes into every aspect of theatre that is needed for this project. Here are some of the areas your contribution will benefit:

  • Cast and Crew Fees
  • Musician Fees
  • Designer Fees and Materials Needed for Each Design
  • Set Pieces, Costumes, Make-up, Lighting, Sound, Props
  • Theatre Rental Fees
  • Rehearsal Space Rental Fees
  • Licensing Rights for the Show
  • Renting Scores and other Materials
  • Staff and Manager Fees
  • Advertising and Marketing Fees 
  • Printing Costs
  • Liability Insurance
  • And Much, Much More!!

So, please donate and contribute to making all of this possible! No amount is too small or goes unnoticed! Getting the word out about our project would be a huge contribution as well so feel free to use the Share tools and tell your friends! We'd appreciate any help we can get, and most importantly, we'd love for you to come see what the outcome is! September 18-22 at the SkyBox at the Adrienne!! We hope to see you there!!

story:
What is Unwound: Beyond the Labyrinth?

Unwound is an original musical that has been in development for the past year. It follows the stories of several Greek myths, all woven together with Ariadne's red thread. The show deals with themes of loneliness, trauma, identity, and hope.

By putting on a free virtual concert, we aim to not only further develop the show's journey, but to provide accessible musical theatre content for anyone to experience and enjoy. We also want to help financially support artists during this difficult time.

 

Why $18,000?

While the performance is free, we feel it is right and fair to compensate the 24 artists who are dedicating their time, skills, and imaginations to the production. 

For 24 artists, at 7 weeks of work, at $100 a week pay, our total comes to $16,800. As Indiegogo takes a 5% cut for hosting the campaign, we raised the overall total for the sake of our performers and designers. 

We know this is an ambitious total, and we may not reach it. But we wanted to show that number, as a way of helping people understand what goes into making a musical. That number does not include costumes, or props, or sets, or royalties. Just people, helping other people, making art in a time of isolation.

Check Us Out!

Unwound: Beyond the Labyrinth has several platforms that we would love for you to check out--and share with friends if you enjoy our content! If nothing else, having as many eyeballs as possible on our concert when the video comes out would mean the world to us.

Currently you can find more about Unwound: Beyond the Labyrinth here:

Facebook: @unwoundmusical

Instagram: @unwound_musical

Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbIOBH1gtpZdIa...

Demos: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PL8vZL0AQIpob...

Patreon: patreon.com/unwoundmusical

story:
We are so excited to share the world premiere of this new work, but we need your help! Fabulist Theatre is an independent theatre company based in the GVRD. We are not-for-profit, committed to diversity and inclusivity, creating opportunities for under-represented and marginalized performers. We want to do something different, something exciting.

The Untold Legend Of Imogen Flight features a wide array of diverse women showcasing many different sides of the female experience in a time that was rooted in the oppression of women, despite a female monarch. 

It’s about how women come together and celebrate one another.

We are asking our community to support what we think is immensely valuable to enrich the theatre scene and create a whole host of dynamic, supportive and badass women in one show. We want to show it can be done, while being fun, funny and entertaining, as well as thought-provoking and inclusive. Expect some thrilling sword fights, filthy pirates, rebel nuns, friendship, songs of courage, and plenty of ale. 

Producing theatre is always a risk but our aim is to create meaningful art that has lasting value. We receive no funding help from the government or grants and rely on the support of our friends, family and local businesses to share in our vision. Ticket sales cover a good deal of costs but they are not a guarantee! 

Our BIGGEST Costs

-Rental of rehearsal space ($1000+)

-Honorariums for performers ($2000+)

-Honorariums for production team ($1500+)

Fabulist Theatre is committed to providing compensation to all our performers, creatives and techs, so every little bit helps us ensure that our work is financially viable and keeps ticket prices affordable and accessible. We have some pretty sweet perks, too, so if you feel like being extra generous we will reward you in kind!

Most of all, we hope The Untold Legend Of Imogen Flight will inspire all who see it to greatness - to recognize what is possible within yourself and realize your heart’s desires. 

The Untold Legend Of Imogen Flight stars a diverse, intergenerational cast of ten women: Eryka Alanna as Jane, Chandni Appadurai as Saifi, Mallory James as Umbriel, Niki Kennedy as Lucy, Monica Maia as Nancy, Helen Martin as Isla, Louisa Phung as Marigold, Christine Roskelley as Barb, Shakira Shute as Imogen Flight & Junita Thiessen as Volta

Written & Directed by Mary Littlejohn, Fight Choreography by Sylvie La Riviere, Costumes by Jenna Johnson, Stage Management & Lighting Design by Andy Sandberg, Publicity/Marketing by Damon Bradley Jang

The Untold Legend Of Imogen Flight runs February 27 - March 7, 2020 at CBC Studio 700, 700 Hamilton Street, Vancouver, BC. Tickets can be purchased at http://imogenflight.bpt.me.

To learn more about Fabulist Theatre and our past shows, visit us on Facebook www.facebook.com/FabulistTheatreVancouver or on Instagram @fabulisttheatre.

story:
Bringing Classical Music to Life

We are hatching a new kind of performance that blends classical music and live theater. As musicians, classical music is the central focus of our lives. However, we realize that not everyone finds it so easy to understand and enjoy our work. Through this project, we hope to illuminate classical music so that others can enjoy it as much as we do.

Our main shows will be held at the Boston University Dance Theater on May 4, 2019. With funds from this campaign, we plan to hold an additional free performance for young people in Boston. These talented kids are studying classical music and circus arts, but they live in underserved neighborhoods where they might not see many shows like this one. We want to inspire them so that they can see where the arts may lead them.

The show

When you come to our show, sit up close while a live quartet performs Dmitri Shostakovich's String Quartet No. 6 in nearly total darkness. During intermission, we will provide our guests with Russian pelmeni dumplings, pickles, and kompot (juice) to get a taste of the flavors of Shostakovich’s native cuisine. After intermission we'll perform the same piece again, this time as part of a story told by contemporary circus performers, including a silks act, ground acrobatics, and physical theatre pieces. The story is inspired by Shostakovich's life, which is rich with material. He ran into all sorts of trouble with Soviet censors and spent many decades in fear that he was about to get sent off to a gulag. The production explores the power of the arts to resist authoritarianism.

The first half of the show encourages audience members to listen deeply and let their imaginations run freely, while the second half illustrates our own interpretation of the music. The whole show lasts an hour, allowing plenty of time afterwards for audience members to talk with the performers and with each other.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the lowdown:

  • We're raising money to fund an additional free performance for kids who are part of Circus Up! and the Roxbury Youth Orchestra, so that they can see what's possible with the art forms they're studying.
  • We believe that artists should be paid for their work. The proceeds from this campaign will allow us to pay our artists for this outreach performance.
  • In thanks for your donations, we have great perks! You could get VIP tickets to our May 4 show, super-cool Dmitri swag designed by artist Phanousit Syhakhom, your name encoded into a musical performance, or even a personal concert in your home!
  • Even if we don't reach our entire goal, every dollar raised will still go towards paying artists to participate in this free performance for young underserved artists in Boston.

The Impact

If you feel like you just don't "get" classical music, you're not alone. Only 8% of the population has seen a classical music performance this year. Compare this to Soviet Russia, where everyone awaited Shostakovich's symphonic premieres with great anticipation. Classical music can communicate humanity's deepest emotions. By giving the music a visual component, the goal is to make it more interesting to audiences who are newer to classical music.

Circus Up! and the Roxbury Youth Orchestra are amazing organizations training Boston's young people in the arts. We want to share our creation with students so that they can experience the power of the arts first-hand.

By presenting a performance that is based in classical music but that also involves circus arts, theater, and Soviet history, we are presenting Shostakovich’s music in an immersive way to broaden the boundaries of what our audience considers to be classical music. Furthermore, we believe the repeated listening and visual component in our performance will help the audience engage with the music on a deeper level. 

Circus Up!

Circus Up uses circus arts to overcome social barriers and build community with people of all ages, backgrounds, and abilities. The organization has been bringing their vision of social circus to Boston.

Social circus often means prioritizing the idea that underserved populations should have access to circus arts, and also that circus arts can and should be used to build life skills, such as confidence, resilience, communication, and the ability to self-advocate. Social circus often works with at-risk youth, using circus arts as a medium for social justice and for providing opportunities to children in underserved communities.  

Students in grades K-12 who have participated in Circus Up's in-school and after-school programs will be invited to our free performance. More info on the organization is available at www.circusup.com.

The Roxbury Youth Orchestra

The Roxbury Youth Orchestra is a world-class music education initiative in the Roxbury neighborhood of Boston. The program is guided by the belief that an intensive music education can have transformative effects on both the individual and society.

RYO students receive over 15 hours of conservatory-level instruction each week including lessons, technique classes, orchestra, and chorus. Participants also perform in numerous local and citywide events. In this way the program provides a daily haven of safety, joy, and fun that will build every child’s self-esteem and sense of value.

Members of the Dmitri in the Dark quartet will visit the Roxbury Youth Orchestra to perform a movement from the piece. Then RYO members will be invited to our free performance.

Thank you for supporting us!

story:
CREEP CUTS IS DRAG.  CREEP CUTS ISN’T DRAG.  WAIT, WHAT’S DRAG?

 

Mz. Asa Metric and Mqr En Between were once drag queens, or maybe they were once agitprop surrealists, or maybe they were butoh racers, and maybe tonight they’re anti-fascist clowns.  We’ve been performing our genre queer cabaret mashup CREEP CUTS for a few years now in New Orleans, bringing our own twist to dada drag realness. After years of sharpening our material and making a mess for audiences all over New Orleans, we’re ready to finally kick this sucker into high gear.  We’ve always wanted CREEP CUTS to be a medium-hopping experience for (some of) the whole family, so we are finally realizing three dreams we’ve had since this project was a baby larvae twinkling in Mqr. En’s eye:

 

-Take the show on the road!

-Make a new album of our original electronic music from CREEP CUTS

-A music video for our original track “PARADE” to kick off a whole bucketful of video content

 

SO WHERE THE HELL’S YOUR MONEY GOING?

 

$1000- LET’S PUT ON A SHOW!

 

The core of the CREEP CUTS is our live show, a one-hour piece of dreamstate trash theater.  We’ve received a fantastic opportunity to perform this show in New York City during the Association of Performing Arts Presenters as part of “Future Oceans” curated by Shannon Stewart and Laurie Uprichard at the Marlene Meyerson JCC in Manhattan..  Two things we LOVE about this gig:
 

1)  This is our first showing of our tour-ready show.  We want to bring this to a city near you, and we want this gig to be the start of a string of gigs and gags in your backyard!  

 

2)  The show will be completely free.  That’s right. COMPLETELY free in New York City of all places!  We want our wild cabaret whirlwind to be as accessible as possible, and while we have always implemented “no one turned away for lack of funds” policies at our shows, it’s even better when there’s no cover at all!

 

But this means ticket sales will not help cover the cost of:

 

-Renting the venue

-Paying for our wonderful techies

-Props and “consumables” budget

-Paying for rehearsal space

-Paying for promotional materials...

 

...and more.  Your help could make our dream of keeping CREEP CUTS open to all regardless of ability to pay alive!

 

$1000- MUSIC FOR YOUR EARHOLES!

 

The core of the core of CREEP CUTS is our original electronic MUSIC!  Written by Mqr En Between with lyrics by Mz Asa Metric, we’ve had an album’s worth of music banging around for years.  We’re finally ready to lay those tracks down, and your help will get us through the initial production costs including studio rental, materials and mastering time.  

 

$4000- MOVIE FOR YOUR EYEHOLES!

 

The most ambitious piece of the CREEP CUTS EXPANSION PACK project is going to be our music video for our original track and first single, “PARADE”.  We’re collaborating with directors NAT AND VERONICA to create ooey gooey monster drag birth rituals… I mean, create our first music video! We’re going to meet Mqr En Between in New Orleans, hire a bunch of our favorite weirdos to create a big, bold vision of mind-bending queer spectacle as only New Orleanians can.  This music video will be the kickoff of our YouTube channel, which will feature more music, malfunctioning sketch comedy and other content created just for the world of the INTERWEBS!

 

CAN’T DONATE?

 

Hey, we get it!  No sweat! If you’re not able to donate at this time, we’d love it if you could help signal boost or help spread the word!  Tell people about our free NYC gig on Jan 5 and 6, or talk to a local venue near you and ask them to bring CREEP CUTS to you!

COMPLETELY free in New York City of all places!  We want our wild cabaret whirlwind to be as accessible as possible, and while we have always implemented “no one turned away for lack of funds” policies at our shows, it’s even better when there’s no cover at all! But this means ticket sales will not help cover the cost of: -Renting the venue-Paying for our wonderful techies-Props and “consumables” budget-Paying for rehearsal space-Paying for promotional materials... ...and more.  Your help could make our dream of keeping CREEP CUTS open to all regardless of ability to pay alive! $1000- MUSIC FOR YOUR EARHOLES! The core of the core of CREEP CUTS is our original electronic MUSIC!  Written by Mqr En Between with lyrics by Mz Asa Metric, we’ve had an album’s worth of music banging around for years.  We’re finally ready to lay those tracks down, and your help will get us through the initial production costs including studio rental, materials and mastering time.   $4000- MOVIE FOR YOUR EYEHOLES! The most ambitious piece of the CREEP CUTS EXPANSION PACK project is going to be our music video for our original track and first single, “PARADE”.  We’re collaborating with directors NAT AND VERONICA to create ooey gooey monster drag birth rituals… I mean, create our first music video! We’re going to meet Mqr En Between in New Orleans, hire a bunch of our favorite weirdos to create a big, bold vision of mind-bending queer spectacle as only New Orleanians can.  This music video will be the kickoff of our YouTube channel, which will feature more music, malfunctioning sketch comedy and other content created just for the world of the INTERWEBS! CAN’T DONATE? Hey, we get it!  No sweat! If you’re not able to donate at this time, we’d love it if you could help signal boost or help spread the word!  Tell people about our free NYC gig on Jan 5 and 6, or talk to a local venue near you and ask them to bring CREEP CUTS to you!
campaign_city: New York / New Orleans, United States

story:
Who we are:

The Bellwether Project is a collective of young, excited artists, formed at Carnegie Mellon University in the spirit of collaboration and intersectional storytelling. Over its 4 years as a company, BWP has produced 3 world premieres, two provocative dance pieces, and a web-series available online. Now, we've relocated to New York City and are launching two world premieres back-to-back.

Where we're at:

The Bellwether Project is lucky enough to have been offered slots in two highly selective festivals this June. One of the projects is a futuristic beauty pageant with a dark secret, and the other is an experimental exploration/celebration of the relationships between mothers and daughters. While we're receiving some technical support from these festivals, we need help in covering the production costs of both World Premieres, and in fairly compensating all of the artists involved.

Why it matters:

With your help, we will be able to launch our company in the highly competitive environment of New York City. Given the size and audience of both of these festivals, we are in an exciting position to use these opportunities to make relationships with larger theatre companies and producers, who can help us take our work to the next level. Our goal is also to engage more artists in thought-provoking work and reach more audiences with compelling, untold stories. Your contributions are the key to achieving that goal, and we grateful for anything that you would be willing to give.

The Ask:

We are seeking $8,000 total, split evenly between both of our World Premiere productions.
These funds will be put toward production costs, like costumes and scenic pieces that will enhance the artistic quality of the pieces, as well as rehearsal space that will give our actors and directors a place to craft the story.

The funds will also go toward paying the team of artists for each piece. The theatrical community of NYC is often taking advantage of young artists by asking them to work for free. Despite being a small company, we are dedicated to fair compensation for all artists working on our projects. Eventually, we hope to guarantee a living wage, but understanding the difficult realities of producing in NYC, we are aiming at a fair stipend for everyone involved. 

The Perks!

  • $25 or more will receive a social media shoutout
  • $50 or more will receive a personalized thank-you card
  • $100 or more will be thanked in the program as a major donor
  • $250 or more will receive a limited edition Bellwether Project T-Shirt 
  • $500 or more will receive a signed photo with the cast 
  • $1000 or more will receive a dinner with the artists behind the productions

The Impact

Both of these productions are fulfilling our mission to share untold stories with the world. So often, the narratives we hear in everyday life are one-sided and limited. At The Bellwether Project, our goal is radical nuance, which means that we dive deep into the human heart of our stories, and find the complexity that lies in their core. We have progressive values of inclusion and diverse representation, which will shine through the artists we have onstage. 

We have launched 3 world premieres, two dance pieces, and a web-series in the 4 years that we've been a company. We traveled to World War II USSR and met the first all-female regiment in military history, we created a time-traveling immersive dance club from multiple eras of the 20th century, and we met the children of undocumented immigrants living in fear in modern-day America. As we plant our roots as a company, our aesthetic is deepening, our growing audience larger, and our stories more complex. We are hoping to continue to expand on all of these values with hundreds more untold stories to come.

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you aren't able to contribute, but would still like to help, here are some ways to lend a hand:

  • Share us on social media!
  • Join our mailing list by emailing: bellwether.theatre.project@gmail.com
  • Tell your friends about this campaign -if everyone we knew donated $1, we'd be able to fairly compensate all of our artists, and have an incredible artistic launch as an inspired young company!

story:
“Profoundly moving... An action packed celebration of life’

BBC Radio 4, John Wilson on The Nature of Forgetting

The Company

Theatre Re is a London-based international ensemble creating thought-provoking, tangible and poignant work. Its shows examine fragile human conditions, in a compelling, physical style embracing mime, theatre and live music. The name of the company comes from the prefix ‘re’. It is the ‘re’ of re-discovering and re-imagining, breathing new life into what already exists.

Since 2011, Theatre Re’s productions have engaged 121 artists, reached over 21,400 people and engaged 3,113 participants. Theatre Re’s Blind Man’s Song and The Nature of Forgetting both premiered as part of the London International Mime Festival (LIMF’15 and LIMF’17). The Nature of Forgetting was part of the British Council Edinburgh Showcase 2017 and will tour extensively nationally (West Yorkshire Playhouse, The Lowry, The Gulbenkian, The Maclive, Tobacco Factory Theatres) and internationally (Brazil, Peru, USA, South-Korea, Taiwan, China, France) in 2018 and 2019.

Theatre Re is an @Home Company at The Point, Eastleigh and an Associate Company at South Hill Park Arts Centre, Bracknell.

Previous productions include: The Nature of Forgetting (2017-2018), Blind Man’s Song (2015-2016), The Little Soldiers (2013-2014), The Gambler (2011-2013), Your Letter, At Last! (2009-2011) and gLoved (2009-2010).

www.retheatre.com | @TheatreRe | facebook.com/retheatre | instagram.com/theatrere

Support So Far

Funded by Arts Council England through Grant for the Arts

Co-commissioned by The London International Mime Festival, The Point Eastleigh and South Hill Park Arts Centre

Supported by Shoreditch Town Hall and Haringey Council.

What we want to do:

With Birth, the main question leading our research is: what is it that we carry deep down within ourselves from the very beginning?

Diving into a world of myths, legends, folk songs and taking inspiration from the fields of neurodevelopment and psychogenealogy, we are exploring pregnancy loss, family memory and what is passed down from one generation to the next.

Through the portrayal of one woman’s journey through birth, we are developing a powerfully sensitive piece of visual theatre about unconditional love, loss, family memory, the future, and being on a precipice.

Following an initial three-week rehearsal period across November 2017 and March 2018 in Eastleigh at The Point and in London at Shoreditch Town Hall, Birth will be developed for another 3 weeks at The Point and South Hill Park Arts Centre (Bracknell) in June and July 2018.

Work-in-progress showcases will be organised at The Point (Creation Space) on July 6th, at South Hill Park Arts Centre on July 12th and at St Ann's Library (Haringey) on July 13th. We will also be organizing free work-in-progress showings at the end of June (see our website for more information). 

How we are working:

We are working with a large team of collaborators backstage as well as on stage: performers, musicians, composer, dramaturg, designers and choreographer as well as with Neuroscience UCL Professor Kate Jeffery, Reverend Professor June Boyce-Tillman and organisation Anyone Everymum. The role of these precious collaborators will be to inform and challenge the development of the work at various key stages. We will also engage with various members of the community through workshops, discussions, showings and feedback sessions with the objective being to link all our research to the real human experience.

Corporeal Mime vocabulary and technique will be the foundation of our creative work and we will keep strengthening and challenging our aesthetic through the use of live music, sounds, light, costumes, props and set, as well as a strong dramaturgy.

What We Need

Now that we have established links with supporters of the project, developed a timeline, appointed a strong team and started the devising process, we are seeking a little help from you to complete our budget.

Donations will contribute towards the costs of costumes, props, set, transportation and artistic fees.

Other Ways You Can Help

Another way to support the company is to come and see our work! Beyond that, if you are able and willing please help us to promote our shows through word of mouth, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and any other way you can possibly think of!

The Creative Team

Conceived & Directed by Guillaume Pigé

Devised by the Company

Composer - Alex Judd

Lighting Designer - Katherine Graham

Costume & Prop Designer - Malik Ibheis

Dramaturg - Tamara von Werthern

Scientific Collaborator - UCL Professor Kate Jeffery

External Advisor - Josephine Tremelling of Everyone Everymum

External Eye - Professor Reverend June Boyce-Tillman (MBE)

Set building - The Scenery Workshop

Performers: Louise Wilcox, Eygló Belafonte, Stefanie Bruckner, Alex Judd, Andres Velasquez, Charles Sandford

Devising cast: Louise Wilcox, Eygló Belafonte, Stefanie Bruckner, Alex Judd, Andres Velasquez, Charles Sandford, Matthew Austin.

Photo: François Verbeek

Video: Danilo Moroni

story:
"Allons! the road is before us!  I give you my hand! Will you give me yourself?  Will you come travel with me? Shall we stick by each other as long as we live?”         

-- Walt Whitman, Song of the Open Road

Dear friends, loved ones and future friends,

We've made theatre in laundry rooms, in attics, in back yards, living rooms, theatres in Athens and theaters in Brooklyn, pubs in London, barns in Maine, studios in universities and museums in North Carolina. And on Skype. What we've been trying to figure out is how to stay together when we're not together geographically. And when we are together, how does our traveling together change us. Change our work, our process and our relationships with the audiences we meet along the way. 

 

With each journey on the road, we get better. Better at being an ensemble. Better at listening to each other, better at listening to the audience. Better at sharing and understanding why we do what we do. Every audience in every town and city we visit offers us a new perspective. And makes us work harder to find that ease of trust and human connection. And to find more love. 

THE OUT WEST TOUR | Summer 2018

We are working on an original play called Come Out of the Storm inspired by Shakespeare’s King Lear. Last year, we toured our 2-man Antony & Cleopatra along the East Coast and touched hearts in places of the world we least expected. We saw how our work affected people where such theatre as we make often isn’t available. 

For summer 2018, the west is summoning us. Our plan is to make a 2-week road trip tour, beginning in Cold Spring, NY and drive to Boise, ID and back. Stopping along the way to share our shows. We are plotting our journey as this campaign launches. New Orleans, Kansas, Montana, California...it's a long list.

We’ve always shared our plays directly with people who were willing to listen. We don’t like to filter anything we do and we think that we have something worth sharing and we want to give it away to as many people as we can.

As a fully nomadic company at heart and in structure, it’s just the three of us. Making theatre that is unique and truthful and that we know people respond to.

How far we get out West depends on how much money we raise. We are currently contacting theaters and friends and are welcoming invitations to perform where you are. Contact us and let's work out how we can perform where you are on our Out West tour! Both ANTONY & CLEOPATRA and/or COME OUT OF THE STORM are available.

WHAT YOUR SUPPORT MEANS TO US

We've never made a profit on any of our shows, usually offering our shows for free or through donations. We've never rented a theater space, having been fortunate in the generosity of strangers and friends. We'd like to continue with that model on our Out West tour. Our goal is to raise $5000 to cover:

  • TRAVEL. This is our primary cost. For our previous tours, we've mostly been able to fund it ourselves with our own resources and through the generosity of those who have invited us to their homes and theaters. But this is an ambitious adventure.
    • Ronald's air travel to and from the Czech Republic and the United States
    • Gas, food, lodging (as needed) for 2 weeks as we drive from Cold Spring, NY to Boise, Idaho, stopping along the way out and back to share our shows.
  • PRODUCTION COSTS - We have little to no production overhead as our aesthetic does not rely on elaborate props, sets, costumes. It's just us up there, creating the atmosphere with our bodies, our own music, sharing our story with the audience. But we might need a few things for our productions, like Luke's been wearing the same costume pants for 3 years, he could use a new pair.

WHAT WE HOPE YOU GET FROM THIS

  • Your contribution will be reflected in audiences’ appreciation across the width of the US. 
  • Think of us as a messenger from Shakespeare’s plays: delivering what you value to people you may never have the chance to meet face to face, through the theatre we make.
  • We will be documenting our journey in a travel log that you can follow along with!
  • We have some perks, too. 

If you know someone who has a theater, a backyard, a living room who'd like to see our shows, we'd love to talk to them, put us in touch!  Contact Colleen at colleen@duomuzi.com.

Thank you for believing in us. Thank you for your generosity. 

See you on the road.

Love, Colleen, Ron, and Luke

Duomuži is Colleen Sullivan, Ronald Prokeś and Luke Robbins. Colleen splits her time between Washington DC where she teaches theater at American University and New York where she lives and makes theater. Ronald is from the Czech Republic, currently living in New York where he is working on his MFA at NYU Tisch.  Luke is from North Carolina, currently living in the Boston, MA area, where he teaches theater to aspiring very young actors. We've made three shows together -- Antony & Cleopatra, Continue (devised piece about the Wright Brothers) and Come Out of the Storm (in progress, premiering summer 2018). With each piece we make we try our best to stay true to an aesthetic that insists on truth and integrity and a desire to deepen our understanding of how an ensemble works. To learn more about us and what we've been up to, please visit our website www.duomuzi.com. 

 

--------------------------------------

Duomuži is a fiscally sponsored project of FRACTURED ATLAS, a 501(c)(3) public charity. Contact Colleen (colleen@duomuzi.com) if you're interested in making a Tax-Deductible Donation through Fractured Atlas.

campaign_city: Cold Spring (and other places), United States

story:
What is You Don’t Know Jack

You Don't Know Jack (YDKJ) is Jack Golden’s memoir show, shared with the audience through a variety of performance styles, including storytelling, improvisation, dance, mime, song, and physical comedy.  Jack is a philosopher clown; in his show he takes you to a South Carolina golf course, his brother’s hospital room, a barbeque joint outside of Houston, and the enchanted edge of life itself. With balance and precision, YDKJ dances on the fluid boundary between the personal and the universal.

Jack’s bag of tricks is full of gifts from a lifetime of performing; through masterful craft he knits you into his yarns.  The journey of the artist becomes the journey of the audience.  You will laugh, you will cry, you will find yourself in that sweet paradox where loss becomes discovery and the absurd reveals the profound.

Jack performed YDKJ to great acclaim at the Shea Theater and Arts Center in Turners Falls MA in June 2017.  Friends and acquaintances found their own lives reflected on Jack’s stage; found the funny side of shared struggles and the vein of love that carries us through the hard times.  They pushed him to expand his horizons and explore taking YDKJ on the road, to other places and other audiences.

Will YDKJ resonate with spectators far from home?  Will it mean as much to people who don’t know jack about Jack?  He has decided to find out, and venture out by packing up his bags, and his baggage, and heading out to the Baltimore Fringe Festival in November.

The ask

However, as with many explorations, funding is needed. I am asking if you’d like to help me on this voyage to the historic port of Baltimore.

Fringe festivals are great at connecting artists to audiences in intimate and exciting venues. However, especially, if you are traveling, the costs generally exceed income. I am hoping to raise between $1,300 and $2,000. Here is a breakdown of estimated expense and income:

My expenses are $2,000

$700   Travel

$500   Administration (including registration, insurance)

$600   Promotion

$200   Technical support

My estimated income from ticket sales is $700.

So as a minimum, if I could raise $1,300, combined with ticket sales, I’d cover my expenses.

If I could raise $2,000, I’d be able to pay myself through the ticket sales, which would be great!

Any addition monies raised over that amount would go towards funding future fringe festival voyages.

Who is Jack

Jack Golden began his career as an actor-mime-juggler-movement artist, improvisor and clown in 1983. He has been the featured clown with the Pickle Family Circus of San Francisco and a founding member of The Wright Brothers, a new vaudeville touring company that was voted “Best of Fest” at the 1987 International Clown and Mime Festival and went on to perform at Lincoln Center in NYC .

In 1989 he embarked on a solo career that has led him to create and perform several award winning, nationally touring shows.

More recently, he played Atigonus in John Bechtold’s “The Winters Tale” and Custodian of the Night in Bechtold’s “Deus Ex Machina” as well as creating and performing “You Don’t Know Jack”.

He studied physical theater and improvisation extensively with the world-renowned director and performer, Tony Montanaro. In addition he has trained with the San Francisco School of Dramatic Arts.

He has taught physical theater and improvisation at Savannah College of Arts and Design, New England Center for Circus Arts, the University of Massachusetts and Boston University.

Risks and Challenges

With any project there are risks and challenges and there is no exception here. However, due to the fact that I have already created and performed (the show premiered at the Shea Theater and Arts Center in Turners Falls MA, June 2-4, 2017) and have years of experience touring with my own productions, I feel that these risks are minimal. The show has been written and performed. I have been accepted and scheduled at the Maryland Art Place in Baltimore. The biggest challenge will be to spread the word to generate an audience.

story:
Bref résumé

QUI SOMMES-NOUS?

CréActifs est une compagnie de théâtre qui a émergé du constat que l’aspect « production » est souvent absent des activités culturelles de loisirs. Notre approche part du principe que c’est à travers le regard d’un public que l’acte créateur prend véritablement son sens et devient ainsi un acquis réel pour le participant. Pour cette raison, nous investissons les fonds que nous recevons envers la location d’une salle et la création de décors et costumes. Le mandat de CréActifs est d’être ouvert à tout participant en quête de créativité et de leur donner les outils, la structure et le support nécessaires pour nourrir celle-ci, non seulement à travers l’acquisition de « compétences » artistiques, mais, aussi et surtout, en développant un sentiment d’accomplissement par l’aboutissement d’un projet complet. Notre mission est de créer des productions communautaires inclusives et immersives qui valorisent les talents de chacun et utilisent les ressources disponibles. Cette dernière année, Julien a passé le flambeau de la production à Anne-Marie St-Louis, une jeune metteure en scène émergente dans le domaine du théâtre d’intervention. En tant qu'artiste menant ce projet, les objectifs personnels d’Anne-Marie sont de déconstruire les notions préconçues de représentation, de culture et d’identité et de s’investir dans les communautés défavorisées. Elle conçoit la performance comme un acte de revendication  puissant et poétique qui se doit d'engager le spectateur directement et de provoquer la réflexion. 

QUE FAIT-ON?

Après une fructueuse résidence artistique en campagne ainsi que des mois de répétitions, de recherche et d’écriture CréActifs présentera Le meilleur des mondes du 26 au 28 janvier 2017. La motivation principale derrière cette production est un questionnement absurde et satirique sur le plaisir. Nous voulions examiner les « cultures de masse » et réévaluer l’obsession contemporaine avec le divertissement et la stimulation constante. À travers cette adaptation, nous espérions commencer à mieux comprendre la société de consommation dans laquelle nous vivons. Comment peut-on concevoir autrement l’art du  « blockbuster » du   « best-seller» et du  «single»   qui attire des foules avec sa promesse utopique d’évasion et de distraction? Comment peut-on concevoir autrement l’idée de divertir le spectateur ?

AVEC
Emna Benjelli, Alaïs Berger, Karine Boillat-Madfouny, Louise Caron, Maëlle Campagnie, David Fornari, Lucas Gizard, Alice Hinchliffe, Samita Mandjee, Clara-Marie Nasser et  Katia Sviderskaya

 Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

 Nous sommes ambitieux et bien que nous soyons de jeunes artistes nous cherchons toujours le résultat le plus professionnel et approfondi possible. Ainsi, ce projet encourt des dépenses considérables pour des étudiants à revenu modique. Nombreux parmi nous contribuons plus de 10 heures par semaine à ce projet sans rémunération pour notre travail. C’est pour cette raison que nous sollicitons votre aide! Cette contribution de votre part ajouterait de la valeur à notre spectacle, ce qui attirerait un plus grand public et faciliterait la possibilité que le spectacle soit remonté dans le futur. Votre contribution irait donc vers l'achat de matériaux pour les décors et costumes qui sont essentiels à la réalisation de notre vision.

Cela dit, si nous ne parvenons pas à notre objectif visé de 1000$, les fonds seront mis vers la location de la salle car notre priorité est d'aboutir notre projet coûte que coûte, afin qu'artistes et spectateurs puissent se rencontrer, se questionner et discuter de leur compréhension du monde.

Pour vous remercier de votre implication et de votre générosité, nous sommes prêts à vous faire parvenir par courrier ou en personne quelques petites surprises originales! Cliquez dans l’onglet de droite pour en savoir plus.

 L'impact

En contribuant à cette campagne, vous soutenez une troupe d'étudiants montréalais qui cherchent à rêver et créer ensemble, vous soutenez du théâtre qui est non seulement nouveau mais novateur, qui veut promouvoir une égalité sociale diverse, qui veut reconnaître la puissance libératrice des individus qui choisissent de se définir eux-même. Vous soutenez des artistes dynamiques qui dévouent cœurs et âmes à ce projet. Vous soutenez des créateurs qui prennent conscience du monde dans lequel ils vivent et veulent éveiller cette conscience chez les autres.

 Risques et défis

 Nous sommes une compagnie toute jeune mais très dynamique!  Nouveaux sur la scène montréalaise, nous cherchons à nous démarquer et à accueillir tous ceux en quête d'une communauté artistique. Nous voulons prendre certains risques artistiques et ne pas nous complaire: nous voulons pousser la limite de notre zone de confort et expérimenter de nouvelles formes... Le théâtre nous passionne et même si nous n'avons pas toutes les réponses, nous essayons de poser les bonnes questions. 

Le principal défi de notre travail est de le faire volontairement. Comme nous ne sommes pas soutenus par un théâtre établi, nous devons trouver et aménager nous-même une salle de représentation adéquate, créer nos propres campagnes de publicité et de sensibilisation et trouver nos propres subventions. Ce n'est pas toujours facile d'équilibrer notre vision idéale du projet avec la réalité concrète de nos moyens et notre situation financière !

 D'autres façons d'aider

Nous apprécions énormément votre intérêt pour notre troupe et notre projet! C'est entièrement grâce a vous, grâce à votre participation, à vos "likes" sur Facebook et à votre encouragement que nous arrivons à progresser et présenter une production finale sur la scène Montréalaise. 

Si vous êtes incapables de faire un don financier mais cherchez d'autres manières de vous impliquer avec CréActifs, soyez rassurés car nous avons quelques options alternatives. 

Vous pouvez par exemple:

  • partager notre lien indiegogo avec d'autres
  • aimer notre page Facebook
  • parler de notre production imminente à vos proches
  • surtout, vous pouvez nous soutenir en vous joignant à nous le 26, 27 et 28 janvier

Pour plus d'information sur la compagnie CreActifs, vous pouvez consultez notre site web a l’adresse suivante : http://creactifs.net/

story:
Meet the Creative Team

Lindsay Bartlette Allen is a Co-Writer/Co-Producer/Actor for Survivor Story: A Workshop. Lindsay is an actor, director and producer who has worked with Adirondack Shakespeare Company, Accidental Shakespeare Co. (NY), The Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey, Pride Films & Plays, the Chicago Fringe Festival, and Waltzing Mechanics. Since 2013 she has been producing her own work in both New York and Chicago under her own theatre company, Transcendent Ensemble Theatre. SURVIVOR STORY is Lindsay's passion project. The musical focuses on her own sexual assault experience in which Lindsay plays herself. Lindsay is a graduate of the University of Alabama at Birmingham with a BA in Theatre Performance. Lindsay dedicates this show to her fellow "survivor sisters"... to those she's know for years, those she's just met, and those she hopes to meet throughout the making of this project. lindsaybartletteallen.com

Rachel Page is the Composer/ Co-Writer/ Actor for Survivor Story: A workshop. Rachel Page is a performer, pianist and voice teacher.  She has performed and taught all over the country.  Rachel has been a part of Second City TourCo (including two contracts on Norwegian Cruise Line), Underscore Theatre, Windy City Music Theatre, Lifeline Theatre, Fox Valley Repertory Theatre, to name a few.  Rachel is also part of the cabaret duo Side By Side and owns her own vocal studio. When not on stage she can be found on her piano bench, telling her students to stop breathing so much.  rachelpagesings.com

​Moira Begale is a  Co-Producer/ Actor for Survivor Story: A workshop. Moira is an actor/producer/fighter and has performed in various storefront theaters in Chicago, some of them include WildClaw Theatre, Akvavit Theatre, Pride Films and Plays, Otherworld Theatre Company and Babes with Blade.  During the day, she is a producer for corporate events at Dave and Co. and at night is a proud ensemble member of Otherworld Theatre Company (Sci-Fi and Fantasy) and the Managing Director of WildClaw Theatre (Horror).  She is represented by Stewart Talent Agency and has appeared in several commercials, industrials and short films.  She received her BS in Theater/Acting at Illinois State University, and has focused her theatrical studies in the Meisner technique at Black Box Acting Studio.    

What is SURVIVOR STORY, and Our Goals

Our goal is to raise money to workshop a musical that will spread awareness of sexual assault and rape. We are planning a four-performance workshop to be presented at the Athenaeum Theatre on Southport Avenue in Chicago featuring three talk-back sessions following performances. We plan to develop the musical more this workshop and mount a full production in 2018.

Inspired by true events, two Chicago women with hope on the horizon are dealt a blow they never imagined. Although they never meet, they share the same fears and face similar trials as they each deal with the aftermath of their own experiences.  As the story unfolds we are left with the question: if you knew the stranger next to you, how much would you have in common? ​

 

Why This Project is Important

We hope that by sharing this story it will empower victims to recognize they are survivors and will share their story in order to continue our theme of 'you/they are not alone'.  By providing awareness and connection we hope that the existing statistics of victims will change and that survivors will actively seek out ways to educate and enlighten individuals just how big of an issue sexual assault and rape are today.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our Budget 

Perks for YOU!

$10 - Personal video shout out of thanks

$25 - Shoutout in the program and mention in social media

$50 - Shoutout in the program, mention in social media, and special thanks given at the top of the show!

$100 -  Signed show poster, all other benefits prior to $100 included.

$250 - A VIP ticket to our workshop, all other benefits prior to $250 included.

$500 - Attend a rehearsal, all other benefits prior to $500 included.

$1,000 - Producer credit and radio-based commercial at the beginning of the show.  You and a guest, invite to the opening night party.  All other benefits prior to $1,000 included.  

If we do not reach our entire goal, the money raised will still go to the project. This would mean we will cut our budget to maintain between the parameters of what is readily available.  It's very important to us that our artists are paid for their work! By donating, you're not only becoming part of the cause, but you're also contributing to the pockets of professional actors, musicians, directors, creative, and designers that make this work possible!

 

The Impact

Sexual Violence Can Have Long-Term Effects on Victims.  The likelihood that a person suffers suicidal or depressive thoughts increases after sexual violence.  By putting these sexually violent stories to music we hope to connect to a wider audience of survivors and give them courage to share their story.  Once shared we believe it will contribute to educating the public so that there are less attacks.

Past successes with Fundraising by Our Creative Team

Producer, Moira Begale, raised a successful 10K campaign for Cheap Plastic Mask through Seed and Spark.

Producer, Lindsay Bartlette Allen, raised $5,000 for her theatre company.  It was an Equity showcase performance in New York.  An ensemble, movement-based adaptation of Titus Andronicus that focused on the aftermath of Lavinia's assault.

 

Risks & Challenges

This subject has saturated the media and world, but the truth is it is still not being dealt with in a kind manner.  Our qualifying factor is that we are telling a true story that is a part of the process to help start a conversation and provide togetherness/network for a group that feels they are alone.  

Through music we hope to break down emotional barriers and societal walls regarding assault and rape.  We are truly trying to create a vulnerable space to share stories and connect with each other in order to heal.

$250 - A VIP ticket to our workshop, all other benefits prior to $250 included.
$500 - Attend a rehearsal, all other benefits prior to $500 included.
$1,000 - Producer credit and radio-based commercial at the beginning of the show.  You and a guest, invite to the opening night party.  All other benefits prior to $1,000 included.  
If we do not reach our entire goal, the money raised will still go to the project. This would mean we will cut our budget to maintain between the parameters of what is readily available.  It's very important to us that our artists are paid for their work! By donating, you're not only becoming part of the cause, but you're also contributing to the pockets of professional actors, musicians, directors, creative, and designers that make this work possible!
 

The Impact
Sexual Violence Can Have Long-Term Effects on Victims.  The likelihood that a person suffers suicidal or depressive thoughts increases after sexual violence.  By putting these sexually violent stories to music we hope to connect to a wider audience of survivors and give them courage to share their story.  Once shared we believe it will contribute to educating the public so that there are less attacks.
Past successes with Fundraising by Our Creative TeamProducer, Moira Begale, raised a successful 10K campaign for Cheap Plastic Mask through Seed and Spark.
Producer, Lindsay Bartlette Allen, raised $5,000 for her theatre company.  It was an Equity showcase performance in New York.  An ensemble, movement-based adaptation of Titus Andronicus that focused on the aftermath of Lavinia's assault.
 

Risks & Challenges
This subject has saturated the media and world, but the truth is it is still not being dealt with in a kind manner.  Our qualifying factor is that we are telling a true story that is a part of the process to help start a conversation and provide togetherness/network for a group that feels they are alone.  
Through music we hope to break down emotional barriers and societal walls regarding assault and rape.  We are truly trying to create a vulnerable space to share stories and connect with each other in order to heal.

story:
Short Summary

We are a brand new theatre company striving to make a name for ourselves in the Chicago theatre scene by providing honest and approachable contemporary musical theatre. Theatre, to us, is about community and people connecting with people. RTP was founded by Morgan Briggs, Ross Egan, Casey Shipman and Mike Evans.

Our campaign will help fund our debut show, Next Thing You Know, and give us the footing we need for a second show next summer! 

Next Thing You Know runs February 14-March 8 Friday & Saturday 8pm and Sunday 6pm 

Funding us is vital to the survival of our company and will give RTP the chance to show the Chicago community why theatre is for everyone.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $5,000 toward our performance space, funding musicians, rights and royalties.  Below is a conservative budget for entire show, so you can see why we need your help!

Performance Space  $ 3,200

Rehearsal Space  $ 1,200

Royalties  $ 1,000

Marketing and PR  $ 800

Production Materials  $ 500

Musicians  $ 500

Because we are a brand new company, by contributing, you get to be a part of our journey on the ground floor and a key to our success.

Not to mention, Next Thing You Know's writer Ryan Cunningham will be involved in our production!
If RTP does not reach its $5,000 goal, the show must go on, but it will go on through our own, tiny pockets.

The Impact

Next Thing You Know is a show very true to RTP's own journey. We are four 20 somethings trying to follow our dreams and spread understanding and equality through musical theatre, the same way we all came together. You can be a part of a moment when the frivolities and distractions of the world were combated with true human connection.

Other Ways You Can Help

If, for whatever reason, you don't want to contribute to our mission, please share our campaign with anyone and everyone you know! And feel free to contact us if you are interested in volunteering your services etc!
