story:
The Residency

Yuli Kovbasnian and Julia Gladstone have been invited by renowned Tel Aviv-based choreographer Yasmeen Godder to embark on a residency in her studio for four weeks, to teach a workshop that invites participants into the world and techniques of their practice, and to premiere their work in a split bill performance on January 17. While Yasmeen has generously offered free use of her studio space for our rehearsals and performance, WE NEED YOUR HELP to raise funds to cover our travel and housing during the residency.

About the Artists

Born in Russia in 1986, Yuli Kovbasnian immigrated to Israel in 2001 and holds a Bachelor of Education in dance from Seminar Hakibutzim College. She was a dancer in Arkadi Zaides piece Land-Research, which premiered at Fabric Potsdam in May 2012. Since then, Yuli has collaborated with various choreographers from Israel and abroad. In May 2013, she presented a solo work, State of Matter at Driven Festival for Contemporary Dance. Yuli is currently studying towards an M.A. in Gender Studies at Tel-Aviv University. In 2013 Yuli was awarded the danceWEB scholarship at ImPulsTanz Vienna International Dance Festival. Currently, Yuli collaborates with Swiss visual artist Celine Manz on the project Online, a Skype-based collaboration that fuses their two disciplines.

Julia Gladstone is a movement, video, and visual artist from Massachusetts. Her work takes interest in locating the animation of the artificial, and the inorganic within the living. She has collaborated on multi-media projects with many artists internationally. Most recently, Julia performed in D21 choreographed by Yuli Kovbasnian and The Multiple choreographed by Aretha Aoki. She premiered her new solo work 1 1/2 at a Workbench showing in Northampton, MA, and her most recent work, CLUB TROPICANA, was developed through the Choreographic Module at Ponderosa. As a dance videographer, she has worked for Jacob's Pillow, Bates Dance Festival, and Ponderosa, and received her Bachelor of Arts from Hampshire College in 2012. Julia is currently living in Detroit, Michigan, collaborating with visual and culinary artist Nicholas Hurwitz-Goodman on a drawing series inspired by instruction manuals.

All Pathologies, Concept and Methods

We propose to choreograph a duet movement performance during this residency. Expanding upon the performative research methods that we have generated together in past projects D21 and CLUB TROPICANA, which centered around alienation and abandonment respectively, we will devise a new work catalyzing from the concept of "pathology."

Pathology, defined as a mental, social, or physical malfunction, or the typical behavior of a disease, is also a compound of the terms pathos and logos. If pathos speaks to the world of emotion and logos to the creation of order, we are interested in pursuing pathology as "the choreography of emotion". 

We are attempting to inhabit the interior of relationship structures without becoming subjects. Through subtle body language and ecstatic quirks, we unleash and arrange the repressed contents of the psychic body. Our work lies in this task of embodying state, emotion, and relationship without becoming human. What happens when we exceed the body or articulate only a microscopic part? How might a memory relate to a piece of bacteria, an emotion to an organ? We must design the codes of conduct.

Taking inspiration from choreographic structures of disease patterns and the logics of infection and mental illness, we will research new architectures of interaction through which to reveal both order and chaos, alienation and inclusion, intimacy and abandon.

As we have done in our past collaborations, we will gather improvised movement material from original scores, and then arrange, cut up, infect, disturb, cradle and poison it until it becomes resonant.

A NOTE OF APPRECIATION: This project originates from a history of important performative research this past August with a group of amazing performers and collaborators who will remain with us energetically in this work, and physically in future collaborations. Endless nods go to the members of CLUB TROPICANA: Yoav Admoni, Mor Demer, and Micheál Rowsome. And to the members of D21: Caitlin Hafer and Monika Smekot. An enormous THANK YOU for the dramaturgical support of Jassem Hindi, Stephanie Maher, and Maria F. Scaroni. And to Nicholas Hurwitz-Goodman, thank you for your brilliant artistic donations to this fundraiser.

A Contested Site

We feel that our artistic research into the structures of alienation and pathology carries particular resonance in the complex political climate of the Near East region in Israel. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is characterized by violence regarding the limits and borders of Palestinian and Israeli bodies and identities; the politics of belonging pose literal physical crises. The concept of statehood can be seen as an attempt to make solid a complete body, rendering those outside the state incomplete, pathologic, and alien. The negotiation of and extreme violence over territory throws into question the possibility of closure and brings to fore essential questions about home and humanity.

Recognizing the serious dangers that Palestinians and Israelis are faced with in the heat of conflict, we are planning to spend time listening deeply to the experiences of people affected by violence, and to bring that listening directly into the conditions of our studio practice. 

The Importance of Experimental Movement Performance

Art provides a reflective and resonant space where invented rules, logics, and values have space to breathe new possibilities back into "reality." Within our artistic practice, we play, question, and imagine the possibility of things operating differently. Importantly, art makes room for the absurd, the senseless, and the impossible to emerge, and for rules to collapse. As the artists of this project, we are not proposing to solve anything, nor are we telling you that we could ever really "understand" another person's experience. Instead, we will attempt to listen deeply and to explore the space of partiality. We believe that the methods, techniques, and practices of performance are ones that work to engage critically, swim in the unknown, imagine change, and question the conditions of being present together.

A Lack of Funding <> Hope For the Future

The sustainability of experimental dance is in danger today due to a lack of funding. We believe that there is immense value in the medium of live movement performance. However, because dance doesn't result in commodifiable or easily reproducible objects, but instead takes the form of fleeting physical languages, it has suffered from a lack of legibility, scholarship, and funding. 
WE REALLY NEED YOUR HELP to sustain, validate, and support the value of live movement performance!

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to raise $2,200 to cover the costs of travel to and from Tel Aviv and to rent a shared room in the city during the month-long residency period. If there are any remaining funds, that money will go directly towards costumes, set, props, promotion, and photography.

WE ARE SO EXCITED TO SHARE AN AMAZING ARRAY OF HANDMADE AND PERSONALIZED GIFTS WITH YOU, DONATED IN PART BY THE TALENTED NICHOLAS HURWITZ-GOODMAN! CHECK THEM OUT ON THE RIGHT:>:>:>:>

SHARE!

First of all, THANK YOU for reading this far and for taking interest in our project. We appreciate all of your support, whether it is energetic, financial, or social. To that end, if you wish to support this project but may not feel able to contribute financially, then simply consider sharing this page with others! It really makes an impact!

story:
“It seems to me, Tilly, that you don’t want to get better.  It seems to me that you enjoy this ‘melancholy’ of yours.  In fact, you seem proud of it.  A little vain, even.  It is my professional opinion that you feed your melancholy little sweetmeats, that you comb it, groom it, keep it as a pet dog.” 

Sarah Ruhl remains a gift to contemporary theatre with her funny, fantastical and poetic plays.  Melancholy Play, a contemporary farce with music, unravels society’s fear and judgment of deep human emotion. 

It is with great pleasure that The Empty Room presents Sarah Ruhl’s Melancholy Play and furthers the much-needed discussion of mental health and depression in our city. 

How We Came To Be

After spending a month training with the renowned SITI Company in Saratoga Springs, NY, Jeffrey Pufahl and Eva Barrie ventured down to Central Park to celebrate Canada Day.  Amidst the lack of Canadian celebrations they began discussing how wonderful it would be to bring their shared training and collaborative theatre philosophy back to Canada.  Jeff then hurried off to Saskatchewan, while Eva settled back into Toronto and the two began exchanging ideas of what play would excite and challenge them most.  Upon finding Melancholy Play, their minds were made up. 

Eva then called upon the producing powers of Edward Hillier, the Artistic Director of The Empty Room (Journey’s End, Under Milk Wood) who immediately fell in love with the play.  Through a Skype meeting with members calling in from Canada, England and Mexico, the decision to take on this bold play was made.

    The Project

    Melancholy Play will be a play like no other.  We are a mix of emerging and established artists from across the country.  We believe in the power of collaborative processes and the beauty of multidisciplinary work.  Our space is the stunning Collective Space in Toronto's West End, traditionally a dance/aerial space, that we are filling with poetry, laughter and a live cello score, created by the prolific Michael Roth. 


    We Need Your Help To Bring Melancholy Play to Life!

    We are asking for $3200.  This money will be put toward:

    $1100 – The rights to Melancholy Play for eight performances. 

    $300 – The music rights to Michael Roth’s breathtaking cello/voice score. Mr. Roth has even offered to make himself available for rewrites, just for us!  Check out some of his previous works at http://rothmusik.wix.com/rothmusik

    $1800 – The cost of our amazing performance venue, the Collective Space in Toronto. We're very excited to have a relationship with the Collective Space, home of the Anandam Dancetheatre Company.  Melancholy Play is one of the first text-based plays to grace the space!

    Beyond raising the money for these costs, we're busily working to raise money for artist fees, rehearsal space, production costs, publicity, media materials and the list goes on! 

    The Artists

    Jeffrey Pufahl (Director, Producer)

    Jeffrey is a director, actor and singer from Saskatoon, SK.   In 2012 he received his MFA in Theatre Directing from the University of Victoria where his thesis project, Eurydice (Sarah Ruhl) garnered critical acclaim for its boldness and theatricality. Following that, he directed Sarah Ruhl's Dead Man's Cell Phone at Persephone Theatre.  Jeffrey was the artistic director for seven seasons at the Souris Valley Theatre and was the associate director for the Armonico Consort's highly acclaimed production of Purcell's The Fairy Queen which toured the UK for several years.  Other directing credits include: Fringe mega hit Caberlesque!, the touring production of Canada's Songbird: The Music of Anne Murray, and for the Globe Sandbox Series: Marg Szkaluba (Pissy's Wife).  Jeffrey wrote and directed three documentary films for the award winning television series Landing: Stories from the Cultural Divide.  An accomplished actor and singer, Jeffrey has performed in theatres across Canada.  www.jeffreypufahl.com

    Eva Barrie (Actor, Producer)

    Eva is happy to return to the Empty Room after performing in the company’s inaugural production of Under Milk Wood in 2011.  Originally from Okotoks, Alberta, she is currently a Toronto-based director, actor and creator and has created art in Germany, India, Italy, Poland, Canada and the States.  She is a graduate of Ryerson University’s Performance Acting Program and has trained with Anne Bogart’s SITI Company in Saratoga Springs, NY and New York City, NY.  In the fall of 2014, she has had the pleasure of being Co-Program Director of Nightwood Theatre’s Young Creators Lab.  Most recently, she played Brutus in Spur-of-the-Moment Shakespeare Collective’s Julius Caesar (director: Taryn Jorgenson).  She has directed diverse shows in Toronto, been a dramaturge for new works and has assisted directors such as Alan Dilworth (The Biographer).  She was lucky to have her play Olga read at Tarragon Theatre’s “Rehearsal Hall” (director: Andrea Donaldson). 

    Edward Hillier (Producer)
    Edward is originally from Nottingham, England, but has proudly been a Torontonian since 2006. He completed a BFA in Acting at Ryerson Theatre School, and is a founding member of The Empty Room Collective.  For The Empty Room: Under Milk Wood; Strange Things Done; Born Free* Elsewhere: The Campbell House Haunting (Guerrilla Theatre); Major Weir (RTS); Frayed (RTS). As an Actor: John, The Lover (3Peasants); Ferris, Hiatus (RTS); Matthias Kirsch, Leer (BergArts); Blakey, You Gotta Stay Cocksure (FilmCOOP).

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Follow us on Facebook and Twitter (@theemptyroom) so that you’ll get updates about the show, casting and our fundraisers!

    Help us spread the word about this amazing play by using the Indiegogo share tools!

    If you know any businesses that are looking for sponsorship/business opportunities, let us know by email at info@empty-room.com!

    Mark your calendars for our Opening Night on January 29th!  We’d love to have you there!

    A Huge Thank You To Those Who Helped With This Video!

    Faran Moradipour!  He, with his genius eye, filmed the majority of this video.  http://www.faranmoradipour.com/

    Simon Miminis!  Simon composed this beautiful music!  To hear other scores he has created, visit: http://www.simonmiminis.com/

    Jonah Greenbaum-Shinder! Jonah lent us his sound skills to record the voice over!

    Jordi Hyndman, Ashton Doudelet, Karen Slater, Anna Wheeler, Jesse Nerenberg and Kelci Stephenson! For providing various costume pieces, props and good-hearted help!

    Kate Condon Moriarty! For lending us her wheels (and her hands to drive) to various shooting locations!

us know by email at info@empty-room.com!
Mark your calendars for our Opening
Night on January 29th! 
We’d love to have you there!A Huge Thank You To Those Who Helped With This Video!
Faran Moradipour!  He, with his genius eye, filmed the majority of this video.  http://www.faranmoradipour.com/
Simon Miminis!  Simon composed this beautiful music!  To hear other scores he has created, visit: http://www.simonmiminis.com/
Jonah Greenbaum-Shinder! Jonah lent us his sound skills to record the voice over!
Jordi Hyndman, Ashton Doudelet, Karen Slater, Anna Wheeler, Jesse Nerenberg and Kelci Stephenson! For providing various costume pieces, props and good-hearted help!
Kate Condon Moriarty! For lending us her wheels (and her hands to
drive) to various shooting locations!

story:
What You See Is What You Get 

by Chan Sze-Wei with Kasia Witek and Chloe Abbot

The Place Theatre

Wednesday 2 December 2015, 4pm and 8pm

Do you remember the last time we were here, together? Sitting in the dark, breathing the same air. 
Trying to understand.
If only we could present to you something that you could use, just like one of those software platforms that hide all the complex machinery and just give you the illusions of the simple result. The ability to directly manipulate what you see: the reality of what we see and expect to see in the theatre. Manipulating the space we share between our bodies, our breath, two women, two wigs, and a trumpet.

Where your donations will go

The theatre venue, ticketing and technical support are provided by the London Contemporary Dance School. However this programme unfortunately isn't able to provide us with other resources! So far, we have secured a generous donation of rehearsal space for this two-month period. 

At this point, we could really use your help to support the 80-100 hours  that each of us is putting into making this project over two months! (That would otherwise be less creative but paid working time..)

This campaign target of £1260 includes:

Collaborator-Performers - £1050 (£350 each)

Production expenses (costumes, props, equipment rentals) - £150

Indiegogo fees (5%) £60


Other Ways You Can Help

Every contribution counts, no matter the amount or kind! 

We would be grateful for your help in getting the word out about this project and its fundraiser - share it on facebook, email and social networks. Our FB event is here.

And of course: Come see our show!  

This performance is part of a "multi-bill" with new short films from the LCDS Moving Image Collaborations project, where LCDS choreographers collaborate with students from the BA Graphic Design Moving Image from Central Saint Martins. Tickets and more details available from The Place. 


About Us

Chan Sze-Wei is an independent dance artist from Singapore, based in London. work melds improvisation, interactivity, dance installation, film, text and Asian traditional forms with an interest in the social sciences. She enjoys creating work that creates spaces for people to enter, in the theatre as well as outdoor and site-specific settings. She has shared work in Singapore, London, Taiwan, Laos and Indonesia, and participated in creations in Singapore and Europe, including Xavier le Roy, Charlotte Engelkes (SE), Ole Khamchanla (FR).

Polish-born London-based dance artist Katarzyna Witek is a graduate of the Northern School of Contemporary Dance (2009), Jasmin Vardimon's postgraduate diploma in Physical Theatre at Royal Holloway, University of London (2010) and London Contemporary Dance School (2015). As a dancer she has performed both within the UK and internationally and her choreographic work ranges between film, installation and theatre-based performances. Katarzyna has a particular interest in music and enjoys working closely with composers. She is also a part of a theatre music trio The Vanderbilts, which brings together performance art, dance, contemporary music and theatre; experimenting with breaking the boundaries between disciplines to create a world of it's own.

London based trumpet player Chloe Abbott graduated this year from the Guildhall School of Music and Drama having learnt with John Kenny, Noel Langley, Will O’Sullivan, Paul Beniston and Paul Cosh during her studies. Chloe has taken part in projects ranging from solo performances in character as a cowboy, to being part of an onstage band of Russian pioneers in Mikhalkov’s Burnt by the Sun. She has worked with directors such as Lucy Bailey, Jo Blatchley and Lore Lixenberg in exploring different ways musicians can be used on stage. Chloe is also very interested in creating her own music using electronics to create fresh sounds and ideas.

story:
A new story on the stage.

Life is a series of Flickers, moments of clarity. Two men meet and the effect they have on each other will make them question what they know and force them to find who they are.
Ryan Scully, a playwright based in Emporia, Kansas, has created a fascinating, funny new play with just a hint of surrealism to bring to the Kansas City Fringe Festival. With this piece, he hopes to further the LGBT cause by presenting a love story as just that: a love story.

Why we need your help.

In order to stage a show (any show!) a lot of things have to be in place, and Flicker is no different! Any contribution you make will be helping us tremendously with:

Props: while many props in our show can be pulled and borrowed, there are several that will have to be paid for. A little money can go a very long way here!

Set pieces: Flicker will be a bare-bones production, but even with as much elimination as we have done already, we still need a few set pieces in order to convey our setting as realistically as possible.

Travel expenses: Several of our actors are traveling from out of town because they are just that dedicated to this show. We would like to compensate them for all of that gas money that's currently coming right out of their own pockets!

Marketing: Each Kansas City Fringe Festival production is responsible for their own marketing platforms. Facebook and other social media marketing can take us a long way, but we want everyone to know about our show! Posters and postcards placed in local Kansas City businesses can take us so much farther!

The impact you will have.

The Kansas City metro has a magnificent, booming theatrical community. This cannot be understated! But having this many shows to see can come at a cost: some shows simply get lost in the shuffle. Even by simply considering a contribution to our show means that you are one more person who knows about us.

We are also determined to stage more realistic stories. There are many shows that contribute to great LGBT representation, and each one of them is important. What makes Flicker different is that the characters' homosexuality actually has nothing to do with the challenges they come across in this piece. We hope to help all audience members relate to LGBT struggles by showing them that most challenges in love are the same regardless of sexual preferences.

Other ways you can help.

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute financially, and that's okay! We hope our passion for this show has inspired you, so here are other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word! By sharing our campaign with others, we may reach our goal because more people are aware of it!
  • If you think you might have props or set pieces that you'd be willing to lend (or give!) to us, email us at flicker.fringe@gmail.com
  • Have a large rehearsal space we can use? Email us!
  • Finally, COME TO OUR SHOW! This is the absolute BEST way you can support us! Details are on our event Facebook page: Flicker Facebook Event Page


Thank you!

story:
Little Women: 

"Based on Louisa May Alcott's American classic, this Civil War story of love and family stands the test of time. This musical embodies the complete theatrical experience, guaranteeing a night filled with laughter, tears, and a lifting of the spirit."

Music & Lyrics: Jason Howland and Mindi Dickstein
Book: Allan Knee || based on Louisa May Alcott's novel Little Women 
Direction: Victoria Pearlman 
Musical Direction: Sasha Bartol 
Stage Management: Cary Reynolds  
Produced by Jackson Strike & Lucy Grebin 

PERFORMANCE DATES: 
April 7th @ 7:30pm
April 8th  @ 7:30pm & 11pm
April 9th  @ 2:30pm (understudy performance) & 7:30pm


Who are we?

MUSICAL THEATRE REPERTORY at USC

Musical Theatre Repertory at the University of Southern California was established in 2005 and is dedicated to enriching students’ lives through the production of quality musical theatre. Our goal is to provide students with the opportunity to participate in musical theatre pieces supplementary to those produced by USC. Find us online at www.uscmtr.com for general info about the company, ticketing details, upcoming events, production stills, and even a few production videos! Thank you for supporting the arts and we can't wait to see you at our upcoming shows!

                                     

                                      


What is Little Women?

Based on Louisa May Alcott's classic 1869 semi-autobiographical novel, it focuses on the four March sisters — brassy, tomboy-like, aspiring writer Jo, romantic Meg, pretentious Amy, and kind-hearted Beth — and their beloved Marmee, at home in Concord, Massachusetts while the family patriarch is away serving as a Union Army Chaplain during the Civil War. Intercut with the vignettes in which their lives unfold are several recreations of the melodramatic short stories Jo writes in her attic studio.

Why Little Women?

Little Women is the thrilling story of a girl defying society and gender norms in order to pursue her dreams and create a better life for her and her sisters. We are reminded of the importance of individuality and believing in oneself while simultaneously contemplating the meaning of family in our own lives. As we go through college, we constantly question the journey ahead of us. This musical invites us to create our own paths and to follow them no matter how daunting the odds. 


CAST: 

Marissa Dubois as Clarissa (U/S Jo)
Evangeline Edwards as Aunt March/The Troll 
Camille Gray as Hag (U/S Meg)
Danny Helms as Professor Bhaer 
Emily Hunter as Mrs. Kirk (U/S Marmie, Aunt March)
Aaron Jung as Braxton (U/S John)
Caitlin Kilgore as Beth March
Selene Klasner as Meg March 
Tiffany Maddahi as Rodrigo (U/S Beth, Amy) 
Massimo Napoli as Mr. Laurence/The Knight  
Sami Nye as Marmee March 
Sidne Phillips as Jo March  
Harrison Poe as Laurie Laurence 
Sean Soper as John Brooks 
Addy Stafford as Amy March 


PRODUCTION TEAM:

Direction: Victoria Pearlman  
Assistant Direction: Jack MaCarthy  
Music Direction: Sasha Bartol 
Stage Management: Cary Reynolds 

Assistant Stage Management: Sabrina Sonner  
Produced by Lucy Grebin & Jackson Strike 
Costumes: Rachel Mathieu  
Props: Mallory Gabbard  

Choreography: Sophie Thomason  
Scenic Design: Jess Peeters 
Sound Design: Jacob Magnin  
Technical Direction: Carla Rubio   


What We Need

MTR is run exclusively by USC students. Thus, we receive no outside support from faculty or professional companies.  Because our company is entirely student-run, every one of us puts in an enormous amount of time and effort in order to bring each of our productions to life. That being said, our financial resources are limited and we need help raising money for our production designers.  Funds we raise will be used for lighting, set, props, sound, and costumes. These design elements are vital not only in helping our production reach its full potential but also in providing design students with valuable production opportunities.  


The Impact

This campaign will drastically increase the caliber of our performance! We are so grateful for all the support we have received in the past. MTR has been producing musicals for and by the students for two decades now. If you would like to see production stills from previous performances, check out our website. 


Other ways to help! 

We hope to exceed $2,000 so please help us surpass our goal and bring this show to life! 

Whether you can offer financial support or not, please join us in the telling of this story April 7th through the 9th. We look forward to seeing you. 

You can also support us simply by spreading the word. Please share this page and find us on Facebook. 

We are always interested in getting other students involved in MTR. If you have any interest in joining our team, working on one of our shows, or getting some more information, email us at uscmtr@gmail.com. We would love to hear from you! 

Also check out our website at www.uscmtr.com

Thank you for supporting Musical Theatre Repertory!

We are also very thankful for the support of the USC Undergraduate Student Government.


Last but not least... PROGRAM ADS! 

We are selling AD space in our show program that will be distributed at every performance. Want to wish a cast member good luck? Are you a company looking to promote your own event? You've come to the right place. 

Contact Rebecca Mellinger, rmelling@usc.edu, to find out more!

We are always interested in getting other students involved in MTR. If you have any interest in joining our team, working on one of our shows, or getting some more information, email us at uscmtr@gmail.com. We would love to hear from you! 
Also check out our website at www.uscmtr.com
Thank you for supporting Musical Theatre Repertory!
We are also very thankful for the support of the USC Undergraduate Student Government.



Last but not least... PROGRAM ADS! 
We are selling AD space in our show program that will be distributed at every performance. Want to wish a cast member good luck? Are you a company looking to promote your own event? You've come to the right place.

story:
DEM is a new experimental play by Fulya Peker that will premiere in 2016, in Istanbul (and may get to NY after). It questions the dynamics of oppression and resistance, existence and survival from a procreative point of view. Imagine that you are only allowed to breathe every 30 seconds; imagine that any form of expression and communication that requires rapid respiration is banned such as to be afraid, to get angry, to laugh, to cry, to have sex; and imagine that the punishment of disobedience is death. How would you survive? How would you express yourself? How would you give birth to a form of language through which you can communicate with a forbidden future? How would you impregnate your self to create anew? 

KATHARSIS PERFORMANCE PROJECT is a New York and Istanbul based theater project founded by Fulya Peker in 2007. With its plays KPP tries to create metaphorical analogies between physiology and existential philosophy; to explore ecstatic states of human consciousness (fear, sexuality, cruelty) through new forms of textual, physical and vocal expressions while focusing on the relation between taboo and transgression; to experiment on the primal sensory connotations of language; and to invite the audience to a poetic and cathartic experience. Katharsis Performance Project is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. 

FULYA PEKER is a New York and Istanbul based theater artist and poet. She has performed in the works by the leading figures of experimental theater, dance and music such as Richard Foreman, John Zorn, Robert Ashley, Katsura Kan, David Michalek, Object Collection.  While presenting her own works as a writer and director, she also collaborated with fine arts, literature, and philosophy organizations on projects concerning the avant-garde. Her poems, translations, and articles on experimental theater were published both in Turkey and the USA. She is the founder and artistic director of Katharsis Performance Project and Modern Mythologies Project. Currently, she teaches in Istanbul and continues to present workshops and performances internationally. 

For more information: www.fulyapeker.com

(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N2__fUDkedQ)

A letter from Fulya Peker

Dear friends, strangers, observers and witnesses,

As some of you may know, after living in NY as a theater artist for twelve years, with the impact of recent Gezi resistance in Turkey, I decided to go back, to experience and to share the agony caused by the current oppressive government in my homeland. The pain is intense here in this side of the world. Death is everyday, everywhere. It gets harder and harder to stand up and resist against the current political destruction. Today is history! The framework through which future generations will perceive today is being constructed at the moment. I think, art carries a major responsibility to keep a record of the moment, to remember the muted screams, to create awareness about the ways in which authorities construct social codes; and to hold on to the possibility of creating a new. Sometimes metaphors may reveal the most avoided truths. Maybe not today, but tomorrow.

In 2016, in Istanbul, I want to engrave my experiences and feelings about the moment on experimental stage, once again, this time in my mother-tongue. My new play is called DEM, which means blood, breath and moment in Turkish. It will be directed and performed by me and presented by Katharsis Performance Project. The money raised during this campaign will be used solely for rehearsal and performance space rental, set design and marketing expenses. 

To be able to construct DEM, I need your support. This time more than ever.

No matter where you are in the world, to be a part of this experience all you need to do is to choose an amount and proceed with your banking card or via paypal. If you cannot donate now, you can always help spread the word...

Contributions on behalf of Katharsis Performance Project may be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Hope we can make it again!

Yours,

Fulya Peker

Hope we can make it again!
Yours, 
Fulya Peker

story:
Our beloved Arturo Galster has passed away.  We are committed to honor his legacy, life, and work in an event fit for royalty.  On Monday September 22, at 7:30pm, we will be holding “A Celebration of the Life of Arturo Galster” at the Castro Movie Palace in San Francisco. 

The evening will be a multimedia celebration of all stages of Arturo’s life and work, including song, dance, visual art, video, film and photography.

The event is FREE and open to the public.

All Indiegogo funds will be used to cover theater operating costs, as well as all other production expenses.

Our goal of $5,000 will ensure a memorable celebration for Arturo.  All funds raised after that goal will go to a charity close to Arturo, in his name. 

Thank you for your kindness and generosity.

Born Arthur Francis Galster (known to his friends and loved ones as Arturo) on May 7, 1959, Mr. Galster was raised in Philadelphia, where he began performing in musicals while in high school. He moved to the Bay Area in 1978 and enrolled at the SF Art Institute, which he attended for 4 years.

By the early '80s, Mr. Galster was a rising star in the city's drag cabaret and theater world, a leader in what's been described as a new wave of ironic camp performance. Besides his iconic cabaret work as Patsy Cline, he created tribute performances to Marlene Dietrich and to Chet Baker, in the guise of the jazz musician's fictitious widow, Chesty Baker.

In 1986, he moved to Japan for four years, where he studied Japanese and traditional kyogen and kabuki theater. In recent years he was an active participant in hula studies and supporter of the preservation of traditional Hawaiian culture, as well as an enthusiastic Airbnb host.

Arturo Galster appeared in plays, musicals, cabaret shows and films in the USA and several other countries from the early 1980s until his death in 2014. He appeared in two cult drag films: as Noodles Nebula in Vegas in Space (Troma Entertainment, 1991) and as Patsy Cline in Virtue II (Margin Films, 1999). In addition, he appeared as a drag-queen streetwalker named Fabrege in “Javelin Catcher,” a 1996 episode of the television series Nash Bridges.

Onstage in San Francisco, Galster performed in a many high-profile and often high-camp theatrical productions that epitomized the city’s renowned queer culture from the mid-1980s on. Among his stage turns were roles in Naked Brunch, Phillip R. Ford’s Dolls, Christmas With the Crawfords, Eve, Dirty Little Showtunes, Naked Boys Singing, Half-a-Dozen Dorothies, Lavender Lockerroom, Stale Magnolias, Simply Stunning: The Doris Fish Story, Scalpel! The Musical, Hedwig and the Angry Inch and Pearls Over Shanghai.

From 1982 to 1989, Galster toured every summer as the incarnation of country music superstar Patsy Cline accompanied by a tribute band dubbed the Memphis G-Spots. The act appeared at nightclubs in Atlanta, Dallas, LA, Miami, New Orleans, NYC and SF, as well as London and Tokyo.

From 1995 to 2012, Galster was a regular performer in shows presented by impresario Marc Huestis at the Castro Theatre that brought together camp and classic films with appearances by stars of the movies accompanied by drag tribute shows. Galster performed in 15 of the productions, singing live in such personas as Conrad Birdie from Bye Bye Birdie, Endorra from Bewitched and Tim Gunn from Project Runway.

Galster also performed in a number of San Francisco’s noted queer nightclubs of the 1990s and 2000s, including Klubstitute, Dragstrip at the DNA Lounge and Trannyshack.

At various points in his career, Galster worked administrative jobs to supplement his theatrical work, most recently at Theatre ZinZanni and the Immune Enhancement Project, both in San Francisco.

Galster spoke German and Japanese, as well as some French and Spanish.

story:
“I saw someone right in front of me and I said, could you direct me please to Fourteenth Street, please, to get a bargain, I explained, although I could hardly remember what it was I wanted to buy.”


As my senior project here at SUNY Purchase, I am directing Jean-Claude van Itallie’s groundbreaking play Interview, an ensemble piece for eight actors. I am mounting this production in collaboration with a fantastic team of students from the Theatre & Performance and Theatre Design/Technology departments. 


It is our goal to present an outstanding piece of theatre that is so exciting because of how relevant it still is over fifty years after it was written. Jean-Claude van Itallie wrote about concerns that came out of what he was seeing around him in the face of technology, advertisement, and consumer culture. Performing this play now brings to light how these concerns are still relevant, perhaps even more so. 


What is this play about?

Interview doesn’t follow a clear plot line, opting instead for an extremely stylistic approach to a series of vignettes that fade into each other. The play offers snippets of everyday life written in a way that explores consumerism and acts as a social critique.


A section that stands out is one where a man speaks to his psychiatrist. He talks about how recently, he was watching television like any other night. As the commercials play, he begins to feel ill. He cannot figure out why, but suddenly he is throwing up. The commercials are making him sick, but beyond that, his slavery to them is the real catalyst. This is a play about people who are severely affected by media. They are obsessed with the impressions they think they are making on others and the societal rules they might not realize they are enforcing.

Where is the money going?

Though we are working hard to keep the costs of this production minimal, many expenses are inevitable. The school graciously allows us access to rehearsal and performance space, but everything else must come out of pocket. 


Our biggest expense is paint and materials for the set. We will be transforming the UnderGround theatre into a space conducive to movement while still fitting the aesthetic of the piece. We also must pay for the performance rights, which are owned by Dramatists Play Service, Inc. 


There are also a number of smaller costs that add up. Our stage management budget goes towards things like spike tape, binders, and a first aid kit. We are also putting money towards purchasing costume pieces, lighting gels and gobos. When we get closer to production, we will be putting up posters and other materials which cost money to print as well. 

Who are we?

Ensemble:


Caitlin McCutcheon, Amine Kassaoui, Lauren Busteed, Colin Ferguson, Brenden Paternostro, Alia Tejeda, Sam Stein, Libby Larkin 


Director: Gabriel Vasquez


Stage manager: Kayla Fecik


Dramaturg: Sara K


Set Design: Tasha Sandage


Costume Design: Claire Buckley


Sound Design: Dan Lemp


----


7:30pm March 5 & 6

1:30pm & 7:30pm March 7
@ the UnderGround!
Performing Arts Center at Purchase College 
Free Admission

story:
'...an ensemble work that embodies physical abandon embedded in layers of competition, seduction, manipulation and intimate bonding.'

'Beautifully explosive, relentless inquiry. These works reconstitute our world.'

Audience feedback from My Only Option was SABOTAGE

performed at MN Fringe in August 2014 as a work-in-progress.


from Taja, choreographer of the work:

This fundraiser goes directly to support the talented artists performing in My Only Option was SABOTAGE , June 18-21st at the Red Eye Theater. I want to say that again, every single penny goes to these incredibly talented, hard working performers! 

I am an emerging artist crafting my voice as a choreographer and in doing so received the production commission from the Red Eye to create this work. That means they gave me rehearsal space, performance space, a technical director to do lighting design, comprehensive promotional elements and feedback along the way to help me grow. Plus they gave me a little money which I've spent on costumes and our hundreds, yes hundreds of edible props. 

I am so grateful to have received this support from the Red Eye Theater, however their support also comes from fundraisers and grants and they commissioned new works from nine artists. Now we need a greater pool of financial support for the performers who make it all possible. 

This is a powerhouse cast of young artists, each of whom I've watched perform in other projects and companies and hand picked them for this piece because of their commitment, stage presence, improvisational background and ferocity. This project has been four and half years in the making, Kathleen Pender has been working with me four of those years and Emily Ban for two! This year I worked with Alexis for the first time with Alternative Motion Project when I set a new work on them and I knew she'd be a perfect fit for this ensemble. This is my first time working with Emma, Kimmie and Rush, but I've had my eye on them for awhile. I couldn't have more gratitude for all these dancers do to support my work. Please help me in supporting them. 

with love - t


The Team

 

Kimmie Allen, a Louisiana native, graduated with a BFA in Dance Performance and Choreography in 2006 from the University of Southern Mississippi, where she had the privilege of working with Shapiro and Smith and Trebien Pollard. In 2007, Kimmie moved to the Twin Cities where she received her massage therapy certification and has since been working as a bodyworker throughout the metro. Most recently Kimmie has been seen performing with ARENA Dances.  She is thrilled to have this opportunity to collaborate and share the stage with such unique and talented human beings during this year's New Works 4 Weeks. She is grateful to Taja for bringing her on to be a part of this process, and to her family and friends who always stand beside her, even in the craziest of times.

Photo Armour Photography


Emma Barber is a dancer, choreographer, and dance educator living in Minneapolis, MN, where she graduated in 2014 with a BFA in Dance from the University of Minnesota. Emma is interested in investigating alternative ways of knowing by privileging the experiences of the body and deconstructing conventional ideas of virtuosity, expectation, and intellect. Locally, Emma has performed with Morgan Thorson, HIJACK, BodyCartography Project, Samantha Johns, Maggie Bergeron, Mad King Thomas, Angharad Davies, Taja Will, Jennifer Glaws, and Vanessa Voskuil.


Alexis Heruth started her dance career three years old at Woodbury Dance Center, which lead her to continue at arts high school, Perpich Center for the Arts Education and Minnesota State University Mankato. While at MSU, Alexis studied with and performed works by Zenon Dance Company, Penelope Freeh, Gabriel Anderson, Lynn Andrews, Mary Davies Stark, Julie Kerr-Berry, Stuart Pimsler Dance & Theater, and Alan Sener. After graduating cum laude with a Bachelor of Fine Arts, Alexis joined modern dance company Alternative Motion Project where she performed at the Lab Theater this past March. She is currently working with local pop singer Ashley Hall and is an instructor at Woodbury Dance Center.

Photo by Dan Norman


Kathleen Pender grew up in Northfield, MN and received her B.A. in Dance from St. Olaf College. Her passion for dance performance and education, in its many forms, led her to study dance in Ghana while in college. Kathleen teaches creative dance, ballet, tap, and modern classes at the Northfield Arts Guild and assists classes with Young Dance in Minneapolis. She also works as Company Administrator with Stuart Pimsler Dance & Theater. Kathleen is excited to be a part of SABOTAGE for the fourth summer in a row and is grateful to Taja for her artistic integrity and thoughtfulness of craft.

Photo by Patsy Dew

Emily Ban grew up in New York City and graduated from Carleton College in 2012 with majors in Dance and French. While at Carleton she had the opportunity to work with several Twin Cities based dance artists and perform at The Kennedy Center with the American College Dance Festival. Since moving to Minneapolis in 2013 Emily has been moving, making faces, and working in Education at The Cowles Center. She is grateful for and inspired by this community.


Rush Benson is an actor, dancer, teacher, musician, and choreographer originally from Minneapolis, MN. Benson, a Gustavus Adolphus graduate of 2013, is currently a company member with the Flying Foot Forum. Rush works as a musical theater choreographer and dance teacher at Washburn High School and Ramsey Middle School. You may have recently seen him in Bloomington Civic Theaters production of La Cage Aux Folles, or taken class from him at Zenon Dance School. Look for him next premiering an original work created for Rhythmically Speaking in August.


Choreographer Taja Will creates work using the moving body to explore realities of social consciousness. She delves into images, emotions and ideas in the creative process, and her performances parallel everyday extremes. For Taja, the body is a vehicle by which to explore the experience of an individual within community. Her techniques straddles the line between movement and voice; resulting in performances which uniquely marry the sonic and kinetic. Will’s work uses techniques of structured improvisation, choreography and contact improvisation to manifest an aesthetic of agency and spontaneity.


Will’s work has been presented throughout the Twin Cities and nationally. Over the past year she performed Terpsichore Told Us To with longtime collaborative partner Blake Nellis at the Walker Art Center Choreographers’ Evening, set a new work i dare you to touch my dangerous skin on Twin Cities modern dance company Alternative Motion Project, completed I Am the True Vine in collaboration with Paul Rudoi with a commission from the American Composer’s Forum Live Music for Dance program, choreographed Love, Obviously for Hamline University’s Dance Ensemble and created, performed in Aftershock : Sampling Impact an evening length improvisation commissioned by the Institute of Environmental Studies at Brown University.


In addition to her artistic work Will maintains a healing practice in the modalities of developmental psychotherapy, somatic bodywork, energy medicine, personal coaching, guided meditation, holistic wellness and healing justice. Her practice is nestled inside the space of the People’s Movement Center, an emerging collective of people of color, indigenous, queer and trans healing justice practitioners that strive to build leadership, economic sustainability, and healing spaces for ourselves and a broader community.


Photo by Denis Jeong

story:
We Believe Dancers Should Perform. Please Help Us Make It Happen! 

The point of studying ballet is to perform. It is performing that gives students the confidence they need to compete or to succeed in a professional career of any kind. Stage experience enables students to develop grace, confidence, and stage etiquette.

The Only Thing Holding Us Back Is Finances

Jaelyn Fellona, IBT Director:

"Between securing the venue, paying for guest artists and promotion materials, production costs for Nutcracker add up quickly. It takes incredible amount of time, dedication, and patience on part of our Artistic Director and our talented students to produce a show. And yet, none of it is enough if finances are not in place. In the past we struggled to produce full-length ballets on very little resources. But if we keep doing it, the company will simply go broke."

IBT Has Talented Students and Exceptional Teachers

Our kids study to become professional ballet dancers. IBT students, who are part of the company, have rigorous schedule: they dance for 20 (twenty) or more hours per week and spend numerous extra hours rehearsing for professional-level performances. 

These kids sacrifice a lot to dance and put their whole hearts into dancing. Trained in the famous Vaganova Syllabus (Russian Classical Ballet Method,) they study Ballet, Pointe, Variations, Partnering, Character Folk Dance, Contemporary, Stretch, Ballet History, and Russian language. All of these classes are graded and leveled. 

IBT regularly participate in prestigious classical ballet competitions, such as Youth America Grand Prix, Tanzolymp Berlin, Arabesque Perm, Russia, American Ballet Competition, and World Balker Competition in Florida. In addition, they are coached by Guest Teachers from Boston Ballet and Mariinsky Ballet (ex-Kirov Ballet of St. Petersburg, Russia). 

IBT would value your contribution, no matter how small! Your donation is tax deductible!* 

Please help us by

  • sharing this video and campaign on Facebook and Twitter;
  • emailing friends who you think would support our cause;
  • spreading the word about our amazing company and students.

THANK YOU!


* IBT: HELP US PERFORM is a fiscally sponsored project of International Ballet Theater under the umbrella of Russian-American United Arts Council, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit arts organization. Contributions on behalf of IBT: HELP US Perform are payable to International Ballet Theater and are tax deductible less the value of any goods or/and services received, as allowed by law. After you made your donation please contact IBT to receive your tax deductible donation form.

Damsel Productions

Last year, Hannah Hauer-King and Kitty Wordsworth co-founded Damsel Productions with the key aim of producing new plays written by women. Last November, Damsel produced Dry Land at Jermyn Street Theatre, which was very well received by the critics. The Independent described it as “an auspicious debut for Damsel Productions, the ironically named and inspiring new company dedicated to putting provocative, true and honest aspects of female experience centre stage.” 

It's an exciting prospect that the company's ethos seems to appeal to people, and we are beginning to garner some support in the industry. Of course, Damsel is just one small cog in a far greater movement towards gender equality in theatre, but it's an honour to be recognised as playing a small part in that movement. Hannah Hauer-King wrote an article in the Independent about why we do what we do: Indy Article.

Damsel has been given the incredible opportunity to produce a new play called Fury, showing at Soho Theatre 5-30 July 2015. The play, by talented emerging writer Phoebe Eclair-Powell, was shortlisted for the Verity Bargate Award and won the Soho Young Writers Award 2015. Hannah Hauer-King will direct.

Fury is a chilling and powerful modern take on Medea, exploring motherhood, class and social culpability. With an all-seeing chorus, it takes an unapologetic look at the life of its fallible but fervent tragic hero, young single mum Sam - the kind of woman who is often judged before she's even opened her mouth. 

What We Need & What You Get

Damsel is committed to delivering the most honest and compelling production of this new play, and we hope its success will help us to continue with our work. As an emerging company we need all the support we can get, and we are currently in a position where your help in raising an extra £2,000 will be invaluably beneficial to Damsel in producing female-led productions now and in the future. Any amount, large or small, will make a significant impact.

Your contribution will also guarantee perks, which you can find to the side. If making a larger donation is something you might be interested in, please email kitty@damselproductions.co.uk, as we would love to meet with you to discuss more personally what the money would mean to our company.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate at this time, it would be just as fantastic if you could forward this on/spread the word/tell any friends and colleagues that you think would be interested.

Thank you for your time and support, and please don’t hesitate to get in touch directly should you want any more information or details about Damsel Productions.

Remember that you can use the Indiegogo share tools!

Fury runs from 5-30 July at Soho Theatre.

@DamselProd #Furytheplay
story_txt:
Damsel Productions 

Last year,
 Hannah Hauer-King and Kitty Wordsworth co-founded Damsel Productions 
with the key aim of producing new plays written by women. Last 
November, Damsel produced Dry Land at Jermyn Street Theatre, 
which was very well received
 by the critics. The Independent described it as “an auspicious debut 
for Damsel Productions, the ironically named and inspiring new company 
dedicated to putting provocative, true and honest aspects of female 
experience centre stage.” 
It's an exciting prospect that the company's 
ethos seems to appeal to people, and we are beginning to garner some 
support in the industry. Of course, Damsel is just one small cog in a 
far greater movement towards gender equality in theatre,
 but it's an honour to be recognised as playing a small part in that 
movement. Hannah Hauer-King wrote an article in the Independent about 
why we do what we do: Indy
 Article.
Damsel has been given the incredible opportunity to produce a new play called Fury,
 showing at Soho Theatre 5-30 July 2015. The play, by talented emerging 
writer Phoebe Eclair-Powell, was shortlisted for the Verity Bargate 
Award
 and won the Soho Young Writers Award 2015. Hannah Hauer-King will 
direct.

Fury is a chilling and powerful modern take on Medea,
 exploring motherhood, class and social culpability. With an all-seeing 
chorus, it takes an unapologetic look at the life of its fallible but 
fervent tragic hero, young
 single mum Sam - the kind of woman who is often judged before she's 
even opened her mouth.  

What We Need & What You Get
  

Damsel is committed to 
delivering the most honest and compelling production of this new play, 
and we hope its success will help us to continue with our work. As

 an emerging company we need all the support we can get, and we are 
currently in a position where your help in raising an extra £2,000 will 
be invaluably beneficial to Damsel in producing female-led productions 
now and in the future. Any amount, large or small,
 will make a significant impact.


Your contribution will also guarantee perks, 
which you can find to the side. If making a larger donation is something
 you might be interested in, please email
kitty@damselproductions.co.uk, as we would love to meet with you to discuss more personally what the money would mean to our company. 

Other Ways You Can HelpIf you are unable to donate at this time, it would be just as fantastic if you could forward this on/spread the word/tell any friends and colleagues that you think would be interested.Thank you for your time and support, and please don’t hesitate to get in touch directly should you want any more information or details about Damsel Productions.Remember that you can use the Indiegogo share tools!Fury runs from 5-30 July at Soho Theatre.@DamselProd #Furytheplay
